text: - Ladies and gentlemen, colleagues from the EU majority in this Parliament: please stop the emotional, half-hysterical numbers with an air of moral superiority.Nor should we as a Parliament pretend to be able to veto this.The only people who had to and could make a political decision in this matter were the people of the United Kingdom, and within the European Union there are many sympathizers of what Britain is doing now.Everything else is a technical settlement.If we could do something useful here, instead of all sorts of suggestions of vengeance or all sorts of proposals for permanently linking free trade to open immigration borders, it is to express our wish, our political wish, to treat the United Kingdom without rancor asa privileged partner and an exceptionally good friend.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Madam President, the statements today by Europhile party political leaders were everything I had anticipated and feared: total misrepresentation of facts and issues by the Socialists and the EPP Group, and misleading interpretation of history, UK economics and EU evolution by the Liberal Democrats, all allowed to pass uncorrected. This morning has seen political theatre, histrionics and political opportunism at full throttle by the Europhiles, and all because the United Kingdom has chosen to leave the European Union.  Well, I suggest we get real and start adopting grown-up politics because there is a serious leg of negotiations ahead of us and we do not need to see yet more Project Threat, Revenge and Penalty from the likes of Mr Juncker, Mr Barnier and Mr Verhofstadt. That is not helpful, and all it does is pander to a press which at the moment is misrepresenting both the EU position and the United Kingdom position. I do not feel that is helpful. So please can I ask everybody to calm down and be calm, and get on with it.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: – Madam President, the process of Brexit has formally started and is testing political and technical capacities on both sides to get a timely and – as Michel Barnier said – successful agreement. The challenges the Union is now facing in the context of the UK withdrawal are well understood and also shared by the Union institutions. The European Parliament is, and will be, at the forefront of the process and has shown a high level of political openness and cooperation, but also unity, in helping to define the Union’s path for the upcoming negotiations. We cannot but welcome the constructive approach set out in the letter notifying the UK’s intention to withdraw and setting out the approach to the negotiations, but the truth is that the really hard choices are yet to come, and for many citizens transparent negotiations will be a learning process. We want to ensure legal certainty and stability and to avoid disruption for citizens and businesses across the Union through an orderly and phased withdrawal, in line with Union law and with a view to mitigating economic, political and emotional – Mr Annemans – damage. But this damage is already a fact of life. European institutions are united on basic guiding principles and values, as well as on ensuring the protection of the Union’s autonomy and legal order. All this sets the right path for cooperative and, above all, principled negotiations based on good faith. For the European Parliament the principles are clear. First and foremost, we must defend and promote the interests of the citizens of the Union whom we represent, and safeguard the integrity and the coherence of the constitutional framework of the Union. These are the key building blocks for the negotiation and also the absolute boundaries on the basis of which the European Parliament will assess the outcome of the withdrawal negotiations through the consent procedure. We must be clear that abandoning membership cannot lead to a status quo ante and to unrealistic expectations. Let me finish just by expressing my conviction that the concerns of those who were against abandoning membership should not remain unaddressed.

name: Sergei STANISHEV
text: – Madam President, the time for regrets is over. The process of the UK leaving the European Union is under way. What we need is sober heads, good faith, but also a very clear mandate from the European institutions. This is what this House is doing today. First and foremost, we should aim to overcome the uncertainty regarding the lives of both EU citizens on the island and UK citizens in the European Union. Their lives should not be used as a bargaining chip, as has been underlined many times. There is also the issue of security cooperation, which is beneficial for both sides in this process. Second, trading freely would be in everyone’s interest, but the UK cannot have a better deal outside the Union and the single market than it has currently. In any future arrangement, the UK will have to play by the same rules as everyone else. Third, last but not least, we must also urgently launch debates on how the EU of 27 will adjust its budget, its policies and its institutions after UK withdrawal, in order to respond to the expectations for our citizens.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Madam President, the decision of the citizens of the United Kingdom is legal and sovereign. No one who claims to respect the rules of democracy can say otherwise. Any attempt to punish, humiliate and harm British citizens is deeply wrong. He will acknowledge the failure of the federalist attempt at politics and show a guilty conscience. The United Kingdom is our friend, ally and ally - a key pillar of our common defense in extremely difficult times. Northern Ireland and Gibraltar are undoubtedly an integral part of the United Kingdom and no such question can be asked. What needs to be achieved and worked out in the negotiations, and they will be conducted between the Heads of State and Government, is a good, profitable and fair deal in relations between the European Union and the United Kingdom. A deal that must guarantee the rights and legitimate interests of British citizens in the Union and European citizens in the United Kingdom. That's it. Nothing more and nothing less.

name: Jill EVANS
text: – Madam President, I was elected to represent the Welsh national interest, and that is what I will continue to do. The people of Wales have the democratic right to decide on their own future, and that includes the kind of EU withdrawal that takes place and the way that it affects our nation. The devolved administrations of the UK, including Wales, should be involved at every stage of the negotiations. I do not accept that the interests of Wales can be ignored by the UK Government, but that is exactly what is happening, despite the publication of the white paper ‘Securing Wales’ Future,’ produced by Plaid Cymru and the Welsh government. It is a comprehensive and constructive plan, which includes our continuing participation in the single market, which is a top priority for our economy and our communities. I see Wales’ potential as a successful nation. We have a lot to contribute to this process and to build in the future, and our voice must be heard.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, allow me to salute once again the courage of the British people, who were able to vote against the prophets of doom who announced chaos in the event of Brexit. Yes, the British democracy, one of the oldest democracies in the world, has been able to thwart the prognosis of the globalist technocracy which is rampant in Brussels, but also in Paris. Now we owe it to ourselves and you owe it to yourself to respect the sovereign decision of the people. No need to threaten the British, we all have an interest in this exit being done in serenity and respect. The UK is not leaving Europe, it is leaving the European Union, a supranational organization that was built without the peoples, and even against them, by organizing the collective impotence of our nations for the sole benefit of the multinationals. For a long time now, the peoples have been asking you to put an end to this bureaucratic functioning, which is detrimental to democracy, and its ideological orientations which harm our vital interests. This is particularly the case with the dogma of the free movement of capital, goods and people. Europe, our Europe has been around for millennia, and you are destroying it. We must therefore rebuild it through useful cooperation, by giving our nations back their sovereignty, that is to say by giving back to our peoples their freedom, starting with that of defending their identity, their culture, this formidable heritage that we must transmit and enrich. This is the fundamental right of peoples to self-determination and to remain masters of their own destiny.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, talk of Brexit and divorce reminds me of the song ‘50 ways to leave your lover’. You know the one: ‘Slip out the back, Jack; Hop on the bus, Gus’ and now we have ‘Say day-day, May’. I wish it was that simple but this divorce, after 44 years and with no precedent, looks like it is going to be tough, and possibly rough. For that reason we need calm heads, clear minds and creative thinking, and with Michel Barnier at the helm, I think we have the package. Where Ireland is concerned, we are very grateful to all groups in the European Parliament for taking the concerns of our Taoiseach, our government and my colleagues on board. The special circumstances of Ireland are referenced, and this sends out a powerful message to the citizens of Ireland and of Europe that when one country, no matter how small, is adversely affected, disproportionately threatened, the European Union will stand in solidarity behind them. And boy are we threatened, both economically and politically. But with this solidarity we can be confident that the terms of the Good Friday Agreement will be observed to the letter, that there will not be, cannot be and must not be a return to a hard border and that the prosperity of Ireland, especially our exporting sector, must not and cannot and will not be sacrificed on the high altar of expediency or pride.  Common sense not nonsense, pragmatism not pride must prevail. This is the best way to leave your lover.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: – Madam President, last June I toured my constituency, day in and day out, making clear my concerns about the dangers of Britain leaving the EU – dangers for our economy and British businesses, and the threat to the jobs they create; dangers for British workers, as the Tory right clamour to use Brexit to spark a bonfire of EU workers’ rights; dangers for British and EU citizens, with our cooperation on issues like counter-terrorism and security linked to our EU membership.  We lost the EU referendum, and while it saddens me to say it, Britain is leaving the EU – but those dangers are still there. In all our countries, there are families for whom the Brexit vote has created worrying uncertainty – millions of people concerned about their rights to live and work in countries they have made home. Citizens across Europe are now at risk of the economic consequences of a bad deal – or even worse, no deal at all – and people in all 28 countries will suffer if Brexit means competition on low wages, lax environmental standards and scaled back rights for workers and consumers. These are the people we represent, and these are the people to whom this Parliament must give a voice.  It will not always be easy to take the responsible path in the coming months, but it is what we must do. There are some in this House and beyond who are actively hoping to plunge Europe and Britain into chaos through a disorderly no-deal Brexit. Why? Because they have no answers to the questions that constructive negotiations will bring. So let us work for a constructive deal. And to those leave campaigners who now sit in the British cabinet or on the benches opposite – there is still one of them there, I can see – you won. Now take responsibility for the promises you made. As we all consider how we conduct ourselves over the coming weeks, let us remember that we are here representing people whose lives and livelihoods depend on the outcome. Serious times call for a serious response. (Applause)

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: - Madam President!Britain, Prime Minister Theresa May said, is leaving the EU, but not Europe.This reminds us that, contrary to current, exclusive news, the Union is not Europe.We should not forget about it in negotiations with Great Britain.We should not forget about the common heritage and common interests that will bind us also when Great Britain leaves the Union.The negotiations must not be about punishing the United Kingdom for a democratic decision consistent with the right to leave the Union enshrined in the treaties.The Union cannot be a community based on fear and coercion, because this is the way to its end.Instead, we should start a process of profound reform of the Union along with the negotiations, restoring its spirit of freedom and solidarity based on freedom.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: – Madam President, as a Scottish European I have long wondered how I would feel today. The answer is, I am heartbroken, not for myself, but for the people I serve, for future generations. Scotland will not be silent within this process, as our rights are taken away by an administration we do not support, by a vote that we clearly rejected and a process that is demonstrably against our interests. While being heartbroken, I am also angry. I am angry at this process, and I am angry at the way the UK is representing itself, doing a bad thing badly. Mrs May and Nigel Farage do not speak for Scotland, do not speak for me, and do not speak for 48% of the UK’s population. The UK is not one bloc, much as Mrs May would like it to be; the UK is a complicated set of various interests, all of which are better reflected in this resolution than in anything the UK Government has put forward to date. Scotland will not be silent in this process, and Scotland’s top priority, in the words of our First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, is to keep our citizens safe. Scotland is your home, you are welcome here. I appreciate that nothing is agreed until everything is agreed but please, colleagues, let us make our citizens feel safe, our citizens from the UK in other countries, and citizens from other nations in ours. Let’s deal with that first, let’s deal with that fast and let’s deal with it now.

name: Herbert REUL
text: - Madam President, Mr Presidents, my dear colleagues! I don't need to add much. Brexit is annoying. I think it's a mistake in the end too. But now it just comes down to dealing with it properly, dealing fairly with it, doing the work cleanly. I think what the Commission, what President Juncker and also what Michel Barnier has said is totally in order. Now you have to work properly step by step and deliver good results. On the other hand, such a difficult situation is always an opportunity, an opportunity for the remaining 27. We should perhaps talk about that more often. A chance to rely a little more on each other again, to have more confidence in each other, to become a little more reliable and to represent the joint project more aggressively to the outside world, to concentrate on the essentials and to ensure that the European project triggers enthusiasm in people again. It is perhaps no coincidence that these days people are taking to the streets everywhere and professing their faith in Europe. We must seize this opportunity. For this we need good results, proper work, mutual reliability and proof that we are able to solve the problems and the concerns. We have to prove that the problems that are worrying people can be solved by us, by the politicians who sit here in the European Parliament. And then things will end well. And if we provide evidence that there is an opportunity for employment and prosperity in Europe, if we perhaps try more to develop economic innovation and economic strength, and not just talk about how to compensate for difficulties and weaknesses but to look ahead -: I think this can be a great opportunity, even if Brexit is the result big mistake is.

name: Jens GEIER
text: - Madam President, President Juncker, Minister, ladies and gentlemen! Mr Barnier, you mentioned in your statement that clarifying the financial relationship between the EU and the UK is about clearing the accounts, not a penalty, and you are absolutely right. The UK did not buy into a company that it is now withdrawing capital from, but has invested for a period in a political alliance for which it has received political and economic benefits and services. Even if the United Kingdom no longer has any appreciation for this, the agreements that are signed by a British government official must be respected, even if these agreements extend beyond the British exit. To put it figuratively: Even in an English pub you can't have a fun evening, eat and drink well and just leave before the bill comes. This applies to the medium-term financial framework - which has been signed by the United Kingdom - this applies to the existing commitment appropriations from the current EU budgets - all of which the UK has agreed to - and this applies to the pension costs for European civil servants - many of them are from the UK - whose work the UK has benefited from during the membership period.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: – Madam President, I do not want to dwell on the past today, but rather to look to the future. We all need to come together with a plan that works for everyone and build a good foundation for our future relationships with the European Union. For the sake of all our people, the United Kingdom and the European Union need to work together as strong allies and close friends when we leave.  Europe has been a strong friend to Northern Ireland and gave us strong support during our darkest days. I am confident that friendship will continue. I welcome the fact that all sides want a frictionless border. However, we all know that finding a solution will require a lot of innovative thinking. Any solution must not diminish Northern Ireland’s place as an integral part of the United Kingdom, as enshrined in the principle of consent in the Belfast Agreement. And can I make it clear to you, Mr Barnier, that I will not accept a hard border. I will also not accept an internal UK border. I would also urge EU leaders not to heed those who are merely using Brexit as an excuse to break up the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. Let me also say to you very clearly – and I hope your are listening, Mr Barnier, and not twiddling with your telephone as you seem to be doing; I would suggest, with the greatest respect, that you actually listen to the speech – that Dublin does not speak for Belfast. We will take care of ourselves.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: - This debate might not have happened today, there might not have been a resolution and all the related troubles, if in a country that I personally admired (he was an inspiration to me when I was behind the Iron Curtain), this existential issue would be be or not to be in the EU has not become a hostage of intra-party settlements and games, and if the referendum itself had not been so poisoned by demagogy and untruth. But Brexit is a fact: we go into the unknown knowing only that a different vision of the future prevails in Scotland, a different vision of the future prevails in Northern Ireland, another - in England itself. We have a roadmap for this uncertain future in the form of a motion for a resolution, and from now on, we will shape the fate of the European Community in 27 countries and we do not need any special prompts from our English colleagues. The motion for a resolution corresponds to the ideas of my delegation, and we have a lot of interest, given our almost one million compatriots in the British Isles. The truths are fundamental: agreement is better than no agreement, orderly divorce is better than uncontrolled breakup in anger, break up first, then shape the future, the situation in Britain cannot be better than any other country. I see a refreshment on the European continent, also in my country, and this is a sign of a certain reflection that was triggered by Brexit.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: - Madam President, no one has anything to gain from the UK leaving the European Union. Breakup is always painful, and if there is strength in unity, disunity is a terrible source of vulnerability. The British have nothing to gain by finding themselves isolated on the international scene and losing all the benefits that membership of the European Union brought them: freedom of movement, freedom of residence, the single market, the charter fundamental rights, and so on. The European Union will also lose. She finds herself with a limb amputated, weakened in many of her policies and with millions of citizens with uncertain futures. Again, the list goes on. But while the pain that all pro-Europeans feel today is severe, we remain politicians nonetheless. So, despite the sadness that we may feel as individuals vis-à-vis our colleagues, comrades or friends, we must move forward and turn this political crisis into an opportunity for the refoundation of Europe. We will have to fight to ensure that citizens are the first priority in the UK exit negotiations, and then in the possible partnership that will follow. But, above all, we will have to hear the anger that carried the supporters of Brexit and reform Europe in depth so that tomorrow, membership of the European Union is once again evident to its inhabitants. The Europe of protection, of peace, of prosperity, the Europe we love must regain all its splendor. The democratic start will be the condition for the survival of the European project.

name: Franck PROUST
text: - Madam President, finally, we are gathered today because the United Kingdom has finally launched the procedure for withdrawing from the European Union. The least that can be said is that it has been a long road, synonymous with a certain lack of preparation on the part of the British government. On behalf of the French delegation of the PPE Group, I wish good luck to Michel Barnier, who has the experience and the charisma to conduct these negotiations effectively and pragmatism. On the one hand, there are the technical aspects, which number in the thousands: the resolution we are presenting today, which makes our institution a democratic bloc capable of agreeing on the red lines and which it is important to defend in the negotiations, is a working basis for the Commission and the Member States. But on the other hand, there is the act of communicating, of explaining, of speaking to citizens, which is a matter of concrete and useful politics. We are elected officials in contact with women and men in our Eurocirconscriptions. In the vagueness that has reigned so far, some may have said to me: "You see, sir, it does not change anything to get out of the European Union", believing that the UK was already outside. Populists or extremists also play on the fears and isolated national destinies of the Union, but let's be honest: isolation leads to decline. No longer belonging to our community of destiny will inevitably weaken this undoubtedly disunited kingdom tomorrow, with Scotland eager to be part of the world's leading economic power, the European continent. Things must be clear: the United Kingdom has chosen to leave the single market, it will lose economic sovereignty. If Theresa May wishes to maintain a stable relationship with the European Union tomorrow, she will have to fulfill the political and financial commitments made by her country. Before leaving the table, you have to pay the bill and a divorce is expensive, Sadly.So, let's not procrastinate!The citizens cannot stand lukewarm water any longer.Let us be frank with our British friends, pragmatic in the negotiations and realistic about the necessary partnership which will forge our relationship in the future.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Jacques Delors liked to repeat that it is impossible to fall in love with the internal market. He probably continues to be right, and it is perhaps for this reason that the British have left. Yet the single market is one of the success stories of the European integration process. If Brexit has one merit, it is to bring out more and more benefits, perceived or not, that the single market achieves in everyone's life. Our task is to preserve the values ​​and freedoms that underlie them in their integrity. Brexit takes European institutions and member states one step further. In an increasingly divided, more protectionist world, more and more hostage to extremisms of all kinds, today is the day of European pride. At stake is not the future, however important and dear to us, of the United Kingdom, but the destiny of 27 European peoples. To these we owe answers. History will judge us on these.

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I think most of us would never have wanted to have this debate. I think most Europeans would never have wanted Brexit to be talked about. Now we must face this negotiation phase with decision, but also with balance, dear President Barnier. We will approve a very precise and precise resolution today with timing and foresight. I want to thank the President of Parliament and the presidents of the political groups who have signed up for this. We know that the negotiations will be neither short nor simple. What needs to be done is to speak with a single voice, with the voice of the 27 countries and three institutions that must march together. We need to negotiate with our citizens in mind, we need to be ambitious with our demands and transparent and linear with our values ​​of unity. It is necessary to use the language of truth. Brexit, mind you, will not stop us: it was reiterated in Rome on the occasion of the anniversary of the treaties. We must look ahead without distractions and alibis, certain that our project of a Union of Peace and Prosperity will be strengthened. This, dear colleagues, is the opportunity to relaunch our Union.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: - Madam President! A majority in Great Britain has decided: out of the EU. And that has consequences: Almost three million EU citizens now live in the UK. They live, love, work, have married, pay taxes, have raised their children - and what about their future? Completely uncertain. More than 1.5 million Britons in the EU feel the same way: today they are still Union citizens with all the associated rights, but what will happen in the future, what will happen in two years after they actually leave? Conservative David Cameron will go down in history as a man to whom short-term populist success was more important than the fate of all these people. And a comment to UKIP: You are not taking back your country. You are trying to destroy this continent, and you do not care how much your citizens and our citizens will suffer from it. But listen carefully: we will not let you succeed. We will continue to fight for a Europe based on solidarity and justice, a Europe where facts expose the lies, a Europe that protects its citizens and does not leave them with the prospect of an uncertain and gloomy future. And I hope that one day the UK will become a real, full member of this European Union.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: – Madam President, while I join my voice with those who express their regrets to see the United Kingdom leaving the EU, I respect the will of the British people. I still believe they were wrong.  It is a difficult moment, as we have never faced such a complex challenge to undo the deep ties that we have founded in our common history. However, let’s be pragmatic, as British people like to be.  As chairwoman of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I want to send a strong message both to the EU and UK. We are bound to work together constructively in the best interest of our citizens, to ensure a clean and safe environment and a high level of public health and food security, and to pursue our common commitment to the climate change.  We will need to ensure a rapid transfer of our European Medicines Agency as soon as is practical, as is said in the resolution, because we have to make sure to avoid uncertainty regarding its future and limit the loss of skilled staff and their vital expertise. So we have to cooperate together in good spirit. It makes no sense believing that environmental and health issues stop at the borders.  I wish us all the best for the future.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Madam President! This Brexit will keep us busy for a long time. Like many of my colleagues, I feel that he was a bad decision, unprepared, thoughtless, and short-sighted. How many do I regret what is happening now. We will miss our British friends, and times will be tougher for the people of the UK too. But we have to take note: History cannot be stopped. It's like divorce proceedings, but you also have to think about the collateral damage. Above all, bystanders are not allowed to pay extra. That's the over three million EU citizens who currently live in the UK. They made their decision to move to the country on the basis of other conditions. You have contributed to the prosperity of the UK. You and your children now have to live in tolerable uncertainty. Actually, their fate should be out of dispute. We expect clear answers from our political friends, and it shouldn't be difficult for them, because fairness and pragmatism are qualities that we value in them.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: – Madam President, we can be certain that this resolution will not be popular in Brexit circles. There will definitely be those who will denounce it as impertinent, or worse. There are many in the United Kingdom who see leaving the European Union as a kind of liberation. It can take quite a while for illusions to dissipate. For the time being, the launching of Article 50 has brought with it an early silly season. Bizarre things are being said and, no doubt, will continue to be said. This can be irritating, even provocative, but that is no reason for us to follow suit. On the contrary, we can stay calm and pursue negotiations with the same professionalism and commitment that is reflected in this resolution. After all, the UK will always have a relationship with Europe. Our aim is, and should be, to frame the long term: to ensure that the future is a positive sum game.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: - Madam President, Minister, President of the Commission, regrets, sadness and disappointment still dominate when one considers the break chosen by a majority of British people. But our responsibility now is that of negotiation on the basis of a constructive but also pugnacious and determined strategy in the interests of European citizens, also with the idea that this rupture, far from weakening the Union, offers him a rebirth. The British Prime Minister says she is giving up on the single market because she refuses the freedoms that come with it. Despite these denials, his letter of termination shows on the contrary that everything will be done to access it, including through the window, if it is impossible through the door. Whatever name Ms. May gives to this agreement, we will not accept any free trade agreement that challenges our social or environmental standards or serves us as arbitration courts for dessert. We must be inflexible and sweep aside the Conservatives' threats to tax dumping or security. We must be inflexible, Mr Negotiator, especially on budgetary matters in order to protect an EU budget already under pressure and already weakened by the devaluation of the pound sterling.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Madam President, I would like to put forward our position and show it with three quotes from Shakespeare, a great British and European writer.  First, our position, our attitude as committed pro-Europeans, is very well described in Hamlet when Horatio describes the expression of the father of Hamlet: ‘a countenance more in sorrow than in anger’ – that will be our attitude in our negotiation.  Next, I would like to give a piece of advice to our British colleagues with another quote, because you should be very aware of what your bard Shakespeare has said: ‘we know what we are, but know not what we may be’. Finally, I would like to answer Mr Farage with a quote from Shakespeare that is probably a fake quote, which is very, very appropriate to someone that is a post-truth politician: ‘Love me or hate me, both are in my favour. If you love me, I'll always be in your heart. If you hate me, I'll always be in your mind’.

name: David MARTIN
text: – Madam President, in September 2014 I voted to keep Scotland in the United Kingdom union and in June 2016 I voted to keep the UK in the European Union. Today, I face the reality that Brexit will remove my country from one union and leave the other union hanging by a thread. Scotland voted overwhelmingly to remain in the European Union. Edinburgh, a city I have represented in this House for 33 years, voted 75%-25% to remain in the European Union. The overwhelming feeling in Scotland is that we are being dragged out of the European Union against our will, a feeling only compounded by Ms May’s determination to pursue a hard Brexit for which she has no mandate.  The resolution we are about to vote on recognises this fact, but provides no solution. The Council document calls for a flexible and imaginative solution to be found for Ireland. I, of course, agree, but I think the same should also apply to Scotland. The Scottish Government has put forward a bespoke proposal for Scotland, which I think deserves serious attention in this House. In conclusion, I want to say that if the UK does not show flexibility in these talks it will not only be the UK leaving the European Union, but the UK will not exist any longer.

name: Мария Габриел (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Mr Barnier, today we are setting out the principles that will guide the negotiations and the foundations of our future partnership. Mr Barnier, you are on the right track. The slogan of the negotiations should be: "Citizens first!". It is our duty to allay their concerns and give concrete answers, for example to students from other European Union countries who live in the UK and benefit from programs such as ERASMUS. Ensuring their rights must be our top priority from the beginning of the negotiations. The European Union must remain adamant about the four freedoms. Brexit has consequences and there can be no question of a Europe a la carte scenario. There can be no status similar to that of the Member States. The key is to have a clear vision for the way forward. First is the exit agreement, then the new partnership. To build a stable home, we need to start with the foundations, not the roof. It is the responsibility of the Member States to commit themselves to no parallel negotiations. Finally, the full involvement of the European Parliament. This is key to ensuring transparency and open public debate.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I disagree with those who say that nothing will change with Brexit, not least because we do not know what the consequences will be. Instead, I agree with those who say that the negotiation will be constructive if it has the interests of the citizens at its center: of European citizens and also of the citizens of the United Kingdom. No retaliation, no retaliation, therefore, but clear rules yes. And we need to repeat what the rules are for the European Union. Of course, respect for the four freedoms and, in the power of the European Union, the policy of developing international trade. Nobody thinks of demolishing the European building, but nobody is playing against it to divide or weaken the UK. The negotiation must have a political vision, we must make sure that in the end our friendship, our relationships, our collaboration are more robust. We must work together on this, and today's resolution is a good basis for us to start our journey.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Madam President, I believe in the Europe of today. I believe in our European project, a project that is based on the belief that together we are stronger and we do things better. That is why it makes me sad if you, Mr Farage and your friends, are likening this project to a prison. Let me remind you that 48% of the voters in the referendum did not share this this view and many millions did not actually participate. I also heard Mr Fox – if I am not mistaken – saying that he is calling for a close and deep partnership and for invisible borders. If this is what you are calling for, then welcome back into Europe. Welcome back into the European Union because this is what we are aiming for. Instead of that, you are, in practice, calling for the negotiation of a similar agreement to the ones we have with the US, Korea or Canada. If this is so, please do not be surprised that in this negotiation we will represent the interest of 27 countries, like we did in negotiations with Canada, the US or Korea. This should come as no surprise to you.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: - Madam President! Mr Juncker, dear Michel Barnier! This resolution is simply good. I support her, especially those points where it says "start negotiations under Article 50 as soon as possible". - Yes, we do. To negotiate in good faith - this is the declaration. Finally, the European Union negotiates as a whole of the EU-27 without breaking off individual states. We defend the interests of the citizens of the European Union. As an MP from Poland, I am interested in defending the interests of almost a million Polish citizens living in Great Britain, whose fate is uncertain. Britain cannot expect unilateral gains at the expense of the citizens of the European Union, and I support this too. I am aware that the EU-27 will be a diminished Union, but it does not have to be a weakened Union, and I am very heartfelt with my Labor Party friends in this House who have expressed their pain at the development of events.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen!I feel sorry for the people of the UK.They were misled for years - before the referendum and partly now.The EU was blamed instead of shared responsibility, the added value of membership was concealed, the fact that membership was also due to membership.Independence was promised, the split was risked and new dependencies created, “money back” was promised and the consequences withheld.There is no participation in the internal market without the acceptance of the four freedoms, without compliance with fundamental rights, without cost sharing, without the acceptance of the European Court of Justice.Rights and values, commitments made in 44 years, are the basis of the negotiations.No more and no less.Let's learn from it!

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: - Madam President, when many hoped that Brexit would be the beginning of the end of the European project, the broad inter-party political consensus in support of the resolution that we are going to pass today on the Brexit negotiations is in itself an extremely important sign of unity and hope. And it is also important that Parliament has set a clear priority, guaranteeing, under conditions of reciprocity, respect for the rights of European citizens residing in the United Kingdom and of British citizens residing in the European Union. And it is not to respect the rights of citizens, to subject them, as today in the United Kingdom, to 85 pages of unnecessary bureaucracy in order to obtain their right to residence permits. Freedom of movement is fully binding on the United Kingdom until the day of its departure and even after that while a transitional regime for access to the single market is in force. This Parliament will not give in to the defense of the rights of European citizens.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: – Madam President, in a couple of weeks I will take my six-year-old son to London for the first time; he will see the Cenotaph and I will tell him about the bravery of those men who fought in two European wars and to whom we will be eternally grateful. But he will not understand because, thank God, he has never known war. Although, not too far away from here – and you can laugh – but not too far away from here children his age and younger are dying in the poisonous clouds of Idlib, the same clouds that we saw over Flanders Fields a century ago.  It is for those generations of young Europeans, those born after the fall of the Berlin Wall, that the remaining 27 Member States need to stand united and together, and work out a reformed and stronger European Union. It is for those young generations of Brits that we need a fair deal and a continued relationship with the United Kingdom, because they did not vote to leave.  Let us, dear colleagues, politicians of this very old continent, show the young people in Britain and in Europe alike that Europe is not a place of hate, of pettiness or of revenge, but that we can learn the lessons of the past and reshape a future in which the negotiating table will always, always prevail over outright conflict.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Madam President, Brexit will be the most difficult, costly and unnecessary divorce in history. In the coming months and years, we can expect the EU 27 and the UK Government to end up in any number of catfights, but let me be crystal clear: whatever the cost, whatever the hassle, whatever the differences of opinions, this Parliament will serve the citizens of Europe. Period. We are their directly elected voice. We will be their strongest defender, their best advocate in this, and their ally. This goes for EU citizens and for UK citizens. We will not allow the Brexiters’ broken promises, half-truths and even lies to harm the citizens of the UK and EU any more than they have already done.  To the citizens of the 27 remaining Member States, I say we will never allow a post—Brexit UK to undermine your rights and conditions by competing in a race to the bottom. To the citizens of the UK, I say that we will continue to fight for your best interests, and we will keep a seat for you at our table.

name: Viviane REDING
text: - Madam President, a successful divorce is better than a failed marriage, and for this to be the case with Brexit, several conditions are necessary. First of all, priority must be given to the conditions of separation: custody of children, sharing of assets, right of access with reciprocity and speed. The European Parliament has understood this well by asking for guarantees for citizens, debts and external borders. Then there may be a transition period for everyone to adjust to their new life, provided that there is payment of child support under the supervision of the judge. Here too, the message is clear: no rights without duties, no access to the internal market without respect for the four freedoms. After divorce, and not before, it takes maturity to maintain civilized relationships, even if nothing will be the same. Hence our demands: neither dumping transforming the UK into a transit country, nor blackmail monetizing free movement or the security of citizens for trade. Divorce is a new beginning. For us, Brexit will be the renewal of Europe, with the treaties as a common thread.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: - Madam President, figures from the UK Treasury say that over the next five years, the British Treasury will lose more than € 122 billion.eur.Recent analyzes show that Brexit will lose half a million jobs in the coming years.Barclays Bank has confirmed that the relocation of activities in the banking sector outside the UK is necessary.That doesn't really sound optimistic.I would like to refer to the United Kingdom: we are suffering just like those of you who voted to stay in the EU.But we respect the will of the majority.We begin to look for a new future together.This period of uncertainty can last more than two years.If you conclude that living outside the EU will seriously damage your future, do not hesitate to go back.Reasonable politicians, however, do not allow their own people to be harmed.

name: David CASA
text: - Ir-Renju Unit huwa sieħeb importanti għall-Unjoni Evropea u għal Malta. Ir-Renju Unit ser jibqa ’sieħeb importanti. Imma huwa diżappunt għalina li r-Renju Unit għażel li ma jibqax membru tal-Unjoni Ewropea. Però rridu nżommu f’moħħna li ser jibqa ’jkun hemm rabtiet b’saħħithom anke wara li r-Renju Unit iħalli lill-Unjoni Ewropea. U għalhekk li ma nistgħux nidħlu għan-negozjati b’ċertu aġir ta ’konfrontazzjoni. Issa rridu nistinkaw u naraw kif ikun hemm l-aħjar kundizzjonijiet bejn l-Unjoni Ewropea u pajjiż terz li miegħu għandna relazzjonijiet tajbin. Madankollu r-Renju Unit irid jagħmel ċerti sagrifiċċji. Ma jistax jistenna privileġġi mingħajr ir-responsabbiltajiet li jiġu magħhom. Dan ifisser li rridu nimxu fuq ċerti prinċipji. Iż-żmien illi nkunu selettivi u nagħżlu li jaqbel lilna biss issa għadda. Ir-Renju Unit irid iħallas dak li hu dovut - din hija kundizzjoni obbligatorja sabiex in-negozjati jkunu possibbli. Fuq kollox irridu nżommu f’moħħna l-element uman illi huwa l-aktar kruċjali. Hija prijorità li miljuni ta ’tittadini Ewropej u Britanniċi fuq iż-żewg naħat nagħtuhom il-protezzjoni kollha tagħna lilhom u lid-drittjiet tagħhom. Jien konvint illi nistgħu nsibu l-kompromess meħtieġ.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Madam President, Romanian by nationality and historian by profession, I am fascinated by your great leader, Winston Churchill. But today I have to confess that I don’t know what he would say about Brexit or how he would judge the Brexiters. This is a real question mark.  When it comes to the status of the European citizens in the UK, the negotiations must be based on the principles of reciprocity and full equality among EU citizens. This means that we need to make sure that our citizens who currently live and work in the UK can continue to freely do so without any discrimination against them or between them based on their nationality. Under such circumstances, we can accept, as the EU, to grant the same status to the UK citizens in our Member States.  Equally important is the issue of security, defence and counterterrorism, where the EU and the UK are mutually fundamental. This is where we are reminded by the recent terrorist attack in London. Both the EU and the UK need to be wise and pragmatic. This is too important an issue to leave a security gap for those who threaten our common values and our challenges, equally the security of our citizens.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Shame on all those who now think they are talking bad words about the British, who meet this decision with penal sanctions, with absurd payment obligations, with political spite and adversity. True political greatness is shown rather by recognizing the relevant referendums, by respecting the fact that the British have decided to leave the European Union. You now have two options for responding to this. You have the possibility, following the Juncker and Schulz model, to centralize even more, to disempower the member states even more, to allow even less direct referendums. Or you can go the opposite way, you give the member states more options to make decisions, you upgrade the parliaments in the member states, you allow direct democracy in the member states, which can again take precedence over European Union law. What you should do now is to treat the British with friendship, to negotiate with the British - meaningful areas of cooperation - and not to behave like in a war of roses after a divorce or like two small children slimming down on each other to deal with it soberly and professionally like adults and to serve both interest groups accordingly.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I keep hearing what a positive project the European Union is. Article 8 of your beloved Treaty says ‘the Union shall develop a special relationship with neighbouring countries’ in a spirit of ‘good neighbourliness’. Well I get that, I understand that, I am with that, that makes a lot of sense. So why, if that is the case, would Mr Tusk have written Clause 22 in his Memorandum giving the Spanish a veto over the future of Gibraltar when everyone knows that the Spanish are antagonistic towards the wishes of the people of the Rock? And why, Monsieur Barnier, in a spirit of ‘good neighbourliness’, would you have plucked this bizarre figure of GBP 52 billion out of the air that you say is our final settlement payment?  Remember one thing. From the moment we voted Brexit to the moment we leave, we will have put GBP 30 billion net into this European Union, and you want another 50. It just does not work. For any negotiation in life to work both sides stake out a position. Both sides ask for more than they realistically expect to get. I understand that, but you have gone so far with this that it is just impossible for us to see any accommodation.  I think there needs to be give and take on both sides, and I think if you gave on the money and you gave on Gibraltar, then what I would like to see the United Kingdom Government doing is saying there are 3.3 million EU citizens living in the UK, they all came to Britain legally and we will now unilaterally guarantee their rights for the future. Both sides need to give on this for any sensible deal to come out of it. We can walk away without a deal, it will hurt European workers and European companies more than us, but surely it makes sense for both of us to come to a sensible accommodation.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, if we want to get to a sensible accommodation, Mr Farage’s speech is precisely the kind of nonsense that we should just ignore. I just want to say that Brexit is a lose-lose game. I would have much preferred for us to stay together. L’Union fait la force, we say in Belgium, and that remains the case today. But there is one thing where I believe no compromise is possible, and that is the only thing that really annoyed me in Mrs May’s letter. It concerns security cooperation. Security cooperation is an area where we cannot let lose-lose logic prevail. It is in the interest of the safety and security of all our citizens, British or otherwise, to cooperate deeply in matters of security, and what we cannot accept is that any other kind of consideration – trade, commercial, whatever – stands in the way. There is no trade-off here. It concerns the lives of men and women.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! The European Parliament - and this has been shown today - has a great responsibility for accompanying the negotiation process, and I have taken note with great attention that it has been explained to us that we will not only talk to one another today and at the end of the negotiations , but - Mr Barnier's offer and the Commission's offer - that we should be put in touch in the meantime, that we can obtain information, express our opinions, and thus exercise political influence. I think that is important because it is important that we above all - and these are the criteria that my group will also apply - pay attention to how the rights of the people who are directly affected by Brexit are protected. We will be careful to ensure that people's safety, especially in the north of Ireland, is preserved as a result of the negotiation process. People mustn't pay the price of Brexit. They did not cause it, there were other reasons for it. So they shouldn't pay him, and we'll take care of it. Let us work together here so that we can really exert influence here as a Parliament.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I find it fantastic that Mr Farage is using Article 217 of the Treaty on the Association Agreement. Now that he is leaving, he starts to read the Treaty and to find the Treaty so good. It is fantastic to see this enormous positive development, if I may say so. That said, what is clear in this debate is ‘let us put the citizens first’, and it does not make any difference whether they are EU citizens or UK citizens. We will be firm, we need to be firm to defend the unity and the interest of the European Union towards the UK authorities, but my appeal here in the House today is to be open, positive and generous towards UK citizens, because many of them, millions of them, want to keep their relationship, their link, their identity on the European level. And last but not least, my appeal also to the House is that, when we vote within a few minutes, we have a huge majority and almost unity in this House. It is key to do that, to have a united European Parliament, together with the EU negotiator and with the European Council, and I hope for a strong vote within a few moments.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, ‘divorce’, ‘sadness’, ‘electricity and heating bills’, ‘foolishness’, ‘disruption of transport links’, etc. ‘We will only speak about the future relationships when we settle on accounts’. ‘We are the champions, but on the other side are the losers’. ‘We will not leave them any single cherry of the cake’. That is a summary of the statements made both in the Chamber today and also in the media.  I would like to ask colleagues to calm down. Does anybody believe that in these negotiations there will be winners when it comes to citizens’ rights issues? Indeed, how successful can we call an arrangement where part of the success is achieved by discriminating against the citizens of another EU nation, or take businesses that are the backbone of economies? Do we really want to extend uncertainties for the next five or so years?  It is possible within the next two years to settle the past accounts and work on the comprehensive framework for the future relationships. This allows for it, business will wait for it, and in the end the European people want it. So good luck to you in the negotiations.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group.- (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, not all British people hate the European Union like Mr Farage does.I would like to remind you that 48% of British citizens voted to remain in the European Union, and I want to remember with particular affection and emotion Comrade Jo Cox, a British MP who was murdered during the referendum campaign.No one has ever forced the UK to do anything.I heard incredible words: threats, punishment, mafia.You have decided to join the European Union freely and you freely decide to leave the European Union.No retaliation, but you cannot force your chaos on us.No, therefore, parallel negotiations: as long as you are part of the European Union, you cannot negotiate with the WTO.We respond to the disorder of Brexit with the unity invoked by Juncker and Barnier, with the unity which is the quiet force of our institution.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, colleagues! That was a discussion today in a good tone, and I hope that many citizens have followed the discussion because they have seen that the major political groups, the European groups, have adopted an objective, constructive tone here and sadly, the populists and extremists that we have here in this house have reenacted. It was quoted as saying that there is fighting in the streets and that independence must be defended. It was a hard, aggressive tone. Objectivity here, aggressiveness there. I hope many citizens saw that in the discussion. By the way, I didn't get any answers. I asked whether you want to continue to be part of Europol now, whether you want to continue to be part of the internal market, whether you want to continue to be part of the research union. Mister Farage has not yet given any answers as to whether these partnerships are still correct or not. That means: the fundamental question of what leave really means remains on the table. At the end of the day, I cannot completely resist one remark, dear colleagues. If we look at the Council, then we have the situation there that when the heads of state and government are discussing Brexit, Theresa May is not here because that is one thing that the EU-27 have to negotiate. That means that Theresa May treats the other 27 states with respect. If we look at the parliamentary situation, we have Westminster, which has to vote in the end - that's where British interests are represented - and we have the European Parliament, which has to vote - that's where the interests of the EU-27 are represented. And that's of course why I'm interested in how Nigel Farage imagines it for the next two years. I want to respectfully acknowledge that Syed Kamall is not today spoke on behalf of his group.He gave the floor to colleagues who are not British to make the group's positions clear.I would like Nigel Farage to be a man of honor in the future and to let his Italian colleagues speak in future debates about Brexit in his group.Nigel Farage has been explaining to us over the last few years how good it is that the British are finally leaving the European Union.I would like him to finally set a good example and then no longer burden the debates in the European Parliament.Thank you very much for that.(Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I report that I have received four motions for resolutions in accordance with Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure.The discussion is closed.The vote will take place today, Wednesday 5 April 2017, at 12.00.I thank all those who took part in the debate, the President of the European Commission, the negotiator of the European Union, the representative of the Council and all the Members who have taken the floor during this debate.Parliament will play a decisive role during these negotiations, it will vote in the end for or against, respecting the rules of democracy.There are 751 parliamentarians in this House representing 500 million European citizens, all duly elected.There are neither mafia members nor gangsters, there are representatives of the peoples and this is not a question of national sensitivity, it is a question of civilization and democracy.(Applause)

name: Vicky FORD
text: – Mr President, I would like to raise a point of order under Article 11.2 about this morning’s debate. Calling other colleagues members of the mafia or gangsters does not show mutual respect, does not represent the views of the vast majority of the British people, and is not the view of the British Prime Minister, who wants to remain friends, allies and partners.  (Loud applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Asked the floor for an item on the agenda the Hon.Carver.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, there has been a lot of confusion in this House this morning, talking about British aggression over Gibraltar. Can I just remind colleagues across Parliament that it was actually Spain that sent one of their warships into Gibraltarian waters.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I do not think it is an item on the agenda under the regulation.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - 2017 March 29 The United Kingdom Government has submitted a report to the European Council formalizing the United Kingdom's decision to withdraw from the European Union. This report is the result of a referendum in the United Kingdom. And while this is an unprecedented event, which is unfortunate, as no Member State has yet left the European Union, we must ensure that the withdrawal takes place in an orderly manner and does not adversely affect the European Union, its citizens and the European integration process. The European Parliament represents all citizens of the European Union and therefore aims to protect the interests of all citizens throughout the UK's withdrawal process. Withdrawal negotiations must take place in an effort to ensure legal stability and help citizens have a clear picture of their future. The status and rights of European Union citizens residing in the United Kingdom and of United Kingdom citizens residing in the European Union would be governed by the principles of reciprocity, equality, equal treatment and non-discrimination. Until the United Kingdom leaves the European Union, all the four freedoms must be fully guaranteed, and any discrimination against EU citizens in their attempt to acquire the right to reside in the United Kingdom would be contrary to European Union law and intolerable.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing.- The UK's exit from the European Union is not a welcome development.Now that the process has begun, it must be as smooth as possible.In doing so, the objectives of both sides' long-term strategies must be borne in mind, as the link between the United Kingdom and Europe will be maintained.We need to conduct the Brexit negotiations professionally and with commitment, keeping calm.Our goal can only be to plan for the long term and achieve a positive outcome that all Member States will ratify with a calm heart.In doing so, compromises must certainly be made, but the interests of both EU and UK workers must always be taken into account.During the separation, we must constantly strive to cause as little damage and loss as possible to the citizens of the European Union.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I regret the UK's decision, but I also accept it.Anyone who no longer wants to remain part of a community must then bear the consequences of this decision: Great Britain retains its rights as an EU member until it leaves, but at the same time it is also necessary to fulfill existing obligations.This also applies to financial commitments resulting from the long-term EU budget, among other things.And it is clear: Those who decide against the EU can no longer benefit from our achievements and advantages.Either you are part of something or you are not.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - Once again, it is proven that the EU institutions live poorly with democracy and with the sovereign decisions of the peoples. It is not today. The stance of pressure, threat and blackmail exerted on the United Kingdom, following the sovereign expression of the popular will to leave the EU, is unacceptable and reveals the intentions that guide the EU institutions in this process. Among these intentions - which we vehemently denounce and fight - is to carry out an operation to launder EU policies and their consequences, and from there to force an escape forward in the deepening of European capitalist integration. The negotiation process that is now starting must be fair and balanced, based on the fundamental idea of ​​respect for the UK's sovereign decision. Defending and protecting the rights of both British citizens residing in EU Member States and citizens of EU Member States residing in the United Kingdom must be a priority of these negotiations. Rights such as: right of residence, right to equal treatment and non-discrimination, right of access to public services and social security, right to family reunification, international recognition of university degrees and training. Positive provisions regarding the free movement of persons must be protected.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - The withdrawal agreement, as well as the individual transitional measures, are scheduled to enter into force before the European Parliament elections in 2019. Until then, the United Kingdom has all the rights, benefits and obligations of a proper Member State. This fully applies to its financial liabilities. Managing the UK's withdrawal from the EU will not be an easy process. So far, it's a big unknown. However, setting priorities is important. These must be, in particular, the security and stable legal status of European citizens living in Britain, as well as of the British in the EU. The departure of one Member State can be an incentive to adapt the functioning of the European Union in such a way that no others want to leave. Brexit is primarily the result of the populism and gambling of former Prime Minister Cameron, who was willing to sacrifice decades of cooperation for a one-time election victory. National leaders should learn from this. They cannot continue to agree on something first, and if it is unpopular, they present at home that the European Union and officials in Brussels are to blame.

name: Ana GOMES
text: in writing. - For this Parliament there are very clear and necessary conditions for the approval, in 2019, of a possible agreement between the EU and the United Kingdom (UK), and it is to this excellent Resolution that we will return to analyze, point by point, if they are fulfilled . I highlight three: - It cannot be the citizens - European or British - to pay the bill. In particular, both parties must have the interests and rights of European citizens living in the UK at the center of their concerns and vice versa. - The EU can never allow the UK to become a tax haven and the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion will be at the forefront of any trade agreement that is drawn up. - In all forms of cooperation that may exist between the EU and the UK, in areas that favor the interests of both parties - cooperation to which this Parliament and Europe at 27 remain open - the compass will be, as in any policy of the Union's external action, our values ​​and principles, namely with regard to respect for international obligations to protect refugees and migrants, and for human rights in general.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: in writing. - Since the referendum, we have been waiting for the British Government and Parliament to consider what to do with the outcome. We hoped, by some miracle, that they would still listen to common sense, and we waited for the United Kingdom to activate Article 50. Unfortunately, Theresa May launched the exit process with no controversy or threat, depriving not only the Union’s representatives but also the surviving British. It is now up to the EU institutions to determine the conditions that must prevail in the negotiations in order to protect the interests and citizens of the Union. Most importantly, the exit agreement must settle in a reassuring manner, respecting the principles of reciprocity and non-discrimination, the situation, rights and working conditions of European and British citizens living in the United Kingdom. The EU-UK financial clearance should cover the liabilities to the Union arising from the 2013-2020 budget, as well as the costs of exit. Future relations can only be established after the conclusion of an exit agreement, including agreements with Member States. Future relations can only be built on the Union's core values, taking into account EU principles and rules on human rights, fair economic and tax competition, the environment and climate change.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: written. - It is difficult to imagine a European science world without Britain. The country's universities and research institutes have given a huge amount to the EU and received many of the best researchers from the EU, as well as substantial sums of money: 7 billion in research and development money, more than their contribution. What happens at Brexit for student and researcher exchanges? Brexit is testing both the EU and Britain in particular in ways that voters could not even imagine. The scientific world remains in a difficult position, as are many other walks of life, and in Britain the magnificent side of the EU was noticed when it was too late. The entire scientific community is almost unanimous in its view that scientific cooperation should continue as before or even intensify. It is in no one’s interest for Brexit to destroy cooperation in the scientific world. The same is said in almost every aspect of society. I recently met with representatives of the British grid company National Grid, who spoke about co-operation in the electricity market, which benefits both parties through interconnectors. The UK is a net importer, connections increase security of supply. The same message from other fields: "Could we continue to work together in OUR field?" This is no wonder, because the whole of the EU is based on agreements that benefit all parties. Negotiations must be open. Both sides must remember the situation of the people, including workers' rights, and guarantee compliance with international agreements. Gaps in tax evasion should not be accepted but prevented. While there is a lot of uncertainty, one thing is certain: in order to compensate for the disadvantages of Britain's departure, the rest of the EU must cooperate better and more.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: signed up. - The situation of Britain's break-up of the EU was created by populist politicians who pushed Britain on a path that could lead it into a dangerous economic state and even into a United Kingdom. The European Union, in turn, had to deal with the question marks over image and credibility. The EU must now embark on a path to unity, communication and transparency, enhanced cooperation in the areas of current challenges: defense, security, migration, the economic and social situation. The European Parliament needs to set some clear priorities: ensuring citizens' rights and the budget. There are British citizens living in the EU and EU citizens living in the UK, including around 300,000 Romanians. There is a need to clarify the rights that they must maintain in the long term. With regard to the UK's desire to participate in security policy along with favorable trade conditions, I believe that there is no link between the two areas. The Agreement on Economic Relations must be concluded under the same conditions as those applied to any third country.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: In written form. - Although many politicians in the UK and around the world mistakenly believe that Brexit came with the referendum in June 2016 or with the activation of Article 50 of the EU Treaties in March 2017, it should be clear to everyone that Britain remains a full-fledged EU member until negotiations on its departure are completed. All obligations - legal and financial, remain in force until the official departure. As the agreement reached at the end of the negotiations needs to enter into force, the consent of the European Parliament is needed, the position we are adopting today must be reflected in the negotiations. First of all, for us, the European People's Party will always be the citizens. That is why we put at the heart of our position the guarantee of fair and equal treatment of EU citizens living in the UK, as well as British citizens residing in the EU. I want to emphasize that no one wants to punish Britain. On the contrary, we will all benefit from an effective agreement on our future relations and the participation of the British in the single market. But this can only happen with respect for the indivisibility of the four freedoms of the internal market - the freedom of movement of goods, capital, services and people.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - The British have officially launched the process of leaving the Union. The will of the British people must be respected, but the next period will be a period of terrible recognition. The nostalgia of the great power, the nationalist arrogance, did not save anyone from reality. Europe's share of the global economy will continue to decline in the coming years. Not because we will be smaller, but because the Chinese, the Indians, the Brazilians will be bigger. Therefore, in this respect, there are two types of EU Member States: smaller ones and those who do not yet know that they are small. Even the largest European member states are dwarfed by the populations of China and India. The rules of the game have changed, some notice this, others hide behind nationalism, trying to keep it a secret. We have to get used to it, because it doesn’t go separately anymore. Special travel is the past and cooperation is the future. Nationalist leaders are lying when they say that the EU is striving for our existence. If there is no EU, our days are numbered when our competitors are continental countries. The fate of European countries is connected, if we like it or not. There is only one way ahead, and that is deeper EU integration, which can compete with the rest of the world.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: written.- Brexit negotiations must be transparent and conducted in good faith on both sides.Britain cannot pick raisins from the EU bun.The free movement of citizens within the EU cannot be separated from the internal market.Britain also has to take care of its departure.Nor can Britain try to blackmail the EU in the negotiations by ending cooperation on common security.Only when the principles of British separation are sufficiently clear can the form of a future partnership between the EU and Britain be discussed.The Brexit process is complex and negotiations require restraint.Both sides need to work constructively and find the best solutions, as Britain will continue to be part of Europe and a close partner of the EU.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - After nine months of gestation, the British government finally decides to trigger Article 50, thus officially starting negotiations with the European Union. In the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, we particularly studied the issue of Brexit from the perspective of the free movement of people. No less than 700 EU legal acts touch on employment policy, social issues or the free movement of workers and all, without exception, will be affected by Brexit. In a number of cases, transitional measures will be essential to protect citizens. This divorce petition should also prompt us to revise the directive on the posting of workers as soon as possible, in order to find an appropriate solution for the Union of 27. Finally, the European Social Fund, as well as the European Fund. aid to the most deprived, and the employment and social innovation program are at risk of being affected by Brexit. It is essential that we ensure that the budget allocated to this is sufficient, despite the British departure. Brexit must be transformed into an opportunity to relaunch and improve the European project.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: written. - Irrespective of the final compromises in the negotiations, it is clear that Brexit will leave a big gap in the European Union's membership fees. In my opinion, this gap must be filled by transfers from other budget articles or by a steady reduction in all EU spending. In other words, membership fees should not be increased as a result of brexit. An increase in the EU payroll tax from 10% to 30% would also generate additional revenue accordingly. The task is not difficult, as the gap can be filled by reallocating budgets from projects for which there is no evidence of effectiveness. For example, there is no evidence of the success of the EFSI in improving growth and employment in the EU. The planned budget capacity can also be allocated to fill the budget gap. If no reallocation of budget articles can be agreed, I propose that the Commission's administration and other expenditure in particular be cut accordingly. While austerity policies are reducing the budgets of several Member States, it is only fair and reasonable to expect the Commission to be effective in its operations.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: in writing. - There are currently about 3 million EU citizens living in the United Kingdom, 170,000 of whom are from Lithuania. We only have 2 years to negotiate Brexit, and there are many issues: the UK's financial settlement, the EU's external borders, the relocation of agencies, future commercial and political relations. Protecting the rights of EU citizens working, living and studying in the UK should play an important role. Negotiations should not turn into a competition from which we will all come out losing. On the contrary, I would like to call on those responsible to keep the fate of those three million people in mind when negotiating, and thus reach an agreement that benefits all EU citizens. By showing that they care about the European Union and that we are here to regain the trust of EU citizens. What is clear is that when the EU leaves the EU, its people will no longer be able to enjoy the same rights or benefits as all other EU citizens.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing.- I believe that with this decision, we are in favor of a negotiating direction that preserves the EU's acquis, unity and values, guarantees the pursuit of common interests and the continuation of European construction, which will provide important political support to EU MEPs sitting at the negotiating table.But unfortunately, it is still a fact that with Brexit, everyone will ultimately lose.Therefore, in view of the public communication of the resolution, I consider it important to draw political lessons, at least in retrospect, from the irresponsibility of Cameron, who, for many years, anti-EU, populist incitement ultimately jeopardized his country's development.I do not really believe it, but I hope that this message will also serve as a serious warning to Orban and the other right-wing, nationalist, demagogic politicians who insist on his power.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: written. - I hate to see the UK leave the EU, but now that the process is underway, we need to move forward constructively. Today, the European Parliament sets its negotiating position for Brexit. For me, the interests of the citizens must be central in this. Nobody benefits from a hard Brexit: neither the UK, nor the EU. At the same time, Brexit for the EU-27 must be a joint choice for a social, sustainable and fair European Union. The EU-27 must unite around a sustainable and social future project. Brexit can thus lead to more unanimity about our common values. Of course we cannot be naive. The UK will try to get the best deal out of the fire. However, it must be clear from the start that there can be no cherry picking: you cannot want to keep all the benefits of membership and still leave the Union. We must be very clear that the Union will not accept the emergence of a fiscal paradise of eco-dumping and social dumping at our borders. In the Brexit negotiations, therefore, sufficient attention must be paid to respecting the climate agreement and compliance with social and fiscal standards.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: in writing. - The debate we are currently conducting is one of the most important in the history of the EP. For the first time, we are not establishing the rules of accession to the EU, but the conditions of withdrawal of one of the Member States from the EU. I would therefore like to highlight only one aspect of the exit. Great Britain, as a member of the European Union, annually contributed to its budget about EUR 17 billion, and received about EUR 6 billion. The remaining funds, i.e. over EUR 10 billion, were used every year to finance investments in many Member States, including Poland. Therefore, these countries planned their expenses based on funds provided by the EU budget, also from British contributions. In negotiations with the United Kingdom, it is therefore necessary to insist that it fully meets its financial obligations, as they were one of the important sources of EU funds allocated to other countries.
