Poland, like other Member States, must be sure that its investments will be financed by the EU budget. Therefore, I believe that the European Commission, negotiating on behalf of the 27 EU countries, should consistently settle the financial obligations between the United Kingdom and the European Union.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is voting time.(For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: We are now continuing the voting time.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, because this is a second reading we only have votes on the amendments. This deal has been a long time in the making: it has taken at least five years to get to this point, so I am pleased to have strong support across Parliament. This is about ensuring patients’ safety and encouraging innovation. It is sad for me that the Right of this House has chosen not to support something that improves patient safety and benefits patients right across the EU. Shame on you.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Rapporteur.- Perhaps just a brief clarification of the process of this vote.Normally on the early agreement we have no second reading vote at all.But now UKIP has submitted a rejection request, not even the EFDD as a whole.And I have to say that I am almost grateful, because today, when we were also discussing Brexit, that gives us another chance to show how united this House is against the ideas of UKIP.We are deciding on something that is for the internal market, that protects patients as best as possible across Europe.I would like to thank everyone who helped us to get to this point - the Council, the Commission, Glenis Willmott, of course, but especially the staff who worked well beyond the normal range to get us to this pointare.So: rejecting the amendment means supporting the result.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: - Mister President!I just wanted to say: Paragraph 37 (1) has been rejected.It is about general reimbursement and publication.Therefore I am of the opinion that Part 5 is no longer permissible here.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Rübig!I think the application is admissible.Paragraph 1 is accepted.So far we have accepted all four parts.(Heckling) Amendment No 1 by the Greens has been rejected, and so we have moved on to Amendment 9, Amendment 17 and then the original text.And then we've all accepted the first four parts, and now comes the fifth part.I will put that to the vote now.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The voting time is now closed.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Dear Colleagues!I would ask you to honor the time that we have now saved by voting quickly by leaving the room quickly if you do not want to hear the explanations of vote and, above all, by not standing in the corridors talking.I will take the liberty of asking individual colleagues by name to stop such discussions.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have been talking in these rooms for months about the likely harmful effects of the United Kingdom's exit from the European Union. We have been talking about the Brexit problem for months, as if there was a real need to discuss the democratic result of a democratic referendum. The people of England voted and decided. The vote must be respected. This need not be in question. Now negotiations are opening: on the one hand there is the UK government, which will serve the interests of British citizens, on the other hand there is the European Union, which I am not sure will do the interests of European citizens - those European citizens who have lived and worked in the United Kingdom for years: their rights must be protected and must not be questioned through responsible discussion. The UK will have to honor the commitments it has made until the end of the effective exit path from the Union, because the commitments made must be honored. We have come to this point, however, because serious mistakes have been made. Those who committed them must apologize and present a black book of the past, not the white and empty one of an uncertain future. Everyone plays the part of him. We call for a fair and just negotiation, and above all not punitive towards the British people. The 5 Star Movement will not be complicit in political choices aimed at punishing one in order to educate a hundred. And if we talk about the mafia in the halls of the European Parliament, we must not be scandalized like bourgeois at an exclusive party. The mafia exists, not only in Italy. The mafia is not Europe, the mafia is not Italy, the mafia is silence and censorship, as well as crime. The mafia is an attitude of threat and silence.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Mr President, what was being asked of the European Parliament today was height of view in the face of the United Kingdom's decision to leave the European Union and a clear position on the recognition of acquired social rights, residence, mobility and social security. for Britons residing in the European Union and Europeans living in the UK. But we have fallen into a confrontation that will strengthen British nationalism. A car targeted by the Government of Spain, for whom the sovereignty of Gibraltar is more important than the rights of the 12,000 workers who cross the fence every day. Let's not get lost in abstract discourses that hide, under the cloak of nationalism or a hollow Europeanism, the neoliberalism shared by the European Union and the United Kingdom. For us, future relations with the United Kingdom must be based on solidarity and mutual recognition of fundamental rights, because there is another Europe, that of the European Social Charter, that of the European Convention on Human Rights, of which we will all continue to form part.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: - Today we have made an important, but not necessarily gratifying, decision. I did not join those who applauded this decision with applause. For me, this is more of a sad decision, but although we have decided, or rather our British colleagues, voted in the referendum, we need to make the appropriate decisions. Yes, the negotiations on Britain's withdrawal must be pragmatic, and I hope that the European Union will negotiate as a pragmatic partner, but with regard to an agreement on future cooperation when we have to become future partners, I hope the European Union's negotiators will be visionary to offer solutions that will enable the European Union and Britain to remain partners, close partners, and not really build new borders in Europe. The Berlin Wall has been torn down by Europeans, and I think we need to learn from this and history so that we do not create new borders in Europe.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - A week ago was a sad day for Europe. Sad because one Member State has officially announced that it is leaving the largest organization - the guarantor of stability and prosperity in Europe. This decision will have consequences for millions of Europeans, both for the several million British citizens residing in the European Union and for all Union citizens living in the United Kingdom. Rubicon is crossed! From 2019, the Union will have 27 Member States, but this does not mean that the rights of European and British citizens must disappear from today to tomorrow. Many people and some politicians are trying to use the migration card as an element of uncertainty and a bargaining chip. This is irresponsible and frivolous. For decades, all these European citizens, including Bulgarians, have contributed to the development and prosperity of the British economy and society. I call on the British Government not to create insecurity for the millions of European citizens, including my fellow citizens, by using or even tolerating rhetoric that increases people's fear of their social rights.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I would like to say that I supported the resolution on Brexit, but I have some reservations about some parts of this text.In some respects, I find the text too harsh.If our aim is to agree on good cooperation in the future and on trade agreements, then I feel that, for example, point six, which clearly states that the United Kingdom cannot negotiate trade agreements with third countries until the end of its membership of the European Union, thatfirstly, the United Kingdom will not have to comply with such provisions and, secondly, that they are too harsh.Forbidding anyone from negotiating something when the agreement is not yet in force seems to me to be really a little over the limit.However, I welcome the fact that the resolution was adopted today, that it gives the European Parliament a clear position on the future Brexit process, which is why I ultimately voted in favor of the whole resolution.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, the Union's negotiations with the United Kingdom for Brexit must be done without hatred, without revenge and with the people in mind, first and foremost in the Union and the United Kingdom. For them, we must negotiate for free trade, for freedom of movement, for their rights and not forget that we want to be together, partners, as countries and as people. Over two hundred thousand Romanians are now in Great Britain. They work in all fields, in highly qualified positions, they are bankers, teachers, doctors, researchers and so on. There are also Romanians where there is a shortage of labor, in hospitals, nursing homes, construction, agriculture. There are also many young Romanians studying at universities in Great Britain. The British Minister in charge of the Brexit negotiations, Mr. David Jones, told us yesterday that he wants to keep the Romanians in Great Britain. Of course, the UK also wants to keep its European citizens in the European Union.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 25 June and 29 March are two sadly historic dates which marked a step back in British history and a setback for the European Union. Now, after the referendum and the notification of the activation of Article 50, therefore, let Brexit be. Without delay, I would say. Because after the decision of the people of the United Kingdom, as legitimate as it is absurd, it is the European Union that cannot afford insecurity and uncertainty. I believe that the priority now is to think about stability and safeguarding the interests of the Union. I believe that the UK exit negotiations must clearly demonstrate that the Union is stronger, and that the UK alone will achieve little. I am convinced that the rights of European citizens should not be questioned, and I am convinced that this is an opportunity to demonstrate to populists, sovereigns and nationalists from all over Europe that their propaganda is empty and sterile, without a political project. . I am among those who dream that, albeit with difficulty, the United Kingdom will one day go back for its future and that of Europe.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Mr President, we welcome the position of the European Parliament ahead of the Brexit negotiations, that it is unambiguous in relation to Ireland. It recognises that the people in the North voted to remain and it commits that the Good Friday Agreement must be preserved in all its parts. Crucially, the Parliament position calls on negotiators to do everything to avoid any hardening of the border. Written as it was by Groups with whom we have fundamental disagreements regarding the current and future direction of the EU, we in Sinn Féin consider this report to be a successful vindication of the dialogue with which we and other Irish MEPs have been engaged in since last summer.  Parliament’s position is even more positive when compared to the draft of the Council. Despite assurances from the Fine Gael Government, the Council draft is weak, non-specific, and simply not up to the standards that the Irish people, North and South, require. My appeal to this House, and to the other European institutions, today is: please do not allow the people of Ireland to suffer the consequence of our own government’s incompetence.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: - Mr President, I would never have liked to be able to vote today on a proposal to negotiate Britain's exit from the European Union. On the other hand, however, the will of the peoples must be respected in this room. Mr President, even if it leaves the European Union in two years' time, the United Kingdom remains a European country, and in these circumstances the social rights of European citizens, members of the Union, and British citizens, members of Europe, must be respected. The United Kingdom and the European Union must remain part of a European social model, respecting social rights. There are a lot of Romanians in Great Britain, just as there are a lot of British people in the European Union. The European Social Charter, the European Convention on Human Rights, obliges us. In other news, Mr President, I believe that negotiations with third countries should be banned. We need cohesion in the European Union and the Union must not make this exit from Great Britain a precedent.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, a divorce is always a defeat, a difficult situation for both sides. Contrary to the false promises of the Brexiteers’ propaganda, leaving the EU will involve difficult decisions and entail possibly unexpected, and often harmful, consequences. It is clear that the four freedoms of the single market are indivisible. This is a red line for us. We will not allow a future relationship that damages the integrity of the single market or lowers European legal, social, environmental and health standards. We want, at the same time, to ensure an orderly Brexit. We want the negotiations to be fair and in the interests of European and UK citizens, the future relationship with the UK to be balanced and comprehensive, and for the United Kingdom to remain a close political, economic and strategic partner of the European Union.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Mr President, although we had reservations on one or two points in this resolution, Labour MEPs voted in favour of this resolution, which provides more clarity and realism on the issues facing us than does the position of the British Government. The British Government still has not said what it wants on many of the key issues that will be coming up in this mother of all divorce cases, but it has said that it wants exactly the same benefits as Britain currently has as a member of the single market. Well, we will hold them to account on that, but it does seem, generally, that the British Government is intent on testing to destruction the theory that you can have your cake and eat it. When it becomes clear that that is not possible, then there will be a question as to what happens next. What should Britain do if the outcome of this Brexit process is damaging, costly and dangerous to Britain? That is why I am glad that this resolution confirms that it is possible for Article 50 notifications to be withdrawn and revoked. We may need it.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the already extreme words spoken by the English Minister of Defense Michael Fallon make us understand the role of great responsibility that the European Union will have to play during the negotiations, which it will have to deal with, also concerned with the fate of the United Kingdom. With his choice, the United Kingdom takes a leap into the unknown, out of any long-term political project, but geographically it remains there, close to France and the Benelux, and history teaches us that generating frustration in neighboring countries always leads to dire consequences. We have to leave a door open for when the UK realizes the mistake and has to go back, but we have to pay attention to the messages that will be sent out, so that we don't have to confuse an act of responsibility with a test of weakness. The issues on the table are many, and will affect both financial obligations and individual rights. To the European negotiators, my best wishes for a good job. I am sure that Brexit will be an opportunity to relaunch the European dream with greater force.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I find it very valuable that 516 Members voted in favor of the joint resolution because it is a signal.The European Union must be united, only then will we achieve a good result for the future relationship with the United Kingdom.For both parties, this divorce decision is a loss and I will miss British MEPs.It is our duty to minimize these losses.Theresa May refused to participate in the common market and the customs union.It therefore rejected the four fundamental freedoms for its citizens.We must respect her proposal, but it means finding a new framework that will allow fair conditions for our citizens and for mutually beneficial cooperation.I believe in good cooperation with Great Britain and I believe in the common action of the European Union and also in the self-reflection that we must do.

name: Clare MOODY
text: – Mr President, today is the day when even Theresa May has started to acknowledge the reality of where we are. The empty nationalistic rhetoric and flag—waving that characterised the debate last year, and again in the last week, has always resulted in damaging our interests. It angers me that people wrap themselves in the British and Gibraltarian flags when they had actively worked against the interests of citizens of both places. We are about to enter detailed negotiations with our friends about the future of our country. It is time to settle down to serious politics, recognising through the process that we have lost some of our sovereignty, and focus on ensuring that eventually we will reach a deal that works for the citizens of the UK and Gibraltar, as well as our European colleagues.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: - Mr President, the Rock does not belong to the United Kingdom or Spain, but to Gibraltarians, and the people of Gibraltar have determined that their future must continue with the United Kingdom: in a referendum, in 2002, they voted to remainBritish.The result was 99%.There is nothing more to discuss.El Peñón remains with the United Kingdom, just as Ceuta and Melilla remain with Spain.The inclusion of Gibraltar in the Brexit negotiating guidance is a threat without reason.The European Union talks a lot about democracy, but these words are worthless.

name: Peter JAHR
text: - Mister President! I very much regret Britain's departure from the European Union, and I think that is not a good story for the European Union either, and it is not a good story for Great Britain either. Second: Of course, we guarantee each other a fair right-wing democratic process. One could say: Both have now also become adult institutions. Thirdly, I would like to emphasize that the European Union is a serious matter and not an intellectual literary circus. There you have rights and there you have duties. First of all, this means that as long as Great Britain remains a member of the European Union - even in the period of divorce - you will of course have all rights, but also have to fulfill all of the European Union's obligations. But that also means that if Great Britain leaves, then they no longer have any obligations, but also no rights. And fourthly: I am delighted with the resolutions that have been adopted by a large majority today, because that gives us the strength to conduct this procedure in the interests of both parties.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - President!I expected the European Parliament's decision on Brexit to prepare for a frictionless, peaceful separation and at the same time outline the possibility of further close cooperation - that is not what happened.It also sets conditions for the UK after 2020, which is why the majority of the population has just decided to leave.He also questions his sovereignty, refusing to initiate negotiations at all in the run-up to the exit.Speakers believe it is in the interests of the EU-27.No, because it would also be in the interest of the Member States to work more closely together.I trust that the Council and the Commission will not follow this path, because it is nothing more than revenge on the British and a deterrent to those Member States that may think of leaving later.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - President! The European Union does not seem to have learned much from Brexit. They did not look at the underlying reasons, they did not look at whether you, as an extremist, a nationalist, a primitive, I do not know why the English majority, branded as such, wanted to leave the Union. They did not look deep into the fact that one of the main reasons was the rejection of migration, and within that, migration within the Union - which should also be remedied in its causes and roots. It should be examined what is the reason for this and how it could be changed that people in the former socialist countries of Central and Eastern Europe are looking for a fraction more than in Western countries and therefore catch themselves and leave, for example, from Hungary to England. Now, an initiative has finally been launched from Hungary with the participation of several Central and Eastern European countries to eliminate these brutal income and wage differences. Please listen and support!

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr Chairman!Brexit is a bad moment in the history of the European Union, but this parting should respect both sides, especially the interests of the citizens of the Member States and the European Union.We are all Europeans, regardless of whether we live on the continent or in the UK.Today, therefore, we should define the most important priorities of this process.In my opinion, the most important priority is security, including the fight against nationalisms.We will all deal with the bad effects of Brexit better or worse - I am convinced that these will be bad consequences - individual people will do well, entrepreneurs will do well, financial markets will do well, everyone will manage somehow.However, we will not deal with conflicts, we will not deal with disputes, we will not deal with racism, we will not deal with xenophobia, we will not be able to deal with nationalism, and we will not be able to deal with war.

name: Vicky FORD
text: – Mr President, the two—year negotiations for leaving the EU have now started, and I was appalled by the name—calling and jeering in this Chamber earlier from UKIP colleagues. It does not represent the views of the vast majority of the British people or the views of colleagues across this Chamber. Real people’s lives, jobs and future are at stake, and we need amicable solutions. There is a huge amount of work to be done on our future relationship. I do think this resolution could have done a lot more on that future relationship and set the tone on some of the detailed discussions that we need to go ahead. It is time to roll up our sleeves, colleagues, and help to find those solutions. I am ready to work with anyone across Europe who wants to achieve amicable negotiations and that long-term partnership.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - The United Kingdom decided to leave the European Union on 29 June last year. Mrs Theresa May sent a letter on 29 March announcing her tough departure from the European Union, a tough Brexit. We can regret things, but we must certainly respect them as facts that will employ the European Parliament and also parliamentarians in the coming months, years. The European Union must be united. We must put the interests of the citizens of both the European Union and the citizens of the United Kingdom first and create a separation that will ensure decent coexistence in the future. It is also time to reflect on the future of the European Union. There is certainly a lot to be done in the European Union to improve the functioning of the European Union itself. Perhaps the right answer, even with Brexit, is to intensify talks on the enlargement of the European Union to the countries of the Western Balkans. These countries want to join the European Union because they want to live in peace, freedom and good for their people. Maybe that's the right answer.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, the British problem – or obviously from a UK perspective, the European problem – is very simply stated. Britain wanted to be part of a common market, not a common government. Guy Verhofstadt expressed some of the reasons very well in his speech this morning: the fundamental difference between a bottom-up common law system and the Napoleonic system on the continent. It is not an argument that applies everywhere, but our economic cycle has always been Atlantic rather than European; our outlook has always been maritime rather than continental. In the talks at the beginning of last year, David Cameron tried to get a looser a deal from the inside. The other Member States decided that that was not a concession they were prepared to make, which is absolutely fine. We are therefore going to seek it from the outside. What should be the framework of that deal? I think a good model is Canada’s relations with the United States. Canada has, on its doorstep, a political union; it is not part of that union, but it enjoys the closest military security, economic and commercial links with that union compatible with being a sovereign state. You will lose a bad tenant, and you will gain a good neighbour.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Mr Chairman! Brexit will certainly be a difficult experience for both the Union and the United Kingdom. During the negotiations, both sides will work out the most favorable solutions for the parties. However, the most important thing in this process is that we remember first of all about European citizens in Great Britain and British citizens living in European Union countries, for whom Brexit will have a direct impact on their family and professional life. Millions of citizens today live in great uncertainty. They do not know whether they will still be able to use the employment rights they have acquired over the years, whether they will still be able to work and live in Great Britain or - as in the case of British citizens - in 27 countries of the European Union. The duty and priority during the negotiations should be to minimize the negative effects of Brexit on citizens. Both parties must ensure that acquired rights are preserved and that they enable freedom of movement, work and services on a reciprocal basis. The resolution made it clear that access to the single market could not be allowed without respecting the treaty freedoms enjoyed by EU citizens today. That is why today I voted with full conviction in favor of the resolution on the Brexit negotiations.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr Chairman!In Great Britain, the public can send signals to the government through the by-elections, in Germany through national elections, and in the European Union, we only have referenda.Referendums that are in fact a touchstone of the mood not only in a given country, but throughout Europe.It is time to acknowledge that Brexit was a representative response to the dissatisfaction of millions of Europeans with the policies that the European Union leadership is pursuing today.Today, in this Chamber, we adopted a resolution announcing the legalization of illegal immigration.You can charm reality, you can perform spells over it, talk about nationalisms, populisms, but you will not be charmed by the basic fact: nations make up Europe.If we do not respect nations, there will be no Europe.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, it is happening. The United Kingdom are packing their bags and they are leaving the European Union. When David Cameron attempted to get what he called a better deal for Britain, he was told that the four freedoms were sacrosanct: they could not be changed. And predictably, when he went back to the people of the United Kingdom he ended up losing, and he ended up losing because he went back with nothing because he was told that the four freedoms were sacrosanct. Yet, at the moment, we are now embarking on another process. A white paper where we look at the future of Europe, where two options could potentially have satisfied the United Kingdom’s grievances. Option two is nothing but the single market, so we could potentially have a situation next December where we have decided to restrict freedom of movement whilst still negotiating with Great Britain on the basis that market access cannot happen without freedom of movement of people. Someone please explain this contradiction.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhí díospóireacht againn i rith na maidine ar an mBreatimeacht agus den chuid is mó bhí sé cothrom, féaráilte agus ciallmhar. Bhí áthas orm agus cuirim mo bhuíochas in iúl do na feisirí a rinne tagairt d’Éirinn – Comhaontú Aoine an Chéasta agus cás na teorann.  Anois, tar éis na díospóireachta, tá cinneadh déanta ag an bParlaimint, agus le móramh mór glacadh leis an rún a bhí os ár gcomhair: 516 i bhfabhar agus 133 i gcoinne. Ba é an móramh céanna é don chuid is mó do na leasuithe. Dá bhrí sin tá an Pharlaimint aontaithe, agus is féidir linn dul ar aghaidh anois agus idirbheartaíocht a thosú idir an Ríocht Aontaithe agus an tAontas agus teacht ar chomhréiteach a oibreoidh don Ríocht Aontaithe agus don Aontas amach anseo.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, I voted against Parliament’s draft resolution on Brexit this afternoon. From the outset, I do welcome the fact that the text recognises Northern Ireland’s unique position in respect of our land border with the Republic of Ireland. This builds on existing commitments by both the UK and Irish governments, and indeed the European Council, to give these challenges priority and adopt a flexible and imaginative approach.  However, I cannot neglect the fact that this resolution would severely limit what can be achieved in the talks ahead. It would prevent the UK from opening trade talks with non—EU countries before 2019. It would take future trade relations with the EU off the table for the next two years, and it would tie the UK into paying an endless and excessive divorce bill well after it leaves.  These are restrictions that would affect taxpayers in Northern Ireland very directly. They would also prevent local firms from accessing new markets and from exporting goods and services in the short to medium term. So while the text is cognisant of the needs of Northern Ireland, the resolution is not conducive.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, almost a year since the UK referendum, a period in which the EU was only a bystander to the phony war on Brexit, the start of the exit negotiations themselves comes as a sort of relief. The start of open, honest and transparent discussions between the two partners was long overdue. Euphemisms used for a radical departure, be it a ‘clean exit’ or ‘a new partnership with Europe’ might have made possible until now to mask for many the hard choices and trade-offs of the negotiations to come. But now the time is slowly coming for the cake proverb to be put to the test, the lies written on buses to be exposed, and promises of libertarian utopias to have their first contact with reality. But the need to come to terms with what an idealistic notion of undiluted ‘control’ in a vastly interconnected world really means, as opposed to true influence and significance, is not limited to Britain, but applies to the EU too.

name: Nathan GILL
text: – Mr President, I represent Wales, which is a nation in the United Kingdom which voted to leave the EU. A week ago today, the Prime Minister triggered Article 50, formally beginning the UK-EU Brexit negotiation process. It was an historic day. After legal challenges, lengthy delays and threats, we will be leaving the EU, and become an independent, self-governing and democratic country once again. This Parliament is calling for unreasonable demands, some of which are going to be impossible to meet. The Commission is meeting a GBP 52 million divorce bill. Can I just ask this: do you actually want a Brexit deal? The people of Wales and Britain voted to leave the EU, not Europe. We still want to be your friends and trading partners, but if you are not going to make us any sensible offers, we will take our business elsewhere. The EU only represents 15% of the global economy. A new, global Britain is going to see us become more forward-facing.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, this morning was important with a really strong resolution and a good debate. For me and for the people I represent, which is a border constituency in Ireland with Northern Ireland, paragraph 20 is important. It talks about the unique position and special circumstances on the island of Ireland and says it must be addressed in a withdrawal agreement. It very specifically says that we must do everything possible to avoid a hardening of the border. I drive through Northern Ireland to visit my constituents in Donegal. I see no difference in our territories except that there are kilometres where I am from and there are miles in Northern Ireland. I want that difference to be the only one that exists after Brexit, but – let us be frank and honest – there is a lot of work to do to live up to the words that we have voted through and there is a political responsibility on the British Prime Minister and her Government to deliver more on this commitment. We did not vote for Brexit, but we have to live with the consequences of it.

name: Seb DANCE
text: – Mr President, I want to pick that point up actually because of course the economies of Northern Ireland and the Republic are inextricably linked, as of course is the peace process that was painstakingly negotiated over many, many years. There was a UKIP amendment that tried to remove the competency of the European Union in relation to the border issue. It said that the Common Travel Area is not dependent on EU membership, and I was surprised to see that the Tories supported it as well. Yes, the Common Travel Area predates the European Union, but it was drawn up at a time when the immigration policies of the Republic of Ireland and the United Kingdom were the same, and indeed the customs policies were broadly similar. It is the policy of the British Government now, apparently, to tear those two regimes asunder. That does make the Common Travel Area an issue to do with Brexit as has been explained. It was not voted for by the people of Northern Ireland and it is an issue that the British Government has to face up to its responsibilities on. It is not enough to simply wish this issue away. We need real political leadership and we need this to be addressed.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: - Mr. President, if we talk about medical devices, we have to talk about Essure. Essure is marketed as a permanent, non-surgical birth control system. The multinational Bayer has sold this device to one million women. Since it was approved in 2002, negative effects have been reported in women around the world: heavy bleeding, pelvic pain, immune system disorders and, the last straw for a contraceptive, a high rate of unintended pregnancy. The intervention to remove the device ends, in many cases, in a hysterectomy. Essure has had dire consequences for thousands of women. Such a contraceptive method should never have been allowed to be marketed and its sale should be banned immediately. I therefore welcome that the Spanish National Court has admitted a demand from the Association of People Affected by Essure: finally, the bodies responsible for controlling a device like this will be investigated. Something like this cannot happen again, at least in Europe. We failed women and now we must regain their confidence.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, today, having seemingly learned from the hip replacement and breast implant scandals, the medical devices regulations have been updated. This should be welcomed. Introduced are a concentration limit for 1B carcinogenic, mutagenic and repro—toxic substances (CMRs), and also for endocrine disrupting chemicals (EDCs) in devices that include a benefit risk assessment of their presence as they are CMRs or EDCs – lots of jargon there. Such assessments would have to be updated within five years. I only wish it could have been more speedy than that. However, all changes to medical devices that increase patient safety and patient choice, without reducing their clinical effectiveness, are to be welcomed. I am 100% sure that in the post—Brexit United Kingdom these standards will be maintained in cooperation with our European Union Member State counterparts.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favor of this regulation because it constitutes an important step forward for the health and safety of citizens.Indeed, the new European rules on medical devices will have a double positive effect: they will guarantee the safety of these important tools and at the same time give patients the opportunity to benefit promptly from innovative solutions in the field of healthcare.Particularly important, then, is the introduction of the responsibility of those who make them.Likewise, quality and performance follow-up will allow manufacturers to intervene quickly if problems arise and will help them to constantly improve their devices.The health of citizens, access to more advanced technologies that improve treatments and alleviate suffering are primary objectives of the European Union.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - President!I mean, we Hungarians no longer want to be the assembly plant of Western countries with poorly paid wage workers.Allow me to describe a few headlines: The Hungarian invention recognizes heart problems, The most modern urine analyzer system presented at the University of Szeged, Sensational Hungarian invention for the delight of allergy sufferers, Well-known American universities are interested in a Hungarian medical invention, namely the anatomical simulatorbreakthrough, intelligent oncology surgical knife: the way of a Hungarian invention.Please, research, development, innovation and the production and marketing of these dazzling innovations as a Hungarian product: this is the Hungarian way, if you do not want to constantly burden your countries with internal migration, then help us and we Hungarianslet us also believe in ourselves that we are suitable for this!

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I would like to say that human health should always be one of the priorities in our assessment, and I am really happy to support it with regard to the compromise proposal that has been put forward.They have been negotiating for five years, and that limit of acceptance, I think, has been met for the plenary, for most and for me.I therefore rejected the motion for a resolution rejecting the compromise reached.I am motivated for several reasons.Firstly, there will undoubtedly be an improvement in patient safety, an improvement in the quality of health services and, of course, an improvement in the means used, which has already been discussed here.At the same time, I think that this report, or this recommendation, will further motivate companies to innovate, to be more efficient within the already set system.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, I have worked on this dossier for almost five years with other colleagues, so it is a good day that we have approved tougher and better legislation on medical devices because public health is our primary concern here and that is vital. But so, too, is the medical devices industry: it is a vital part of our economy and it produces products that sustain lives, quality of life improves and our lives are extended by it. So good work has been done across the House. The next step is implementation, and here the Commission and Member States and we ourselves must keep a watch so that what is in the legislation is put into effect. There are two core issues, but I will deal with one in particular and that is post-market surveillance of products. Many of the problems with faulty devices were made worse because there was not adequate post-market surveillance. In other words, there was no reporting system and the problems were not identified. This legislation changes that and let’s make sure it is fully implemented.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I supported the proposal for a regulation on in vitro medical devices. The intention means easier identification and traceability of the medical devices used and is correct and is of course also in the interest of patients. The regulation should achieve greater safety of medical devices, rigorous control before they are placed on the market and after they are already on the market. However, I would like to draw attention to two problem points. One concerns the possibility of renewing single-use medical devices, the so-called reprocessing contained in Article Seventeen. The second point is the electronic system of registrations and its interconnection with national registries. I would rather prefer the possibility of keeping registration at national level with the transfer of validated data to a central European database, but the regulation as such means greater safety for patients. That's why I supported him.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, we voted today for on an important regulation that will finally, four years after the initial proposal, regulate a big portion of the so-called shadow banking system, money market funds. I strongly supported the report, as these money market funds are important in providing financing to financial institutions, corporations and governments. Because of the financial crisis in Europe, these funds confronted problems of liquidity and stability. That is why a debate started on how to make them more shock-resistant. I definitely support the European Commission proposal for new rules on money market funds aiming to improve the ability of these funds to, where possible, reduce pressure on them by boosting their liquidity profile, and increase their stability by means of the five initiatives mentioned in the report.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I supported this report because money market funds provide short-term funding to financial institutions, businesses, but also governments, and thus actually contribute to the functioning of the money market.Past years in the financial crisis have shown how vulnerable these funds are to risk.It is important that it is in this context and with this experience that we establish some uniform prudential requirements that will apply to the operation of these funds in the money market in the European Union, while fully taking into account the need to balance the safety and soundness of money market funds with the effective functioning ofin these markets.This cannot be achieved satisfactorily at national level, but it was important that we take this initiative, which is why I supported it.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I supported the European Parliament's recommendation on the proposal for a regulation adjusting the multiannual financial framework for the years 2014-2020.The revision of the multiannual financial framework is moving in the right direction, especially in terms of increasing competitiveness funding by EUR 1.4 billion while not raising the overall ceilings.I support the principle in the form of reallocation, we will give priority to those programs that draw on and function effectively and contribute to strengthening growth and job creation in all member states.Under the proposed promotion, for example, the Erasmus + program will receive an additional EUR 100 million and the Horizon 2020 science and research program EUR 200 million.I believe that the funds thus newly earmarked for asylum and migration policy should be primarily intended to finance the European Border and Coast Guard and Europol.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, the first years of implementation of the multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020 have been major challenges for the Union, security, humanitarian affairs, and they have called for rapid and comprehensive budgetary flexibility measures, precisely to respond to these crises.Emergency aid reserves were also activated and the financial flexibility instrument was used.I understand the urgency of certain budget measures, but I have some questions: Do we have a clear budget planning for 2018-2020?We do not have.And Brexit will have a major impact on this clarity or ambiguity regarding the 2018-2020 budget.Further: how did the Commission ensure that we have transparent payments?Is it ensured that all expenses are systematically reported, that they are transparent, that we spend only what is strictly necessary, because it is the citizens' money?

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, thank you for the excellent management of this meeting.I did not hesitate to support this recommendation and I am very pleased that we were able to approve it in this form today, after a long blockade by the Council.Indeed, the outdated multiannual financial framework needs to be adjusted as soon as possible so that we can address the challenges facing the European Union now.I am thinking in particular of the migration crisis, but there are other problems as well.However, I emphasize that these new means must be used properly.Only the efficient and meaningful use of this money will lead to a greater European Union's ability to act, and the common willingness of all of us to make the most of the resources for concrete action is key to the future of European integration.I consider it beneficial to strengthen flexibility, which will enable the European Union to respond to unexpected challenges much better than before.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I think this report is going in the right direction. I wanted to support the revision of the multiannual financial framework, and I also supported it. There are a number of new priorities brought by the crisis, be it security in Europe, of course the issue of the migration crisis and the importance of fundamental security of the European Union's borders. In my speech, however, I would like to support, in particular, that these priorities do not further weaken the funding of cohesion policy from the relevant European funds, because this policy is currently serving the cohesion of the European Union, eliminating regional disparities and it would be very unfortunate if this chapter of financing in terms of European support. I think that our main task for the future is not only mine, but I think that all those who want to speak out in favor of this cohesion policy should not be weakened in the next new programming period as well.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favor of the resolution on the amendment of the multiannual budget because this review does indeed contain positive aspects, but it must be emphasized, and needless to deny, that we would have expected much, much more. At such a delicate moment, the European Union certainly needed more courage. If the point of changing the EU budget is to adapt it to new challenges, I do not think the proposed corrections are up to par. We proceed in small steps. Therefore, the effort to indicate as a priority measures in favor of youth employment is certainly welcome; 1.2 billion more for young people is a positive figure. That is why I voted in favor: because it is clearly stated that these funds should be increased in the event that unemployment surveys do not change or new emergencies and needs arise. A rigid budget is a sign of myopia. The future of the European Union and of Europe itself is uncertain. So the watchword can only be flexibility, but we need to improve.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Dear Members! I may be a masochist, but I tend to think very, very much about the victims of terrorist acts: victims in London, Paris, Brussels, Berlin, like a mother who tried to go to kindergarten on Westminster Bridge for her two young children and never got there. I thank the good god that we are in a situation in Hungary where a radicalized Muslim mass could not have been created within our borders. I thank the good God that we have chosen wisely not to give in to any pressure and not to allow mass migration. He who denies that there is a connection between these brutal acts of terrorism and even a system of multi-generational migration habits is lying. It would be better for Western countries to brainstorm what they have spoiled and how to improve the situation of their citizens than to do something to force us to do what ... (the President withdrew from the Member)

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, unfortunately I could not support this report, although my colleague Díaz de Mera García Consuegra has made a great deal of effort in drafting it, because there are a number of issues throughout the report. Firstly, it is extending the definition of a refugee to persons who have had to migrate because of poverty, climate change and natural disasters. It is thus difficult to determine to whom to grant asylum and who to send back to the country of origin. In addition, it can be another motivation for people to simply go to Europe for a better life. The second point is the aforementioned unconditionality of European Union development aid. If we are to provide development aid, we must be sure. The certainty that our help will be handled responsibly and will not be misused. In addition to these two things, I find other problematic points in the report, such as granting special status to those who have been displaced because of climate change. Therefore, I think that this report should be re-discussed and re-evaluated.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, EU external policy should be honest. If you want to get the result we need clear understanding on what the European Union wants. How can we see the situation when EU actions contradict the EU declarations? The official EU position is that we should help people who need protection, according to the Geneva Convention. But on the other hand, the European Commission and EU Member States make deals with President Erdoğan, African strongmen and Libyan warlords. The main aim of this deal is to prevent not only illegal economic migration, but also a real refugee movement to the European Union. The aid for poor African states becomes more and more connected with the prevention of migration. If EU countries prefer to adopt Trump’s approach we should say this openly and not pretend to be angels that do not understand why these poor people do not come to us. If we adhere to formally declared principles we should show now real solidarity on the issue of development aid and refugee policy. I voted in favour.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: This concludes the explanations of vote.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the discussion on hate speech, populism and fake news on social media - Towards an EU response (2017/2644 (RSP)).Many Members have asked to be allowed to intervene with the procedures that are generally included in our discussions (the "catch-the-eye" and the "blue card" questions), but I would like to remind you that, unfortunately, these procedures will not be accepted on this occasion.You know that there has been a change in the rules, on a proposal from the political groups, and these procedures are not foreseen for this debate.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: - Mr President, thank you for giving me the floor on this point of order.I have not studied the question you just raised, but I am a little surprised.There has been a recent revision of the rules and, if I understood correctly, you are now telling us that there is a new revision of the rules which was adopted at the request of the chairmen of the political groups.However, the rules of the assembly do not depend on the consent of the political groups.If the rules of the assembly contain a new provision, the latter can only be adopted once it has been voted on by the plenary assembly itself, including by deputies who, like me, do notbelong to no political group.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Mr Gollnisch, as you know, the political groups have decided to put the debate we are now starting on the agenda and have introduced the new regulation into this debate, which as you know has entered into force and which we must respect.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: representing the S&D Group. – Mr President, I am very pleased that we are having this debate today. The issues of hate speech, populism and fake news on social media are relevant given the rise in extremism, populism, xenophobia, sexism and other forms of discrimination and intolerance. Here are some of the most popular fake news titles which were making the headlines in the 2016: ‘1 000 Muslims screaming “Allahu akbar” set fire to Germany’s oldest church on New Year’s Eve’, ‘Pope Francis shocks world, endorses Donald Trump for President’, and ‘ISIS leader calls for American Muslim voters to support Hillary Clinton’.  Fake news is not a new phenomenon. It is as old as the press itself. However, it gained momentum and global visibility during the US elections, the UK referendum and even during the recent elections in the Netherlands. What is especially worrying is the accelerated spread on social media. Today around half of European citizens follow news on Facebook and other social media and six out of ten news items shared are passed on without being read first. The majority of people, mostly young, have difficulty in identifying fake news. We have already called in this Chamber in the past for a European solution to fake news. Today I call again on the Commission to urge social media firms to boost their efforts to counter fake news. We need some kind of clarification from the EU on the self-regulatory measures in the sector. We have to strengthen efforts in working towards the establishment of online platforms so that fake news or illegal content is completely eliminated and to impose fines on those who fail to do so. We have to better support fact—checking websites. This is why I also call on the Commission to analyse in depth the current situation and legal framework with regard to fake news and to explore the possibility of legislative intervention to limit the dissemination and spreading of fake content. Next education: for children to be taught in schools how to spot fake news and the inclusion of media literacy in education as we have to actively engage with our youngest citizens. I am convinced that part of the solution is also to strive for better quality in journalism and the media. To achieve this we need to encourage quality journalism online and to extend ethical journalistic standards to all media actors. We need more investigative journalists, professional and courageous media outlets and more transparency in media ownership.  It is also of key importance to address the particularities of hate speech online. The Code of Conduct published by the Commission is a step in the right direction. We also need more financial means to fund research on social media algorithms that create filter bubbles and prevent the viral spread of fake news. Finally, why not launch the European Union’s own broadcasting channel to counter the lies and draw Europe together and defend democracy, not as an EU propaganda system, but as a major European media platform in its own right? This idea is currently being floated in Germany and France. My group, the Socialists and Democrats, are committed to being in the forefront of this important fight. We owe this to our citizens. If we do not win this battle, fake news and propaganda will, together with its main goals: provoking fear leading to apathy, chaos or completely irrational decisions. We must not let lies dictate the truth of what is going on in our society.

name: Ian Borg
text: President fil-Kariga tal-Kunsill. - Grazzi tal-istedina li għamiltu lill-Presidency sabiex f'isem il-Kunsill fuq suġġett ta 'tħassib komuni nagħtu l-fehmiet tagħna dwar kif l-Unjoni Ewropea tista' tirreaġixxi għad-diskorsi ta 'mibeguliħda, il-lzm aħbarijiet foloz - fake news - fuq il-mezzo ta 'komunikazzjoni soċjali. Ippermettuli nibda bl-ewwel parti tas-suġġett, jiġifieri d-diskors ta ’mibegħda. L-evidence minn different sips bħall-Aġenzija tal-Unjoni Ewropea għad-Drittijiet Fundamentali u l-Kunsill tal-Ewropa tikkonferma żieda alarming fl-intolerance u l-mibegħda fl-Ewropa. Jista ’jkun hemm several raġunijiet li jispjegaw dan il-fenomenu, iżda żgur li ma hemm ebda lok għal ġustifikazzjoni għalih. L-Unjoni Ewropea adopted leġiżlazzjoni speċifika dwar il-ġlieda kontra l-intolerance u l-mibegħda, partikolarment anki l-framework decision tal-2008 dwar il-ġlieda kontra ir-razziżmu u l-ksenofobija. U f'Ġunju tas-sena l-oħra, fl-2016, il-Kunsill stieden ukoll lill-Istati Members jiżguraw it-transpożizzjoni u l-implimentazzjoni effective tal-framework decision u ta 'liġijiet oħrajn relevant marbutin ma' ta 'mibegħda fuq livell nazzjonali sabiex jiġġieldu kontra l-pjaga tar-reati ta 'mibegħda. U barra minn hekk, il-Kunsill talab ukoll lill-Istati Members jiżviluppaw effective methods sabiex jiġu rrappurtati r-crimes ta ’mibegħda u allura tkun żgurata r-reġistrazzjoni kif xieraq tagħhom. Ma hemmx dubju, Sur President, illi l-mezzo ta 'komunikazzjoni soċjali llum huma wieħed mill-mezzo ewlenin, kif qalet anki l-Ladies Fajon, wieħed mill-mezzo ewlenin kif id-diskors ta' mibegħda qed jinfirexies ma 'ħafna n jinfirex fl-inqas żmien possibbli. U rimedju possibbli kontra din l-epidemija hija reazzjoni Ewropea li tkun koordinata u tkun determined. Fil-kuntest tal-kooperazzjoni interistituzzjonali, il-Kunsill diġà wkoll appoġġa l-pjanijiet ambizzjużi tal-Grupp ta ’Livell Għoli tal-Kummissjoni li qed jipprova jiżviluppa, mal-Istati Members, prattiċi u għodod konkreti ħalli titjieb ir-reazzjoni għar-razziżmu, il-ksenofobija u forom oħra ta ’intoleranzi. U allura nilqgħu u nappoġġaw ukoll id-djalogu li għaddej fil-livell tal-Unjoni Ewropea ma ’kumpaniji ewlenin tal-informatika sabiex tiġi addressed to il-pjaga. Fl-aħħar iżda mhux l-inqas f’dan l-await għandna niftakru u nfaħħru wkoll il-ħidma eċċellenti li saret mill-Aġenzija li rreferejt għaliha aktar kmieni. Dawn il-kontromiżuri jkunu kollha għalxejn, however, jekk ninsew l-irwol important tal-edukazzjoni u l-ħidma tagħna fost iż-żgħażagħ. U b’mod aktar preċiż il-bżonn li niżviluppaw ir-reżiljenza demokratika, il-litteriżmu medjatiku, it-tolerance, il-ħsieb kritiku u anke ħiliet ta ’riżoluzzjonijiet tal-tal-kunflitti fil' tag-proċlim. Fl-aħħar nett, nixtieq nenfasizza wkoll li l-ġlieda kontra d-diskors ta 'mibegħda fuq l-internet hija wkoll waħda mill-prijoritajiet tagħna bħala Presidency. Fil-fatt, proprju għada fil-Belt Valletta ser jitlaqqgħu madwar mitt espert li ser jiddiskutu kif għandhom jitwasslu b'effective narrative modes pożittivi kontra d-diskors ta 'mibegħda fuq l-internet u l-irwol tal-Unjoni Ewropea u l-irwol tal-Unjoni Ewropea u Members fl-appoġġ lis-soċjetà ċivili f'dan l-isforz. Element pożittiv ta 'dan l-event huwa, jidhirli, il-fatt illi l-means ta' komunikazzjoni soċjali qed jitqiesu mhux biss bħala l-problem iżda bħala parti mis-soluzzjoni. Issa nixtieq nidħol aktar fid-Dettall dwar it-hold parts tad-debatit: il-manipulazzjoni u l-propaganda permezz tal-fake news. L-aħbarijiet foloz u l-informazzjoni skorretta li jitqiesu minn ħafna bħala perikolużi għad-demokraziji għax jheddu s-sisien infushom tas-soċjetajiet tagħna: li ċ-ċittadini jeleġġent afna bħala perikolużi għad-demokraziji għax jheddu s-sisien infushom tas-soċjetajiet tagħna: li ċ-ċittadini jeleġġent afna bħala perikolużi u ġust. Iż-żieda fil-popularity tal-internet u l-media tal-komunikazzjoni soċjali wasslet għal tkattir ta 'sorsi tal-aħbarijiet, u dan minnu nnifsu huwa tajjeb, iżda bosta minn fosthom mhux ta' min joqgħod fuqhom. Hija reality. U allura l -organazzjonijiet tal-aħbarijiet jinsabu taħt pressjoni dejjem akbar biex iwasslu fluss kontinwu ta 'aħbarijiet fil-mument li jseħħu, u allura jħalli anqas żmien, bħala ħin, għall-kwika tal-veralità tal-kontroll. U allura dik hija challenge fuq il-kmamar tal-aħbarijiet illi aħna nifhmu. Barra minn hekk, inti għandek ukoll l-atturi populisti li qed ixerrdu informazzjoni skorretta sabiex jappoġġaw in-narrative tagħhom, illi hija ta 'ħsara partikolari fi snin b’mod partikolari meta l-poplu jkun qiegħed jiegagħmel tmel. Mhuwiex faċli li ċ-ċittadini jagħrfu liema huma l-aħbarijiet il-foloz, jew anke li jsibu u jaċċessaw l-informazzjoni affidabbli. Smajna diġà xi proposed u dwar dan nimmaġina li Members oħrajn jitkellmu matul dan id-debitu. L- algorithms jagħlqu lin-nies f'bużżieqa: sew meta wieħed qed ifittex ir-riżultati u sew fuq il-media ta 'komunikazzjoni soċjali, illi qed isir dejjem aktar diffiċli biex in-nies jiġu different exposed għal fehwomn. U allura l-preġudizzji jissaħħu peress li l-means ta 'komunikazzjoni soċjali joħolqu bżieżaq illi jiffiltraw l-informazzjoni. U allura jeħtieġ li l-gvernijiet, l -organazzjonijiet tal-aħbarijiet u l-kumpanniji anke tal-informatika jagħrfu dawn il-perikli u jieħdu azzjoni kontra tagħhom. The-Presidency tuża l-mezzo ta 'komunikazzjoni soċjali, u fuq l-internet ukoll, sabiex tiżgura li tkun aċċessibbli l-informazzjoni affidabbli f'dak li għandu x'jaqsam il-ħidma tagħna. But hawnhekk m’aħniex qegħdin nitkellmu biss fuq il-ħidma tagħna, qed nitkellmu fuq sens ħafna aktar wiesa '. Smajt ukoll illi xiorganazzjonijiet tal-aħbarijiet, jidhirli li fi Franza, bħalissa qed ukoll jingħaqdu ma 'pjattaformi ta' media ta 'komunikazzjoni soċjali fil-ġlieda kontra fil-fatt it-tkattir tal-fake news fuq l internet U f'xi Member States oħrajn, is-sejħa għal leġiżlazzjoni li tħares id-debitu politiku minn manipulazzjoni u l-qerq sfaċċat fuq media ta 'komunikazzjoni soċjali qed titqawwa. Il-kumpanniji tal-informatika nemmen illi għandhom jaqdu rwol tagħhom fis-soċjetà u allura dak il-ħarsien ta 'dan l-element ewlieni li hija d-demokraziji tagħna. President, Honorable Members, nixtieq nagħlaq billi nisħaq dwar kemm hu important li ma nħallux li ċ-ċittadini tagħna jitqarrqu minn fake news u anke is-soċjetajiet tagħna illi jkunu determined mill-mibegħda. Aħna wkoll nużaw pjattaformi soċjali, aħna wkoll naraw dawn ir-realtajiet u jiena nittama li l-means soċjali jkunu l-pjattaforma fejn wieħed jesprimi l-pożittività, il-pjattaforma fejn wieħbie-malta-jaqs l-esperjenzi pożittivi, u mhux ikollu jitqarraq b'aħbarijiet foloz u anke ddominati mill-mibegħda. L-irwol tagħna huwa wkoll illi nfakkru lilna nfusna dwar ir-responsabbiltajiet tagħna u nkunu serji u responsabbli għal dak kollu li ngħidu. U għal din ir-raġuni, il-liberty tal-espressjoni għandha l-limits tagħha u hija r-responsabbiltà komuni tagħna li nilħqu dak il-bilanċ ġust għalkemm naf li dan huwa diffiċli ħafna drabi ma jkunx faċli.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, politicians have a responsibility to uphold European fundamental values of freedom, democracy and solidarity. We have a responsibility to make sure that we have effective tools to address situations where the right to free expression is deliberately abused to promote violent extremism or discrimination against certain groups in society. This is based on the set of values laid down in Article 2 of the Treaty: ‘The Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities.’ It is our collective duty to show that democracy is there for everyone. Countering all expressions of discrimination, violence and intolerance is a priority for all of us. It requires a joint effort. The EU has increased its actions to prevent and fight against different forms of hate crime and hate speech.  The proliferation of hate speech online is shrinking the space for democratic discussions. When ‘toxic narratives’ about migrants and religious minorities publicly incite hatred and violence, the thin line between hate speech and hate crime merges into one. Where public incitement to violence and hatred is spread against groups or individuals on grounds of their race, ethnicity or religion, we have EU laws that criminalise these kinds of behaviour. The Commission has engaged with the social media operators to counter illegal online hate speech. In May 2016, IT companies – Facebook, Microsoft, Twitter and YouTube – agreed a voluntary Code of Conduct with commitments to take action and tackle illegal online content that publicly incites violence and hatred. We will present the results of this self-regulatory exercise next month. The Commission’s proposal to revise the Audiovisual Media Services Directive widens the definition of hate speech by referring to ‘incitement to violence or hatred’, and includes ethnic origin, belief, disability, age or sexual orientation. It calls for a requirement for video-sharing platforms to protect people against incitement to violence or hatred. The Commission is now assessing whether improved EU-wide procedures are needed for the removal of illegal content from online platforms. We will announce our conclusions on 10 May this year as part of the mid-term review of the Digital Single Market. Fake news – or simply ‘lies’ – are also a serious problem... (The speaker was interrupted by off-microphone comments from Ms Morvai)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Hon. Morvai, please note that you cannot interrupt the discussion.We are talking about tolerance and intolerance, try to be respectful of the discussion and of our guests.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Fake news or simply lies are also a serious problem. We are aware of the need to protect freedom of speech and to trust people’s common sense, but we also need to be aware of the possible negative effects of this phenomenon. Promoting media literacy is vital, as is the need for quality journalism. All journalists’ codes of conduct include accuracy as one of their main requirements. Self-regulation and ethical standards play a very important role here. Social media platforms and users are acting to expose fake news and unmask the source. I also see global brands and media organisations deciding to move advertising money only to sites that are known to be free from harmful content. I welcome private sector initiatives to cut commercial funding of fake news sites. Last November, First Vice-President Frans Timmermans, together with Commissioners Oettinger and Jourová, organised the European Commission’s Annual Colloquium on Fundamental Rights. This focused on media pluralism and democracy. It identified two main routes: ethical standards among those producing media, and media literacy among those using it. Lastly, the EU External Action Service has set up a taskforce on strategic communication to promote EU policies and a healthy media environment in the Eastern Partnership region. Its key task is to improve the EU’s capacity to forecast, address and respond to disinformation activities by external parties. Preventing the damaging effects of fake news is a challenge for all society. It means that industry, civil society, academia and lawmakers need to continue their discussions on this problem so that we can better understand it and identify possible policy responses.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Incitement to hatred, recruiting for terrorist or other criminal purposes, fanatization, ideologization, demarcation, marginalization, incitement to acts of violence - none of this is a trivial offense, none of these are things that can simply be left standing. In normal reality, this leads to a prosecutor's investigation, it then leads to a lawsuit and then to a conviction. What is true in the real world must also apply in the digital world. In the digital world, there must be no legal free space that enables people to hold hate speech at others, to cause endless suffering, to marginalize people, to bully or persecute them for various arbitrary reasons and then to enjoy themselves without being held accountable for being able to anonymize themselves, without prosecutors and judges even having the option of still having access to the person who is committing hate speech or such a crime. For this reason it is imperative to create legal regulations for this. Beyond that, Commissioner - I am delighted with your speech - it is very important for me to put a stop to the social bots. It cannot be pretended to be hundreds of thousands of people sharing a message and wanting it, and in reality there is a program behind it, a machine that only one person or ten people send off. We have to protect ourselves from this kind of - how do you call it now - alternative facts - there are no alternative facts, there are only facts, and although there is freedom of expression, there are no alternative facts. There are facts; For example, if it is claimed that a thirteen-year-old girl by the alleged name Lisa von If refugees have been kidnapped and raped, which is being displaced worldwide and which in fact is not true, then this is seriously dangerous for a mood within the population.For this reason, it is imperative to adopt legal regulations across the EU in order to actually be able to react effectively.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mister President! It was not long ago that we celebrated the Arab Spring as a Facebook revolution, there was talk of new opportunities for citizens to participate, and nobody could have imagined at the time that we would discuss today whether the fakes spread on social media were possible news elections can decide. So social media is neither good nor bad. They have a great impact and they expand public space across borders. Social media create new audiences, and they are serious competition for the mainstream media. But it would be foolish to think that you can sit back and just watch. We must not let ourselves drift, we have to shape this process with the aim of expanding the opportunities for democratic participation. So what to do What we don't need is a censorship agency, a Ministry of Truth in the sense of Orwell. The users, the citizens, are mature enough to judge things for themselves. In order to be able to fulfill this role, of course, more information is required, more knowledge about the background, about how social media works, etc. In a certain way, all of us are digitally illiterate. Second, companies are very important. The code of conduct is an important step, but voluntary commitment is not enough. We need sets of rules, because blocking and deleting must be carried out transparently and promptly. The users must be notified and adequately informed. There must also be the possibility of objection and complaint, and there needs to be a public discussion of how to identify fake news. And finally, the possibility of counter-speech must also be strengthened. Third: Obviously criminal acts should of course be punished clearly and promptly. But we should leave it at that. We Above all, should try to see social media as an opportunity to consolidate democracy.This requires responsible citizens who courageously oppose hatred.You cannot outsource the responsibility.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, seven years ago the Smolensk catastrophe occurred killing Polish President Lech Kaczyński, his wife, and other members of the Polish elite. Fifteen minutes later a Kremlin-triggered avalanche of fake news and disinformation started to move, so powerful that it was winning the imagination and perception of western societies. Polish military pilots were blamed, the President himself, his generals. We had to swallow every possible humiliation, including the desecration of the bodies of the victims, which is totally alien to our civilisation. Hopefully we are able to learn a lesson from the mistakes.

name: Morten LØKKEGAARD
text: for the ALDE Group. - Sir. Chairman! If someone had imagined just a few years ago that we here in 2017 should stand and discuss hate speech, extreme populism and fake news, many would probably have shaken their heads and thought we were paranoid. Nevertheless, it is a reality. The new technologies have not only made it easier to communicate, they have also created a violent fragmentation - and they have helped to create echo chambers where we as citizens can seek refuge and be confirmed in our worst prejudices and perceptions. Even darker forces are abusing the new opportunities, and therefore we must, of course, be ready to defend the open, liberal society, representative democracy and the rule of law that are under pressure now. Propaganda and misinformation are simply poison for the Western values, for the opportunities we have, for our way of life and thus also for our cohesive cancer. We owe it to each other to take this threat seriously. In the Liberal Group, we are very keen to take this fight and take the lead in the fight for our democracy. However, as liberals, it is also our job to hoist the warning flag. It is important not to fall into the trap of introducing new forms of censorship, of restricting the freedoms that precisely define our society. The answer is no restrictions, no truth ministries here, thank you! What we should do, on the other hand, is to map out the threats, their extent and the possible efforts against them. I would suggest devoting resources to setting up a knowledge center for misinformation. Here, at European level, one can gather media actors and ask them to come up with ideas for self-regulation and self-justice. One could also imagine a form of certification of online content, again without interference from the authorities, but as an opportunity to stamp the quality that we are all calling for. Finally, I also believe that a European Ombudsman for freedom of expression should be reconsidered. Likewise, of course, we should back up, as there too has been said by several speakers here, about a stronger public service, about investigative journalism and about educating young people in internet skills.It has been four months since the report came from Parliament, and not much has happened yet.I believe that we should take action, and we Liberals should, of course, take the lead.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group.- Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen!Yes, it's true: hate speech, populism and fake news on social media are on the rise.Fake news aims to influence elections, to destabilize countries and organizations and thus ultimately democracy.On the other hand, in the struggle against it, there is currently a real regulatory rage, which is producing increasingly absurd proposals - from real-name requirements on the Internet to network blocking.It is naive to assume that there is only better regulation on this issue and that the problem disappears.Above all, more media skills, independent monitoring and the use of transparent commentary and discourse moderation on the Internet help against filter bubbles.One thing remains fact: the causes of racism, populism and its information lies, hate speech and social bots do not lie in the internet, but in society.It is the social climate that we have to change.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! We live in times in which false news, alternative facts suddenly become absolute truths and in which the hate speech against ethnic, sexual, religious minorities and also sexist hate speech against women is becoming more and more widespread and is gaining more publicity, especially in the social media. We recognize that the internet is not an unlawful area and that rules are also required there. Because this Internet has become part of our society, but the free, secular, democratic, pluralistic society that we have fought for has not yet found its way there. The winner of the Peace Prize of the German Book Trade, Carolin Emcke, said in her speech last year when she was the winner: “A free, secular, democratic society is something we have to learn. Again and again. ”That means giving us rules for this behavior. Rules are necessary. To the Commission: It's good that you have this code, the code of conduct with the four companies. You recognized the problem, but the implementation is poor. Because private companies cannot simply replace courts. Yes, it is important that Facebook can delete inflammatory statements, but then it needs a final decision in court. That is, it is necessary. And one more thing: we need to improve the Council framework decision on racism and xenophobia. Sexual orientation, gender identity are included, and the criminal offenses as a whole need to be defined more clearly. Let me give you two more examples of how this can be dealt with: My party leader in Austria, Eva Glawischnig, and the Austrian Greens have so far conducted over 40 proceedings, in which the main focus is on threats to life and limb, hatred, insult, foul gossip and clear falsehoods passed. We have won almost all of these proceedings.That is, that is also a way of saying stop here.The money that then had to be paid is made available to charitable organizations.And one last thing: Former German Agriculture Minister Renate Künast chose a different path.Without prior notice, she visits those agitators who have abused her on the Internet.And do you know what happens then?When they are confronted with their statements in real life, they become very small.That too is a way of dealing with these agitators.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Hon. Morvai, you showed your signs, but now I invite you to sit down, take your seat, and follow the discussion.Please don't let me intervene.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: – Mr President, I feel offended on behalf of the citizens of this Union, to see one of our colleagues behaving in a completely inappropriate way in this Chamber at this moment. I would like to say that this is not a mud-wrestling arena. This is the European Parliament and things like this should not be tolerated by you or me and I kindly ask you to turn to our colleague and ask her kindly to behave in this plenary, on behalf of all of us.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Excuse me, but you didn't need to ask me, because I did it before your surgery.I invite the Hon.Morvai, who showed her signs, to sit down and take a seat.Don't abuse my patience, I've already asked him twice.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: On behalf of the EFDD Group. - We keep hearing that the Americans did not elect that Short, that Hungary is not led by that Orban, but that Poland is not that Kaczyński. The French people may choose the wrong Marie Le Pen. The fear of losing power, the fear of losing political influence, even the fear that one may have to take responsibility for the impoverished creation of an omnipotent market is what gives rise to debates in which open and frank words are called hate speech, where the interests of society, not a handful, are served politicians called populism. Strange that discussion today. It's like we're not being blown up. It’s as if we, not us in Europe, feel hatred. As if the Pope had told European leaders before the anniversary of the Treaty of Rome that, yes, so-called democracy is very good and public representation in politics is bad.
