I would like to remind you that the word 'popular' in its primary sense means society. And the word democracy is by no means a tool for those in group politics to maintain and increase their power. Let us stop measuring fictional ratings of democracy. Let us finally turn our faces to the people whose interests we have chosen to represent. I recall that in the countries of Eastern Europe many years ago there was one truth and one party and election results that satisfied the then authorities. We are now talking about elections that are affected on the one hand, and we are considering how to influence them on the other. Consequently, under the guise of democracy, we are pursuing the same results, so that the elections retain their power, so that they are not the choice of the people of Europe. So who needs an election then when there is no choice?

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group.- (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I apologize to those who watch us from home, I apologize to the public who are listening to these delusions.In my opinion you are not normal.There are twenty million unemployed in Europe, there is Islamic terrorism, there is an out-of-control immigration, and what do you engage the European Parliament with, which is also deserted on Wednesday afternoons?With the gag on Facebook, the hoaxes, the fake news!You should be treated by a good doctor!I would like to know if… (The President cut off the speaker) (Applause) Thank you for the applause.Watch them throw you out if you clap, so beware ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Mr Salvini, you must be respectful not only of the decision of a Chamber which, democratically, decided to discuss this issue, but also of the colleagues who spoke.I invite you to be attentive to the words you use.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: - So, this vague threat makes me neither hot nor cold. For the peoples of Europe, being against Islamic terrorism means being Islamophobic, being against gay adoption means being homophobic, wanting to close Roma camps or stop clandestine invasion means being racist. No: it means having common sense, it means being free men. You are doing badly, you are no longer able to buy brains, to check the newspapers, the news, the radios. In Great Britain they voted as they wanted, in the United States they voted as they wanted, in Italy they voted as they wanted, and you are going crazy. So what are you making up? Facebook gag, Internet gag, penalties - 1 million, 5 million, 50 million! You invent George Orwell's Ministry of Truth, the Ministry of Propaganda. I expect the European Parliament to pay the psycho-police to investigate the psycho-crimes of those who are not aligned with the single thought and the single currency. You can invent all the gags you want. The only thing you can do is pack your bags and go look for a real job, because freedom doesn't stop anyone, neither here nor elsewhere. Thank you and long live the network, long live Facebook.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - Mr President, I fully agree that there is a problem in Europe with hate speech and fake news. The political forces currently prevailing on the continent have unleashed a unique rhetorical attack on anyone who expresses views that do not agree with the established ones, and we have reached the point where the national controversy has almost been criminalized. The current political system is one that systematically cultivates and nurtures hatred in our societies, dismantling social cohesion and establishing a real witch-hunt against those who dare to have a different view. Contrary to what you accuse us of, we believe in freedom of opinion. Everyone, without exception, should be free to express their views, no matter how much we disagree with them. As for populism, the term itself, as it is used today, is simply another creation of the ruling political class, which baptizes a "populist" who presents a different perspective that is closer to the real needs of the people. It is the fault of populism, you say, that the citizens are now aligned with parties outside the political establishment. In fact, you simply have no contact with their desires. Fake news has a huge share of responsibility for governments and systemic parties with fake leaks. Every day, social media friendly to the political establishment distorts the truth and creates a false reality, hoping that they will continue to control and guide the citizens. There is no greater and more insidious propaganda mechanism in the world than the administrators of these social media networks that serve political interests.

name: Franck PROUST
text: - Mr. President, demagoguery, said Aristotle, is the perversion of democracy. Is it a coincidence that demagoguery was born in the cradle of democracy in Athens? No, because the freedom of speech offered by democracy leads to the freedom of ideas. Is it a coincidence that there is so much demagoguery in European democracies? No, because Europe, beyond promoting the free movement of goods and people, also embodies the free movement of ideas. It all depends on the intentions of those who wear them on social media, it is not for nothing that we talk about viral spread on the internet. The notion of virus is there. Some take the opportunity to inoculate it. It was not Donald Trump who invented this alternative fact process. We have specialists in the hemicycle, such as Ms. Le Pen, Mr. Mélenchon and even Mr. Jadot. Fear is their breeding ground, the internet their weapon, and citizens their targets. Their popularity is not based on what they have done, but on what they do with the facts. Their mentors are known. From Hugo Chávez to Vladimir Putin, to be sure, there is experience. The great projects of history have, however, been carried out in the serenity and discretion of negotiations, such as the Treaty of Rome, whose 60th anniversary was celebrated. Let's take a step back. Can we imagine General de Gaulle responding on Twitter to people criticizing his call from London? Can one imagine parodies on the Internet of Chancellor Kohl and President Mitterrand holding hands in the Douaumont ossuary? Could we have shown the Normandy landings on Facebook? The giants of the web must take responsibility for letting arsonist firefighters play with fire. And the media must be able to afford journalists who take the time to analyze. The two subjects are linked for those who intend to restore serenity. I end with a rhetorical question: populist parties have been more powerful since the advent of social media, is this too a coincidence?

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: - Mr. President, Amnesty International, in its last annual report for 2016, estimates that this has been the year of hate speech and demonization through the dissemination of messages that convey the dangerous idea that some people are less than others. In conclusion: I reject the different. Hate speech plays a fundamental role in the perpetuation of discriminatory stereotypes, whether based on race, gender, or sexual orientation. And, in this sense, we must commit ourselves from the European institutions to pour our efforts into the eradication of these stereotypes. To prepare this debate I have read some reports. One of them said that, in a study on misogyny, carried out during three weeks in April 2016 among users in a European country, more than 200,000 tweets with the word "bitch" or "whore" were found, finding that every ten seconds someone insults a woman with those words on Twitter. And the truth is that as a button shows. A month ago, I was participating in a debate in this House that had media and public significance. I received a lot of messages through social networks. One of them is this. I'm not going to read it in full, but it says: "Mrs. Iratxe Garper, you're dead, whore." He carries a photo of a woman chained and hanged and a photo of a hand with a firearm. You will understand that to remain impassive in this situation is to allow the values ​​of the European project to deteriorate. To some it may seem inconsequential that we have these debates today, but I think it is necessary that we all be able to guarantee that freedom of expression has limits and that limit is that of respect for people's rights.

name: Andrew LEWER
text: – Mr President, there is a battle being waged at the moment against hate speech, and, while gearing up to take part in this sounds laudable, without care the result can be, inadvertently or otherwise, censorship. It leads to questions about who determines what hate speech is. Free speech is essentially accepting that people are free to say things we do like, not merely free to say things we do like. Should these be offensive then they can be tackled by a forthright debate. Indeed, debating ideas in a public forum makes it harder for those ideas to be formed as an individual insult, and a public debate provides the target of offence with a rebuttal. There is a quotation that is commonly attributed to Voltaire: ‘I disapprove of what you say but I will defend to the death your right to say it’. That was in fact written by Voltaire’s biographer, Evelyn Beatrice Hall, and she was absolutely right.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Mr President, when addressing fake news, or rather junk news, or broadly the impact of the technological revolution on democracy, we must ensure the rule of law retains its meaning in a hyper-connected world. Hundreds of millions of people only access news through social media, and now the largest tech players – Facebook, YouTube, Google – should act with equally massive responsibility. The algorithms they perfect for optimal advertising revenues can become propaganda and hoax vehicles and the claims that platforms are neutral intermediaries, especially with more and more self-regulation, will prove unsustainable.  No one wants a Ministry of Truth, but I am also not reassured when Silicon Valley or Mark Zuckerberg are the de facto designers of our realities or of our truths. Through the e-Commerce Directive and otherwise we must ensure that free speech, access to information and the protection from discrimination are ensured. But we must be careful not to treat hate speech the same way as distasteful, undesired, shocking or insulting expressions. Even the ones that we have heard here today should be debated in an open manner. I fully agree that we have to make sure that censorship is not the alternative when we are trying to make the rule of law meaningful online.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Mr President, I agree with much of what has been said and I do not want to repeat it. Please allow me to submit my own opinion. We have our own responsibility, dear colleagues. Are thousands of politicians, in every corner of Europe, not ready to lie to the world but to be honest with themselves? Let's be honest. Aren't thousands of politicians, in every corner of Europe, involved with one, two or more media outlets? Doesn't this cause corruption and feed the myth and the lie? We, to a great extent, nurture the phenomenon we are trying - those of us who are trying today - to stop. And we have an obstacle in front of us that we have largely created and gotten to the point where one has to be prepared that they can call him a "liar" if he tells the truth. We need education, ladies and gentlemen, - I very much agree here with Mr Borg - education to help us adequately fight lies and myths. Lies and myths that often take centuries to be abandoned, especially if we feed them with deeds and apathy. Castles, dear colleagues, are being catalyzed, but myths and lies are not being catalyzed, except by the development of the youth crisis. But we also need our faith and our constant struggle for it.

name: Helga TRÜPEL
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! There has always been fake news, but its scope has increased significantly. Hate comments on the Internet have also grown significantly and have reached a level that cannot be tolerated. It is therefore no wonder, given all the really positive developments through social networks, that anti-social networks are now being talked about more and more often. Echo chambers on the internet mean that we are only ever strengthened in our own opinions and that we do not perceive and consider other opinions enough. But that is the essence of an open democratic society, precisely to perceive other opinions. Freedom of expression must not be restricted - I would like to emphasize that again. This is not about a Ministry of Truth, but illegal content such as incitement to hatred and violence and group-specific misanthropy are not covered by freedom of expression. And if illegality has already been established, it must be deleted immediately and, in obvious cases, deleted within 24 hours. And many companies, especially Twitter and Facebook, are still doing far too little here, and more political pressure needs to be exerted here. But private companies must not be the ones to replace the courts, but the final decision on deletion must lie with the courts. Overall, however, we need to strengthen media literacy and we need a public debate on the future of quality journalism, and I also believe that we need a European public service broadcaster, and we urgently need to have this debate now.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I brought three articles taken from traditional media: Colin Powell presenting the evidence of the existence of Saddam Hussein's weapons of mass destruction, the catastrophic outcomes for Brexit and the apocalypse if the "no "to the referendum in Italy. These are three examples to show that fake news always existed, well before the advent of the Internet. Fake news has always existed, because this is the information that you have used to manipulate information, for example by funding European propaganda. But who can have the authority to say what is true and what is false? The truth is that you are the power that seeks to absolve itself for the mistakes it has made, for having given citizens in the hands of the banks and finance. You remain closed here in this ivory tower and you don't even realize it. And for a reason: because the network scares you. Because the network allows you to get in touch with citizens, without actually having a filter in front of you, and therefore for this reason you have proposed, for example, the creation of an independent authority for checking the truth on the web. Here, attention: please, do not jeopardize the freedom of the network, because it is very dangerous, and you could even have an authoritarian drift. The solution, on the other hand, is education, civic sense. In this sense, for example, projects for citizens' media literacy are welcome, especially for the new generations, for adolescents, for minors. We want informed and aware citizens. Instead, you want controllable media. I close by quoting our founder of the 5 Star Movement Gianroberto Casaleggio: "Information online can be true or false, or both, but online it is impossible to sustain a lie for a long time".

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! In his last sentence today, the representative of the Council dropped his pants. And I didn't like what I heard at all, but it was predictable. What's this about? He made it clear: it is the limits of freedom of expression - literally, he said that. That is exactly what hate speech is about. Because freedom of expression ends at the penal code. And it's not that some things aren't already prohibited. There is the insult, and there are many, many other things that are prohibited in Germany and elsewhere. But political opinion making in the sense of a ministry of truth - we certainly don't need that under this label. And when we talk about fake news: Well, it is the job of politics to argue about truths, but it is not their job to agree a majority of objective truths. There, too, the representative of the Council said something very nice: it is particularly important to fight the lies put forward by politicians before elections. Well, give your colleagues in the Council a warm greeting: all the governments in this European Union base their ability to govern precisely on this: on lying to the voters in their countries before the elections.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: - Mr President, one more debate that is pointless, specious, even grotesque, on, I quote: "hate speech, populism and false information on social media - towards a Union response". This debate in fact proves that the majority of this institution, faced with its failures, has nothing better to do than attack the opposition. What you call "populism" is the voice of the peoples who are victims of Euro-globalism who want to express their legitimate anger to you. What you call "fake news" are mostly sassy responses to official lies from print or broadcast media groups you control. And if there is some false information there, what is stopping you from refuting it? What you call "hate speech" is anything that goes against the dogmas that you have established. In reality, hatred is the product of political correctness. In Germany, where the head of state boasted of respect for human rights yesterday, there are more than 1,000 political prisoners or prisoners of conscience. In France, and whatever one thinks of their ideas, which everyone, of course, has the right to contradict, an 88-year-old academic, Professor Faurisson, a father of a large family, Mr. Reynouard, and a known polemicist, Mr. Soral, each have just been sentenced to prison for expression, under the freedom-killing laws that exist in my country. This is what should shock you. Sweep these laws instead of preparing for the introduction of new censorship.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: - Mr President, Europe must seize the opportunities that arise from the digital revolution, while facing the new political battle that is that of populism against representative democracy. But confidence in European democracy must be restored to citizens. And to win the battle against populism, we cannot ignore the existing social unrest, something that populists take advantage of. We need to reconnect with the part of the citizenry that feels abandoned. To facilitate participation, we must bring Europe closer to our regions with the growing use that this Parliament makes of digital tools and through its information offices that tell our work to each citizen in their language. At the same time, it is necessary to identify and fight against the techniques that are serving populisms to go against the European Union, especially through social networks. And in this area, it is urgent that digital platforms assume responsibilities. We must ensure that they do not contribute to the spread of hateful messages and false news. They have to cut the channels that facilitate their dissemination and they must be more transparent, because citizens deserve to know how the information they receive is decided. Fighting the tyranny of the algorithm is an ethical question. In addition, we must guarantee resources to combat the disinformation that comes, for example from Russia. But it is not enough to deny the populisms that seek to delegitimize the Union. We Europeans must promote a solid European narrative. We have to communicate more and better Europe. Because telling our citizens what Europe does for them is the best way to regain lost trust. Of course, having heard some opinions this afternoon in this debate, I am concerned, as much or more than the false news, the lack of respect, the excess of demagoguery and the contempt for this Institution and what it represents.

name: Soraya POST
text: – Mr President, not a long time ago hate speech was a fringe phenomenon: Neo-Nazis shouting in the streets or other cowards who have a lack of intelligence, common sense and human dignity. It was, of course, still a shocking reminder of the atrocities of Nazis, not least to Jews, Roma and the LGBTI community, but a decade ago hate speech was contained. Now it has become mainstream. Due to social media it can spread without control. Hate speakers are now even in power in some countries.  Therefore I am very encouraged by the EU Code of Conduct with Facebook, Microsoft Twitter and YouTube to counter hate speech online. But we cannot rest. The hate speakers certainly will not. The IT companies need to work closely with civil society and with the victims of hate speech and share best practice among themselves. And should the EU Code of Conduct not work we need to put hard legislation in place.  We have a duty to stop the hate in time this time around, and hate speech is not what freedom of expression is.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: - Mr President, we are all aware of the enormous increase in populism and hatred in our countries. I appeal first and foremost to the responsibility of us, all politicians. The absence of critical thinking manifests itself in all spheres of society, and even politicians are not immune to it. Many have lost the ability to respond in a cultured and democratic way to their opponents. Today, every critic is immediately labeled: EXTREMIST, if he expresses his opinion, which goes against the majority. As politicians, we must therefore be careful with this concept and really use it only for those who deny the truth or historical facts. We are celebrating 60 years since the signing of the founding Treaties of Rome, but what did they mean for Europe? Above all, peace and cooperation between countries that have fought against each other for years. I consider it outrageous if someone describes the murder of Jews, Roma and others in concentration camps only as an uncertain historical fact. Today, the presentation of false, hateful and racist views is confused with the search for truth and freedom of speech. If we do not act wisely and vigorously against this, what our fathers in Europe founded will end in ruins. That is why I want politicians and I pray that they will not be afraid to face criticism, but to move them forward in the search for real solutions to the crisis we have here.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: - Mr President! Yesterday, thousands of people formed a human chain around the Central European University in Budapest. This is because the Orbán government's legislation, which is now affecting this university, is a frontal attack on academic freedom and all critical thinking in Hungary. It could not have happened without it being preceded by hate propaganda, populism and alternative media, which have repeatedly incited that this could happen. It was very brave of these people to form this ring, because we know that what is happening in Hungary now, in terms of academic freedom, has been preceded by hate propaganda on social media, alternative facts and a society that has more or less suffocated freedom of speech and instead cultivated a culture of silence. The nationalist, totalitarian view that characterizes the Orbán government, which previously politicized the rule of law and introduced state censorship, has now gone a step further and attacks research, education and ultimately academic freedom. What is happening in Hungary is an insult to the EU and all that we stand for. And our answer must be simple: the bottom has been reached. We must now stand up and defend the academic freedom and the values ​​on which this Union is based.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: - Mr President, where does fake news, hate speech and populism gain ground? Where there is a lack of transparency, education is degraded and unemployment, poverty and inequality remain high. What are they discussing in the Commission? We do not know in depth. How does the Eurogroup make decisions? Are the minutes of the meetings of the European Stability Mechanism, the European Central Bank or the IMF published? No. Darkness, suspicion, information warfare and competition for lies prevail. These are forced to be managed by the citizen. Lying survives where transparency, education and prosperity are lacking. It is a matter of democracy. And the answer we have to give to this is one: Everything in the light!

name: Julia REDA
text: – Mr President, almost any female politician will have experienced hate speech on her social media accounts. It is a widespread phenomenon that did not start with the internet. It is important not to forget that the core of the problem is not social media, it is sexism and racism.  According to Council of Europe data only 15% of hate speech messages actually qualify as illegal. Then why do certain Member States think we can fix this problem? We are simply getting Facebook and Twitter to install a content filter. No technology is qualified to make the difficult decisions needed to define hate speech. By relying solely on technology we are not helping the victims and we are silencing free speech if we try to turn private companies into enforcers of laws that often do not even exist in the first place.  Instead, we need to address the terrible experiences that many women have when they actually try to report sexist hate speech to the police. We need to invest in training for law enforcement, in easier reporting of crimes and in supporting grassroots initiatives countering hate speech. If we try to solve one problem with blunt and ineffective technological tools we will end up creating more problems.

name: Tim AKER
text: – Mr President, we learned something from the European Parliament’s reaction to Article 50. This debate is on an EU response to all the things you try and associate with the Brexit vote. If you genuinely want to build a better Europe, how about this: stop what you are doing and think about why people voted the way they did. Those you call ‘populists’ are patriots. We love our countries, we love our communities, we love living in nations where the people are the masters and, through democratic decisions, the people have the final say. What they hate is you lot imposing unfettered immigration that has transformed communities without the people’s say. They do not like seeing their streets changed without their approval. They do not like living in places that no longer resemble those they grew up in, and they know the EU is to blame. You can call us all the names you like, but it will not change the result. The majority of the British people voted to get our borders back, to get our democracy back, to get our country back and the sooner we are out of this place, the better.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Mr Aker, I remind you that the Brexit debate took place this morning.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: - Mr President, the European Union is in dire straits. The British people fired her and other Europeans are about to do the same. Instead of questioning herself, she seeks to gag her opponents, those she calls such a pretty name: the populists. Today the European Parliament dares to conflate populism and hate speech. The goal is transparent. It consists of demonizing the patriots to better censor them in social networks. The Commission has just admitted through Mr Ansip: "We have contacted the social media operators," he said. And other speakers, like Mr. Proust, have just designated the target of future censorship: Marine Le Pen. If you have any honor left, ladies and gentlemen Europeanists, tackle the real hate speech emanating from the jihadists and respect democracy. Respect the freedom of expression of your political opponents.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: - Mr President, Mr President of the Council, Commissioner, the subject of this debate is too wide. Hate speech, hate speach, is not the same as populism. Fake news is not necessarily hate speech. I am afraid that we are mixing different realities. But I want to refer to each one. First, we cannot tolerate hate speech. Not in this house, nor in any public forum, and that also includes social networks. It is necessary to involve and cooperate all actors: State, online platforms, schools, traditional media. All. It is not just about removing the hate speech that appears in the public square, but first and foremost, preventing it from arising. It is important to educate for tolerance, respect for others and difference. Second, we cannot be afraid to look at fake news, also as a propaganda weapon with geopolitical implications. And for that, the Union must be strong and have robust means to attack what are often deliberate disinformation campaigns. Third, populism is an extraordinarily complex phenomenon, which grows every day. We must fight it, but we must also understand its origin. Reducing populism to hate speech and false news can also be populism. Combating these phenomena requires an effective, robust and comprehensive response by the Union. The danger they pose to democracy and freedom is too serious. That is why political leaders and citizens are required not to give in to either facilitism or cowardice.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I want to emphasise the social and citizenship aspects in this debate, in particular media literacy and digital participation within a safe internet. Media literacy enable citizens to use and create media content effectively and safely. Media-literate people are able to exercise more informed choices, understand the nature of content and services and take advantage of the full range of opportunities offered by communication technologies. Media literacy and education for citizenship is not only important for learning about the tools, but also to encourage a shift in political cultures and practices so that individuals can be not only digital consumers and users but active citizens in connected societies.  I remain very concerned by the lack of effective response to cyber bullying and discrimination online. Consumers and citizens, in particular the most vulnerable, especially children, must be properly protected online. Member States and the EU must work with internet providers and platforms in order to ensure that illegal and offensive content is effectively taken down and stays down.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Mr President, we talk a lot at the moment of fake news, whether we think of Trump’s tweets, Putin’s control of the Russian media or the false promises spread by some Brexiteers during the UK’s EU referendum campaign. We might have a new word for this but it is plain, old-fashioned, populist propaganda, lies and half-truths, seeking to muddy the waters and twist reality for political gain. The internet, social media and 24-hour news cycles have made their job all too easy.  Fake news is not the only addition to the political lexicon in recent years though. ‘Truthiness’, ‘post-fact’ and the use of ‘metropolitan liberal elites’ as a pejorative, are all part of a wider movement against expert opinion and reasoned analysis towards a world of half-truths where views and opinions are reported as facts. We must not underestimate the difficulty in counteracting these forces. Trust in governments, politicians and traditional sources of media is low and they are deemed to be biased. Indeed, the arguments put forth by official institutions, even very credible ones, to counteract fake news are derided as nothing more but the same thing: merely another opinion, a different point of view.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: - Mr. President, the free communication of thoughts and opinions is one of the most precious human rights. Any citizen can therefore speak and write freely, except to answer for the abuse of this freedom. This is the principle laid down by the French revolutionary in 1789 and which has become an extremely famous formula. What's he saying? Indeed, freedom is the rule, but freedom of expression is not a right to lie. This is not an absolute principle, no offense to some in this Chamber who sometimes seem to feel targeted. Without recalling either the beautiful legend of the Bocca della Verità of Rome, which threatened to crush the hand of the one who was lying and without imagining either to create an authority of the truth, the freedom of expression also imposes to protect against the speeches of hatred, against speeches inciting jihadism and terrorism, against racist and offensive speech, against false information that floods social networks, to such an extent that they are now often qualified as anti-social networks. We must take action against illegal content and remove it. We need to work with the big internet companies, we need to work with the education community to deconstruct disinformation, and we need to actively work with professional journalism to remove this false information.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the title of this debate is actually somewhat ideological. The case of fake news with the most tragic consequences in our times is Saddam's WMD legend, which has nothing to do with populism or social media. I don't want to deny that there is a serious problem with the quality of information. The Internet revolution has produced an unregulated monopoly system, in recent years, where very few players, Google and Facebook above all, collect 90% of the resources, have no responsibility for what they publish, do not produce content, do not pay taxes, while journalists , publishers and independents go hungry. And the public is bombarded with garbage. We could intervene, but we don't want to. The truth is that the Commission, for example, does not want to take action on the e-commerce directive, which is 17 years old and outrageously inadequate. Then there is the suspicion that we want to talk about politics and not intervene to protect the interests of citizens. Let me use three seconds for what happened in this House. Hon. Salvini does not consider political work a serious matter. Before being elected here, I worked for 38 years, since I was 17, in "real jobs". Hon. Salvini has been taking pay as a politician since he was 20. I'm sorry for him: he must have very low self-esteem.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, very different areas have been deliberately mixed here. But one thing is hate speech, cyberbullying, violence and online threats - condemnable and unacceptable, of course - while so-called populism and alleged hoaxes are quite another issue. The latter have in fact become the pretext for making the legitimate expression of the diversity of political opinion pathological or abnormal, with the consequent risk of an undemocratic squeeze. Knowing that, for example, Facebook would turn to an institution for the verification of the facts, sponsored by realities and foundations connected to the interests of multinationals or assault speculating financiers, just does not make us rest assured. Who has the right to delete or censor information? Finally, allow me to say a few words about the much reviled populisms. Why are the people, groups, movements that speak to citizens and act for their greater involvement in decision-making processes seen by so many of you as smoke in the eyes? Why do you consider the enemy who criticizes the austerity and austerity policies, or this Europe of the euro, of the big finance markets? Could it not be because they show that the king is naked and that this is not a Union of European citizens, based on cooperation, solidarity and equality? Colleagues, why do you point the finger that points to the moon?

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: - Pluriformity in the media no longer exists.The state media is completely failing to deliver colored news that is no longer recognized by people.The circulation and viewing figures are therefore constantly falling, because nobody trusts the media anymore.That is why ordinary people provide information on social media about what they experience in their normal life: that Islam is not nice, that Islamization is taking place, that this is not enrichment, that unemployment is not decreasing, that purchasing power is falling, that taxesthat the climate is not perceived as a problem and that migrants are perceived as a problem.Brussels calls all this populism and is looking at possibilities for censorship, but if Brussels wants to know what fake news is, it should mainly look at its own jubilation stories.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, the spread of false news is a security threat to all Member States of the European Union. This phenomenon needs to be effectively confronted and, on the basis of objective facts, this misinformation refuted at both European and national level. In this context, I would like to highlight the new Center against Terrorism and Hybrid Threats established by the Ministry of the Interior of the Czech Republic. The purpose of this office is to monitor threats related to the internal security of the state, among which purposeful misinformation coming from abroad undoubtedly belongs. I think it is essential that similar offices be set up in other Member States of the European Union in order to strengthen existing European mechanisms, such as East StratCom, which is currently facing Russian propaganda. Disinformation internet platforms such as Russia Today or Sputnik are a pan-European danger. I therefore call on Mrs Mogherini to pay much closer attention to this security threat than hitherto, including a sufficient budget. Underfunding the European Union's defense against misinformation originating in Russia is a significant security risk for the European Union. The information war waged by the Kremlin against the European Union aims to dismantle the European Union. The Kremlin's disinformation campaign targets every Member State of the European Union from a different perspective. Therefore, defense against it must be conducted both at the central level of the European Union and at the level of individual countries.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: - Ms. President! Hate speech, fake news in social media - all this is not a completely new phenomenon. Recently, however, perceptions of these phenomena have changed dramatically, as their political significance has suddenly, and perhaps somewhat unexpectedly, increased. And this process is inseparable from the strengthening of far-right parties and movements, from the unscrupulous politics, which, by exploiting people's ignorance, fears and worries, misleads people, deceives people, creates vile feelings and hatred towards others. However, the far right not only uses social media for this purpose, but has made hatred, the division of society, a central element of its own political culture and even a government policy. If anyone thinks this is an exaggeration, take a look at Hungary or Poland. This is the essence of the illiberal democracy being built in these countries: misleading, slipping, demagoguery. The Hungarian Prime Minister claims that the refugees are a threat to the security of the country and to Hungarian culture. He says the European Union wants to dictate taxes to attack job creation measures. He claims that NGOs are foreign-backed organizations that threaten the country’s independence, breaking the law and encouraging illegal immigration, while knowing it’s all not true. But it is organizing a propaganda campaign on these issues called a national consultation. In this lying world, the Central European University and the critical, free academic world in general become enemies. And this ruling party is sitting there, in this House, in the ranks of the EPP. It enjoys its protection and support. And all because he is afraid of democracy. But if we in the European Parliament do not oppose this policy firmly, we do not exclude it from the walls of Parliament, then we will also be contributing to the destruction of democracy.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Madam President, the false news, hatred and lies transmitted through which xenophobic and populist discourse are instruments of dictatorship and cynicism of oligarchs and hypocrites. Some political leaders want a Europe divided and made up of island countries, surrounded by high and opaque walls, created by misinformation and lies, walls through which nothing can pass inside and nothing outside, but only what these leaders want to convey to those on which actually keep them in prison. Machines for making and spreading false news are paving the way for extremism and Putinism in Europe. I will refer mainly to the influence of the Russian Federation and to the hatred and propaganda made by the Russian Federation. We must explicitly acknowledge at the level of the European Union that the Russian Federation is the main source of the hostile war of disinformation and therefore call on the High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to stop Putin's actions against the European Union.

name: Yana TOOM
text: – Madam President, first of all I have to say that I very much agree with what Tanja Fajon and Helga Trüpel said. I wanted to share with you some concerns regarding our fight against propaganda and fake news. Like Commissioner Ansip, I was raised in the Soviet Union, where so—called anti—Soviet propaganda was perceived as one of the major reasons why the Soviet people were not happy about the regime. The Communist Party believed that people were misinformed and manipulated by foreign actors, and that is why the people looked up to the West. I am sure that the other side’s propaganda has poor chances if it is not based on some real facts, or if it addresses issues that are properly touched upon by the mainstream media. As for fake news, it cannot attract public attention if it does not seem to be reliable or does not reflect the wishful thinking of the audience. For instance, any fake news about certain countries like North Korea, may be accepted by the public because the regime there is so nasty. Regrettably, mistakes, misinterpretation of data and manipulative delivery of news – I mean all these games with titles, subtitles, selection of pictures, experts and the use of specific terminology – are a big challenge for us. We need critical thinking and we definitely need to have high—quality journalism back in Europe.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: - Madam President, they want this Parliament to teach lessons on how to fight hate speech, when it turns out that this House is full of Members with violent speeches and the sanctions are laughable.Mr. Korwin-Mikke for making the Nazi salute in plenary session or for his macho speech was only sanctioned with thirty days without diets.The other day they allowed a press conference in the Parliament of the president of Hazte Oír, which is carrying out a transphobic campaign in Spain.And not only the extreme right, the problem is that they also feed hatred against migrants from the center of the chamber, every time they are associated with terrorism or are branded illegal against whom they must defend themselves.We are not here to give lessons, especially those who this weekend applauded Viktor Orbán at the congress of the European People's Party in Malta when he spoke of the invasion of immigrants.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: - Madam President! I understand that this increasingly centralized Union likes the media to be centralized to a few media houses. The European Union is making the same mistake that the American left has made, namely to confuse fake news with news that takes on different perspectives. When all Swedish media only reported the positive aspects of the enormous migration we had to our country, and in some cases pure misinformation, so-called alternative media emerged, where individual citizens on their own dug up the truth behind the angled news that dominated society. Among other things, it was revealed that the news about violent crimes often completely withheld the fact that the perpetrator was a migrant or had a foreign background. While in those cases the perpetrator was Swedish, this was reported very clearly with name and picture. Many of the major media houses in Sweden have long had the line to show only the benefits that they believe migration has, regardless of whether it can be proven or not. In most cases, their theses do not allow for closer examination by researchers or educated citizens. Both the European Union and the Swedish state keep these media houses under their arms through grants and loans. Already dominant actors receive additional support through tax funds to conduct agenda-setting journalism instead of objective news reporting. I appeal to you. The solution can not be that we simply give money to the big media houses in some kind of hope that they are right just because they have been around for many years. They were the ones who helped drive the migration crisis. It was not only Merkel and Löfven who welcomed the whole world to Europe, but also the media houses' campaigns.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: - Madam President! Yes, what we are experiencing today is a tragic comedy, and it is interesting that Mr Borg from the Presidency is warning today that wrong information is being spread by evil populists, especially before elections. That is a sensational new finding, but I am very grateful that you mentioned it that way today, because I can well remember: In my home country Austria I have seen for years from the ruling party of the Socialists that pensions are regularly taken before every election secured and rescued, but they are obviously subject to permanent decline, also thanks to the European interest rate policy. And I can well remember how our socialist state secretary at the time promised us before Austria joined the EU: “Every Austrian has a thousand schillings left in the bag.” The result is of course completely different. So I thank you for obviously warning against this. As of today, based on your factual assessment, I can also call the Austrian socialists populists. Ultimately, I am very scared in this discussion because what you want is a truth agency, censors, and I am scared of that kind of censors because who is checking these censors!

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Mr. Obermayr, you have a minute, we have to wrap up, I'm sorry.There is no question of censorship, it is just that your speaking time is over.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Madam President, the title of this debate caught my attention, because when we talk about false news - fake news - it is quite simply lies. I'm afraid you shouldn't be afraid to call things by their name. The practice of hate speech, populist arguments and lies is not new. I come from a country that had this experience under communism. What is new is indeed the use of social media. Otherwise, the goal of terrorist groups and extremist political parties is the same as that of totalitarian regimes in the past, namely to establish authoritarian regimes and thus bring totalitarian practices back to the present day. The attacks which have hit Europe savagely have made us aware of the need to work together to counter terrorist propaganda. The task is not easy because, while social media companies show goodwill, it is very difficult to spot such messages and remove them in time. The European Union has made significant efforts with the establishment of the Stratcom Task Force to combat the hate messages of the “Islamic State” group, but for our actions to have any impact, we must endow this structure with real means. A few months ago, we adopted a report on the Union's strategic communication in this area and one thing is clear: effective communication will not be enough, we must invest in education, awareness and, above all, in freedom of the press. This freedom is essential to fight against these lies.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Madam President, hatred, racism and the populisms that foster them are yet another corollary of the neoliberal and authoritarian policies that have increased the deficit in democracy, social justice and values, polarizing our societies, digging divisions, marginalizing young people, in second generation, raised in ghettos and segregation. They fueled fears and insecurities used by the UkIP, Front National, Fidesh and quejandos to promote their poisonous agendas. European governments are accomplices, without policies for employment, equality of justice and democratic control. Where are the Council and the Commission in protecting immigrant refugees? And in this era of fake news, trolls-online and Trump Tweets, how do they do anything to prevent a strategic instrument like Euronews from being, in fact, financed and controlled by Moscow and an Egyptian billionaire without ensuring the required quality and editorial exemption to a news channel associated with the European Union. Are you not aware of that, Commissioner Ansip?

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: - Madam President!Populism and lies have a very wide scope.We need to talk about what is extraordinary, about propaganda hitting from outside Europe, which wants to influence the decisions of our nations, our voters, propaganda organized by President Putin, by Russia by Putin.I want to join these appeals from Mr Štětina, Mrs Macovei, for the mobilization of the European Commission and the High Commissioner on this issue.And finally, hate speech - it must be said clearly: in reality it affects mainly Christians and Jews.It is these two communities that fall victim to discrimination, including discrimination online.You have to talk about it openly.Other groups are harmed to a much lesser extent.Antichristianism and anti-Semitism are the most basic phenomena.The answer should be good education referring to what is basic in our civilization.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, a lot of measures have already been referred to today, and I think that one can agree with a lot of those that have been taken at national level, but this is not just a national task and I am glad that the Commission is looking into it. I am not a great fan of unnecessary regulation and I would like to point at some measures that can really work pretty well.  First of all, reinforce the Strategic Communication Task Force that we already have, and establish an online space where the public at large can find a range of tools for identifying this information, with an explanation of how they work; and of course that can also be to the benefit of civil society. Secondly, strengthen media plurality and the objectivity, impartiality and independence of the media within the EU and its neighbourhood. Thirdly, support journalists and develop capacity-building programmes for media actors. Then, develop education programmes in schools to detect fake news. That is where it starts. Finally, enhance cooperation among Member States for intelligence services.  These are concrete measures that can be taken immediately, and I think the EU Strategic Task Force has to be reinforced, and that is underestimated.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: - Madam President!First of all, I would like to emphasize that we must have total respect for freedom of expression and freedom of the media, and I would particularly like to emphasize that we must increase support for public service media.But I also think we need to fight the increased hatred and the threat and the discrimination.Today, we see homophobic, sexist, racist forces ravaging wildly, and they are also supported by forces on the right-wing seats in this House.It's a shame.Countries in Europe even have laws that mean that you are not allowed to talk in a positive way about homosexuality and transsexuality.How is 2017 possible in Europe?We see open misogyny and we see an Islamophobia that is not contradicted.We have refugee camps on fire.A large group of our citizens live in insecurity.Discrimination and hatred must be fought.Incitement against ethnic groups must be extended to include homophobia, transphobia, sexism and all forms of racism.

name: Elmar BROK
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen! The new media were seen - social media - as something that gave the citizen, the individual, more opportunities to express themselves, for which the new media were actually just the platform. Today we see that these are increasingly becoming instruments of manipulation - by rich groups of the private sector and by states under the protection of privacy and freedom of expression. And I think this has to be pulled apart. We must in no way restrict personal freedom of expression through a ministry of truth or something like that. But we must not give up that we give states and strong groups the opportunity to become president or to influence other countries. And for this reason it must be made clear that there are limits to manipulation here. And that has to be done in a legal way. This has to be done by strengthening traditional media. If we destroy the ancillary protection arrangements that we will later discuss and vote in this House, normal journalists will no longer have an income, newspaper publishers will break down, and nobody will be able to say clearly what is true and what is untrue. And it will be left to this conglomerate of manipulation. That is, it is related to other things. The questions that have to do with media education are to be seen, which have to do with the distinction between the true and the untrue. The Guardian's dictum says: "Comment is free, but facts are sacred". I believe this Guardian principle no longer applies to the media world as a whole, and colleagues on the side have spread their conspiracy theories themselves in the debate.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: - The aid was granted in respect of certain arguments put forward by the Court of First Instance: the l-libertà tal-espressjoni m’hijiex dritt infinit. The espresso-es espressjoni ma tibqax dritt fundamentali fil-mument li żgħażagħ trans jew gay ikunu attakkati b’mod li jwassalhom jikkomettu suwiċidju; ma tibqax dritt il-mument li l-vjolenza domestika ssir is-suġġett ta ’ċajt goff; ma tibqax dritt il-mument li tinċita n-nies biex joqtlu lil xi ħadd minħabba t-twemmin policy tagħhom. In this case, the network has been shown to have been shown to be different from those used in the present invention. Id-diskors ta 'mibegħda online u offline jattakka l-qalba tad-democratic account. Il-Gvernijiet, is-soċjetà uivili u l-industrija tal-internet iridu jaħdmu flimkien biex jedukaw, joħolqu kuxjenza, jipproteġu lill-vittmi u jaertaertau ruħhom li min jgħid dan il-kliem ikun penalizzat. In the present case, the internal market and the discrepancies are limited to those of the Community which are indicated by the provisions of this Regulation.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: - Madam President! Indeed, the culture of debate on the Internet is sometimes aggressive, hurtful and not infrequently also hateful and threatening, and that is by no means socially acceptable. The question, however, is: Can and must we take state measures against this? And I think we'd go astray. After all, who would like to define rules in advance that should be followed later? There will be a large number of cases and we will find in practice that this is not at all affordable. It is a fight on the one hand for freedom of expression against things that are socially unacceptable. But I trust in society, in the self-healing powers. We need better education here, especially for the younger generation, so that they learn how to deal with such media, so that they learn what a fact check is. And populism is even harder to grasp. For example, if someone says: "If the euro fails, Europe will fail", I mean, that is populism. But there are a lot of people in this house who see things differently.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: A number of our colleagues who have joined us wish to speak on demand.I want to make it clear again that there are no on-demand interventions in this framework of discussions.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: - Madam President, European values ​​are based on the protection of human rights. It is based on respect for the dignity of each individual. This respect is based on our Christian-Jewish roots. Hate speech is the content and often the vocabulary of the opposite of this respect. And it doesn't matter if someone hates out of conviction or spreads hatred and lies for money - this is the case of Kremlin agents on social networks, but also in parliaments. Yes, we are in an information war where hate speech and lies have become a weapon. And with the help of an excess of lies, the information war is about undermining trust in virtually any information. This is the path to chaos and subsequent totalitarianism. Hatred and lies undermine trust. And our society is based on trust - from families to the monetary system to democracy. Therefore, renaming lies to alternative facts cannot be accepted. But there is also room for lies and hatred for exaggerated political correctness - a reluctance to name problems with dignity but clearly. Without dignified naming of problems, populism and hate speech ensue. How to face it? The spread of misinformation and hate speech must be confronted, and I therefore call on the Council, the Commission and High Representative Mogherini to set aside adequate human and financial resources to detect misinformation.

name: Kati PIRI
text: - Evidence is piling up that the Russian government is actively interfering with democratic decision-making in the West. While we are speaking here, Russia is blocking a UN Security Council resolution on the use of chemical weapons in Idlib, Syria, and according to Moscow, this is not about facts, but about fake news. Putin should be ashamed. Spreading fake news on social media is a propaganda tool with political purposes to confuse, create divisions in our society and influence our democratic elections. This makes good use of our open democratic societies. That is our strength, but at the same time also our weakness in effectively countering this kind of disruptive propaganda. The answer is not against propaganda. We must invest more in quality journalism and pay attention to this in education, so that the future generation is less prone to this form of political manipulation.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, social networks represent a revolution in human communication and a great gain for the global economy. Thanks to them, information spreads globally in a second, and companies reach their customers cheaper than ever before. But like any revolution, social media is often abused, and the latest trend of spreading fake news is actually the least worrying. Our priority must be to stop the growing trend of using social networks for serious crime such as pedophilia, prostitution, human trafficking, terrorist recruitment and similar illegal activities. Let’s not forget that even the mainstream media, consciously or unconsciously, often published inaccuracies, so any form of social media censorship would automatically introduce self-censorship into the media because they would be afraid to publish intriguing information. I am not in favor of restricting freedom of speech, but I am in favor of bearing full responsibility for malicious information that can cause psychological or material harm to people.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Madam President, we see how the social and digital media are becoming a powerful tool for propaganda, populism and hate speech. As such, it is nothing new, therefore we should not be tempted to limit the freedom of speech. Rather we must recognise the signs early and act responsibly but decisively to counter them. It is our common challenge. We can see that this information stems from a weak institutional and democratic environment, and simultaneously feeds into preserving the same defined milieu.  This phenomenon appears inside the EU but also outside our borders. I am observing its alarming prevalence in Ukraine, in Belarus but also in the Western Balkans. Unfortunately, it became a political tool of influence used by authoritarian regimes and governments. Various disinformation techniques are used to systematically undermine the values and policies which the EU strives to defend in these countries. We experience here campaigns and increased activities during elections with the aim to influence the result. These should be our last wake-up calls. We should invest more attention and resources in resilience of the media environment and information literacy in the EU, but also in our partner countries of the neighbourhood and our future members.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are discussing a very sensitive subject which concerns certain aspects, certain levels. The first are the conditions of freedom of expression, of access to information, of correctness of information and therefore of ethics and true responsibility in the age of social media, which must see a level playing field of responsibility among the entire media system. , and this is one aspect. But there is also that of the contents of hate speech or fake news, which are actually creating very dramatic impacts, not only on democracy: I am thinking of the organized intervention of real campaigns, even by foreign states, which alter choices democratic, but I am also thinking of forms of persecution: we think of cyberbullying, we think of the insane persecution for which many young people and women have committed suicide even in my country in recent times. And here it is not only a question, dear Commissioner Ansip, of seeing how the over-the-tops give themselves codes - it is very important - but, as we are also doing in the AVMS directive, we want them to be included in the directives of the Commission European Union, mechanisms to immediately remove such content and to make these media accountable.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: - Mr President, I myself have worked with the more than 30 years in politics and I am During the last few years, too often had to find that news, which is made of any conference or event is strongly colored according to its author's own political vision, which is often responsible media house owner's perspective . Often, these excesses occur just before an election to influence which party or candidate citizens should not vote under any circumstances. However, when such coverage exceeds a certain threshold, they turn against the intentions of their performer, as citizens themselves know how to think and make independent voting decisions. Before the election, there is often news of the upcoming election result for both parties and future elected candidates because of the desire for voters to move on to the winner’s sled. It is sad to say, but even the traditional media should sometimes look in the mirror when we discuss misinformation, propaganda and outright false news.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, in times like these contaminated by hate speech, by post-truth and by false news, as Albert Camus said, indifference can become criminal. Another French philosopher, André Glucksmann, wrote in his book Hate Speech that the first response has to be his exposure to ridicule. But in Europe we have learned that this is not enough. We have learned that it is necessary to transpose Framework Decision 2008/913 / JHA exactly to set the penal limits of a threat to democracy in which Europe risks everything. Now more is needed. It is necessary to find out how hate speech spreads, how it is financed, how to protect victims on the Internet and in the digital world and, of course, it is also necessary to know that naming things by their name is the beginning of rigor for prevent the banalization of evil from being the seed of fascism. Europe has a threat, it is called hate speech. And Europe must give an answer, an answer that contemplates the limits of compromise in the face of those who despise the different and humiliate the inferior.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: - Madam President! Fake news is a sin. “Disinformation is the greatest damage that the media can do, because opinion is steered in the wrong direction.” This sentence comes from Pope Francis. Disinformation can break even a strong country. We would do well to face this phenomenon of our digital world together and as one. Germany is one of the countries facing a major, important choice of direction this year. There, too, targeted disinformation and influence can be pursued from third countries. For me that means: Fake news has the power to destroy values ​​and kill human lives. We must oppose this. Furthermore, the fight against hate speech must not undermine freedom of expression. For the Amadeu Antonio Foundation, for example, hate speech begins with the we and your categories. Using man and woman as natural categories and bad satire. So let's be careful when evaluating hate speech. Some things don't have to be forbidden, some just have to be dealt with decisively in direct dialogue.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: - We rightly condemn hate speech.It is a fact that social media has largely become a gutter.However, I am afraid that filtering and removing hate speech and fake news from the internet will be very one-sided and will end up with selective political censorship.In this context, I would like to ask my colleagues whether such words thrown without reflection or knowledge as, for example, "populism", "populist", "nationalist", "putinization", "anti-Europeanness", the inflationary use of the term "fascism" or "fascists",is it hate speech or not?After all, such terms are most often not used for a factual analysis or characterization of views and actions.They are very often a club for hitting and discrediting inconvenient, politically hated competitors.Will they also be removed and filtered?

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, extremist fake news and hate speech are all closely connected. They challenge the values on which the EU is based. However, each requires a different policy response. The concept of free speech protects not only that which we agree with, but also that which is critical or disturbing. We need to address the spread of false information by improving media literacy and critical thinking, as well as by better communicating why democracy, the rule of law and the protection of minorities and fundamental rights are key interests for everyone. By contrast, illegal hate speech that incites violence or hatred based on race, ethnic or national origin, colour or religion is not protected by free speech. It is illegal. The Commission will continue to make sure that EU law is enforced in the online, as well as in the offline, world. In all these actions we have to bear in mind that it is our responsibility to protect fundamental rights and freedom of expression in the European Union. We have to believe in the common sense of our people. Once again, fake news is bad, but the Ministry of Truth is even worse. It was said more than a century ago that you can fool all the people some of the time and you can fool some of the people all the time, but you cannot fool all the people all the time; but it is still valid today.

Jiena konvint li kemm bħala Kunsill; Anki bħala Presidenza, kif għedt: l-inizjattivi u l-avvenimenti li għandna matul dan is-semestru fuq dan is-suġġett u kif nistgħu ngħinu, kif ukoll anki l-Istati Membri, se jkunu qegħdin jagtutu l-piż xieraq lill In the case of the Chamber and the Chamber of the United States of America, the Community has been notified of the action taken.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - While Europe is undergoing an unprecedented crisis: 20 million unemployed, growing precariousness, austerity, mass immigration and above all Islamic terrorism, the EU finds nothing better to do than to fight against alleged hate speech or populists. Populism comes from the Latin "populus" which means the people, what is bothering this EU? Is it against the defense of peoples' interests? Everywhere the “fakenews” of the media and the policies in place to scare the people no longer work. We have seen it in the United Kingdom, the United States, Italy and Hungary. It is clear that citizens no longer want to be fooled by illusions and that your answers are nothing democratic! Orwell's big brother couldn't have dreamed of better! Social media is a formidable tool (even if you have to be careful) of reinformation and struggles against your unique thought. Being against terrorism does not mean being Islamophobic, being against marriage for all does not mean being homophobic and fighting mass immigration does not mean being racist! I say stop to self-righteousness and yes to the truth!

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written.- In times like these contaminated by hate speech, by post-truth and by false news, indifference can become criminal.It is necessary that the Framework Decision 2008/913 / JHA be transposed correctly so that it unfolds all its effects and helps to establish the penal limits of a threat against democracy in which Europe risks everything.In addition, it is necessary to find out how hate speech spreads, how it is financed, protect victims on the Internet and in the digital world and, of course, it is also necessary to know that naming things by their name is the beginning of rigorto prevent the banalization of evil from being the seed of fascism.Europe has a threat, it is called hate speech.And Europe must give an answer, an answer that contemplates the limits of compromise in the face of those who despise the different and humiliate the inferior.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. - The circulation of false news on the net - the so-called "fake news" - is today a problem that must be tackled as soon as possible on a supranational scale and effectively. The Internet represents an extraordinary source of information which, however, can turn into a dangerous instrument of artificial manipulation of reality with the aim of weakening and dissipating the consensus around the fundamental values ​​on which the European Union is founded. The right and necessary freedom to provide information through the network has in fact highlighted the need for clear regulation that provides greater certainty about the legal responsibilities of those who, through the amplifying power of social media, leverage the creation and dissemination of slander. , lies and incitement to racial and institutional hatred to generate income, regardless of the devastating social effects that such activities entail. Since the network has no borders or barriers, the issue can only be effectively addressed at the international level. I therefore welcome the discussion that opened today in Parliament on the subject and I hope that this reflection will also involve the other EU institutions as soon as possible in order to arrive at prompt, concrete and effective answers.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. - An entire old information society that is easily controlled and enslaved by political and economic power is increasingly in crisis. Hate speech and fake news do not arise with the advent of the Internet and social media, they do not manifest themselves exclusively through these channels. Information that has distorted reality, disseminated by the traditional media, and which has served to justify wars and maneuvers by certain power groups is recurrent in contemporary societies. The risk of a form of censorship of alternative information channels behind the demands for excessive Internet regulation is evident. Speeches full of hate and false news have easy ground in all those situations where we see a lack of transparency, where there is a lack of democratic control. Just think of the decision-making processes that occur in ways unknown to most people by bodies not elected by anyone. Citizens have the right to know the truth and have their freedom of expression protected. What they need are not gags, but policies that know how to offer them tools of knowledge, that are able to fill educational gaps and economic disparities, in order to feel informed, aware and fully free.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: written. - Of course, we politicians know exactly what hate speech can cause on the Internet. Each of us will have seen it before. But that's nothing against what teenagers or even adult women have to endure. In this way, social media quickly turns into anti-social media - which in the worst cases can also lead to people putting an end to their lives because of the attacks on them. For this reason alone, we have to be particularly attentive here - with all due caution - and consider measures. So-called fake news represent a similar socio-political problem. While this type of journalism played a major role in the last election campaign in the USA and attracted the attention of the established media, this phenomenon is also becoming more common in the EU . An additional danger is that outside players are increasingly using these lies to drive a wedge between European social classes. More and more people trust the Internet when they consume news - and that now also includes fake news. That is why we have to raise awareness across Europe and start providing information quickly.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: written.- Europe has a threat before it, and it is called hate speech.A response from Europe is necessary, it must consider the limits of tolerance towards those who despise the different and humiliate the inferior.It is necessary to discover the way in which hate speech spreads, how it is financed, as well as to protect the victims on the net and in the digital world.In times like these, tainted by hate speech, post-truth and fake news, indifference can turn out to be criminal.It is necessary for Framework Decision 2008/913 / JHA to be transposed correctly so that it deploys all its effects and contributes to establishing the penal limits of a threat against democracy, in which Europe risks everything.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. - It is estimated that there are 3.4 billion Internet users. This means that fake news can reach 3.5 billion people with just one click. For news, traveling the world on the Internet is easy: some sharing and here is news like "The Pope supports Donald Trump" bounces everywhere, from one continent to another. It goes without saying that the denials never reach the same diffusion as the primary news. False information is now a consolidated phenomenon even ridden and exploited by those who do business with clicks and advertising, certainly all this must be countered by making the online platforms that publish the news responsible. News that from time to time, from lies to lies, condition civil society, electoral choices, the formation of public opinion and social balance. Fake news are accurate and scientific constructions of those who often have a specific political design. It is not easy, regulating the web is controversial, difficult. In addition to the legislation, necessary to punish those who spread false news, we need to fight fake news on their own field, with real and truthful news, with a militancy of truth. With simple and effective information that opposes the instrumentality of populism, the force of reason against the force of falsehood.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: written.- In times like these, contaminated by hate speech, post-truth and fake news, indifference can become criminal.It is necessary that the Framework Decision 2008/913 / JHA be transposed correctly so that it unfolds all its effects and helps to establish the penal limits of a threat against democracy in which Europe risks everything.In addition, it is necessary to find out how hate speech spreads, how it is financed, protect victims on the Internet and in the digital world and, of course, it is also necessary to know that naming things by their name is the beginning of rigorto prevent the banalization of evil from being the seed of fascism.Europe has a threat, it is called hate speech.And Europe must give an answer, an answer that contemplates the limits of compromise in the face of those who despise the different and humiliate the inferior.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: in writing. - Populist rhetoric, hate speech and false information disseminated primarily via social media is a growing problem that we cannot ignore. In the world of the ubiquitous Internet, the circulation of information has not only accelerated, but has also become significantly democratized: almost anyone can, most often remaining anonymous, release information to the network available to hundreds or tens of millions of citizens. We also already have more and more evidence that such actions are aimed at causing specific political consequences: destabilizing existing governments or influencing the election results. Therefore, I am glad that the first steps to combat this phenomenon have already been taken, such as the East StratCom task force, whose activities include fight against false information. During almost a year and a half of its operation, it managed to disclose over 2.5 thousand such cases, which on the one hand proves its effectiveness, and on the other shows the enormous scale of this phenomenon. In view of the seriousness of this problem, I believe that one should consider both strengthening this group and other intensive actions aimed at counteracting hate speech and populism.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- The Internet can be a very useful tool for exercising freedom of expression, although it is necessary to take into account the harmful purposes it may have.Freedom of speech is one of the fundamental rules of the European Union, but increasingly false profiles on social networks indicate that they are used to spread hate speech, fake news, recruitment and propaganda, thus violating fundamental human rights.Extremism is increasingly present on social networks, and in addition, some Member States are introducing special laws to prevent this.Clearly, clear guidelines are needed to take effective measures to limit the spread of hate speech and false news.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: written. - Under the name of hate speech, article 510 of the Spanish Penal Code incorporates a catalog of all-embracing behaviors that punishes with imprisonment from one to four years. Criminal types such as the one I have just cited are the result that the legislator achieves when he is thinking exclusively of punishing and does not strictly respect the terms and concepts established in the DM2008 / 913 / JAI. Today, public opinion is almost inevitable as a consequence of the social media revolution. But what speeches are susceptible to crime? The trend in international law and the ECHR is not to condemn expressions of hate except when they contribute directly to discrimination or violence. That is, the restrictive interpretation is advocated. This shows that Member States do not always comply with European standards and create hate crimes that symbolize contempt for freedom of expression, belief and ideology, which must not be forgotten, are fundamental rights. It's good to use the law as a mixed bag. The European Union and the European Parliament have to ensure that hate speech is only subject to criminal prosecution when it actually creates a potential danger of discriminatory or violent acts.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: in writing. - Hate speech is a very serious, but unfortunately often underestimated problem that may have serious consequences for the social order, increasing aggression, violence and conflicts.
