We are currently seeing a worrying increase in this phenomenon on the Internet, social media and political discourse. Hate speech is mainly born of ignorance, prejudice, or lack of respect and tolerance for otherness. Education is the only long-term and effective tool to combat these phenomena. Education makes it possible to recognize propaganda and hate speech, fight them and prevent them. From developing critical thinking skills, to developing discussion, communication and tolerance skills, education enables safe and responsible use of the Internet and media in communities. Therefore, it is important that educational programs targeting people of all ages and backgrounds address media literacy and critical thinking skills. These issues should also be mainstreamed into the new skills agenda for Europe. It is also crucial to intensify efforts, in cooperation with the Council of Europe, to promote education at all levels in the fight against hate speech and to organize social campaigns to combat racism and xenophobia online. I also stress our huge role as politicians in defending society against hate speech and protecting its rights by raising awareness of human rights, promoting respect for freedom of expression and political culture.

name: Ramona Nicole MĂNESCU
text: in writing. – Fake news or, as it likes to call itself, ‘alternative news’, is not news. Yet today the scale of this phenomenon is astounding. How does it sustain itself? Let’s follow the money! Journalists found fake news websites, fake products, promoted by fake photos, fake names and fake statements and advertising agencies. All of them getting real money from gullible readers and buyers and all connected through ownership. We are talking about a huge audience and a system that produces countless financial resources. Underneath there is a whole machinery which goes much deeper than just a room with internet trolls, somewhere in Moscow. Are we worried? Apparently some of us are not. Someone asked here today: ‘who can have the authority to say what is true and what is false’. This gives credit to something that is both junk and malicious. Later I heard ‘who has the right to remove or censor the information’. A piece of junk becomes ‘information’ and later ‘freedom of speech and opinion’. That is both irresponsible and dangerous. The EU must build, as soon as possible, an institutional and legal framework capable to create the specific antibodies needed to protect European citizens from this disease.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – The liberal value system prevailing in Western Europe since the end of World War II has created a tolerant, open society that allows diversity, freedom of thought and speech and respect for human rights to flourish among us. However, if not in crisis, this value system is straining to cope with the ethical and social tensions generated, inter alia, by technological innovation, especially in the communications field, intercultural disparities within societies, immigration, terrorism and rising social inequalities. In responding to these tensions, we need to update the expression of our values to make them consistent with the times, while enhancing Europe’s tolerant and liberal profile. For instance, when does the right to offend, which we recognise, become equivalent to hate speech? Under what conditions does the full observance of traditional religious customs contradict liberal practices? What justification can be advanced for rigid surveillance of internet traffic, including its ‘censorship’ in order to combat, say, ‘fake news’? To what extent should an individual’s right to privacy prevail over surveillance measures intended to address concerns about internet and other criminal activity, such as tax fraud and hate speech? We do not have clear-cut, satisfactory replies to such questions.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - Hate speech, populism and false news are three phenomena that have seen a worrying increase in recent years. EU citizens are increasingly exposed to misinformation and propaganda campaigns, and as we have already seen in the case of Brexit, they seem to be working. This should worry us and take a firm stand against those who intentionally misinform. Given that we are approaching two very important elections in France and Germany, it is important to remain vigilant and not allow debates to be diverted by people and organizations that rely on hatred and fear to win. We must drastically punish hate speech, including anti-Semitism and anti-Islamism, but also false news. At the same time, in order to prevent the spread of false information, I support the strengthening of media institutions so that they are objective, impartial and independent. I support investment in all Member States to raise awareness and education, including the use of digital platforms. This would allow citizens to critically analyze the content of the media and the information they access on the internet, contributing to personal, national and European security.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – Although the Soviet Union collapsed at the beginning of the 1990s, the Russian Federation acclaimed itself as its legal successor, and the former Soviet intelligence mechanism known as the KGB went through a metamorphosis and took control of the state with Vladimir Putin coming to power in 2000. The Putin regime understood that the same tricks used by the KGB during the Cold War could be used in a modern context. The combination of hate speech, populism and fake news, with the aid of social media, was a perfect way to gain political leverage over the EU, NATO, and the Western World. It is time for us, collectively, to take back the steering wheel. The truth will always prevail.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: signed up. - In the 'post-truth' era, as some have summed up the historical moment we are experiencing due to the use of the internet, it is becoming a priority for the EU to combat false news, so-called alternative sources of information and the avalanche of propaganda. Usually, information chaos and media intoxication work for the benefit of extremist, anti-European forces, hostile to the European Union's integrative and pacifist project. Social media is the main source of information for a third of young Europeans. Therefore, illegal online content, fake news and hate speech must be firmly and effectively combated. Human, technical and financial resources appropriate to the size of the challenge are needed. And in this regard, I draw attention to two major crises exacerbated by new technologies: the recruitment of jihadists and the coordination of terrorist attacks by the Islamic State, and the information war launched by Russia against the EU. Combating hostile propaganda and properly informing citizens are strategic obligations in this hostile context.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing - On Wednesday afternoon, there was a debate in plenary on hate speech, populism and false reports. I consider it good and important for Members of all political groups to discuss these topics, because populism and lies, combined with new technologies and services such as the Internet, social networks or the ability to collect and evaluate large amounts of information about everyone who uses the Internet, can pose a threat to democracy and freedom in certain circumstances. On the other hand, we must not allow the line between suppressing hate speech and restricting freedom of thought, conscience and religion to be blurred. Some of these problems, now facing citizens of all Member States, can be solved by law, but by no means all. For example, countries with quality education are proving to be much more resistant to false reports and misinformation. But the quality of education cannot be changed from day to day or from year to year. Parliament will not adopt a resolution on this subject. However, the speeches of MEPs from the various factions will be an interesting signal as to whether there is a consensus in response to these topics or whether we are still at the stage of analyzing problems and proposing solutions, some complementing each other while others competing with each other.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: in writing. - The crisis in the eurozone has revealed deep structural inequalities in the Union, a sense of a win-win and a failed globalization process that has led to an increase in euroscepticism among voters and has enabled populist parties to gain power in many European countries. Populists question the foundations of democracy, including by attempts to weaken the independence of the judiciary and the independence of the media, often also by creating artificial divisions in society based on the dichotomy of "us" against "them". In addition, we observe attempts to influence the situation in Europe from the outside by spreading disinformation, which may be part of a hybrid war. Populism inside the EU and disinformation from outside are two complex phenomena which, however, are closely related. They use similar manipulation techniques, and therefore we need to consider preventive measures together. The response from the EU to disinformation, also used by populists, can only be impartial, reliable and objective communication and information flow based on reliable facts. In order to provide EU citizens with access to such information, it is first of all necessary to strengthen the pluralism and independence of the media in the European Union and its neighborhood. A complementary element is education at all levels, which provides the necessary knowledge and skills to critically analyze media content and respond to disinformation.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the report by Miapetra Kumpala-Natri, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the regulation(EU) nº531 / 2012 regarding the rules applicable to wholesale roaming markets (COM (2016) 0399 - C8-0219 / 2016 - 2016/0185 (COD)) (A8-0372 / 2016).

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: rapporteur. – Madam Chairman, a long-standing priority will now finally become a reality. On 15 June, roaming surcharges will be a thing of the past for European citizens travelling in the European Union. Europeans will no longer face huge phone bill shocks after travelling in another EU country. In June, Europeans can use their phones just like at home without paying extra. Before, Europeans used to switch off when they crossed a border. This summer, Europeans will be able to call their friends from the beach, tweet from the work conference, or check emails and social media from Lisbon to Latvia, from Dublin to Dubrovnik, without fear of surcharges.  Often we are asked what is the benefit of the European Union, and what is the significance of the internal market, for citizens? We are and we will be reminded of the roaming surcharges when leaving the internal market when travelling outside EU borders. I will give you a concrete example: I checked many European operators, big and small, on the prices for data roaming when travelling to Croatia and to Serbia – neighbouring countries. Travelling to Croatia, a Member State of the EU, applying the rules of the internal market, the cost of using one gigabyte abroad after 15 June will be no extra cost on my tariff plan as it is included in my tariff plan at home. When travelling to Serbia, a neighbouring country but outside the EU, how much do you think that one gigabyte would cost? Make a guess! The bill sent to me would be thousands of euros for using that one gigabyte! What is the reason for this? It is that operators in visited countries, and visiting operators, can both charge much more than needed from the consumer without regulation of the internal market that has now been created over the decade by reducing roaming costs within the EU.  Tomorrow we will vote on the last piece of legislation to make ‘roam-like-at-home’ a reality. It sets a price cap for what operators can charge each other when their consumers travel. The European Parliament defended the interests of the citizens, competitive markets and small operators. As a rapporteur, I am proud of this result. I am proud of what we can achieve together. Together we have reached a dramatic drop in the prices from the original proposal by the Commission. The most important was the price on the data caps. The lower data price cap benefits European citizens directly. The lower the price on data, the more data Europeans can use when they travel.  Mobile data plays a key role in today’s digital society. The use of data is growing rapidly. Data will play an even more important role in the future. Today, Europeans use mobiles everywhere; opportunities are unlimited. Already today, mobiles are used for many services. We follow news online, order bus tickets, make restaurant reservations, use maps, look for tourist attractions, play mobile games and we can stay connected with our colleagues online. All the time we can do more and more on our mobile services using mobile data. The services must not stop at the internal borders of the European Union. The end of roaming surcharges contributes to the freedom of European citizens; it contributes to the development of the internal market, connectivity and the use of electronic services wherever Europeans travel in the EU. I want to thank shadow rapporteurs representing all parliamentary political groups, the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, all of you my colleagues, the Commission and the Council for supporting this achievement.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, the Commission warmly welcomes the political agreement achieved by the co-legislators at the end of January. It is a great achievement that will have an immediate positive impact on the lives of millions of Europeans from 15 June this year. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Ms Miapetra Kumpula-Natri, and all honourable Members of Parliament who were involved in this work.  This is the result of more than 10 years of regulatory effort by the EU institutions. During this time, several of you played key roles in reducing roaming prices in the European Union from extremely high levels. Two years ago, Ms Pilar del Castillo led critical negotiations from which the decision emerged for full abolition of roaming charges while travelling in the European Union. Several additional steps had to be taken for this to become a reality. The main step was to reduce wholesale roaming prices. Without this, many operators would not have been able to eliminate roaming charges without increasing their domestic prices. This was technically complicated and involved finding an adequate political balance. The new caps on wholesale roaming prices agreed with the Council – and on which you will vote tomorrow – will allow operators to provide roaming at the domestic price. At the same time, they will ensure that the networks visited can recover their wholesale costs. In addition, as you know, the Commission delivered the implementing regulation on fair use policy in time last year on 15 December, after a lively debate with stakeholders, Member States and Members of this House. Thanks to all our efforts together, the ‘roam-like-at-home’ system is now fully designed and predictable. We have shown people across Europe that the EU institutions can deliver, also in difficult times. The widespread positive media reaction reflects that. With this deal, we should not forget that we have achieved a much more vibrant Digital Single Market. It brings many new possibilities that will benefit all of us, if they are used properly. The Commission therefore strongly urges the European Parliament to adopt the new regulation on wholesale roaming markets.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! Thank you very much. I would especially like to congratulate the Commission on the proposal. Today we are celebrating the tenth anniversary of the roaming regulation. A student from Linz brought me a complaint and we've been negotiating roaming ever since. We have always set ourselves three years, a sunset clause that will enable us to now bring the roaming 4 period to an end. In truth, we are already preparing the fifth round for the digital single market. And ten years means: We have a child who is ten years old and who now understands a little what the digital single market should look like. We have now achieved that there is at least competition within the Member States and that our citizens can finally go on vacation, our small and medium-sized enterprises can finally go on business trips within the European Union and pay the same tariff here as they do at home. So you no longer have to have two phones and two SIM cards when traveling within the European Union: of course it is still very dangerous outside the European Union. The tariffs for one gigabyte go up to 19,900 euros, whereas today we have an average price of 2.77 euros in the European Union. And we won't be ready until 2022 that this wholesale cap of 2.50 euros is below today's average price. So we are not setting prices here, we are only defining where fraud begins, and I think that is the right thing to do, so that the citizens can rely on us. Of course, we have also ensured that there will be no increase in the national tariffs, that competition can take place at the national level and - this is the most important thing - that investment will continue to be made in the future. We urgently need the fiber rollout, we urgently need 5G, with it an equal technological basis is created compared to Wi-Fi and a real digital single market can emerge.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to congratulate my colleague, Miapetra Kumpula-Natri, and the Maltese Presidency for reaching an agreement on the wholesale roaming markets. The rules agreed were significantly lower caps, designed to allow mobile phone operators to offer free roaming to their customers without increasing domestic prices at home. The caps will also have a direct impact on how much mobile data a consumer can use when abroad. The lower the cap, the larger the amount of data. This was the last stumbling block standing in the way of ending roaming charges as of 15 June of this year. This was the last, but definitely not the least. The pieces of the puzzle leading to meet the 15 June deadline to abolish roaming charges are now all in place. In two months, people travelling across Europe will pay no more extra costs for using their phones. Soon, roaming charges will be a thing of the past, and people will not even remember their existence. It is satisfying indeed that Europe has managed to deliver on its promise to abolish roaming charges. This is the end of a very long battle for the Parliament, which started almost six years ago, a battle which was faced with a lot of opposition from different sides. This is why it is an honour for me to have been part of this battle and, in particular, part of the S&D team, who not only started it but followed it right through to the very end, until today’s success story. However, for me, the fight is not over. and now it is time to push for the next step: to make intra—EU calls non-discriminatory with the same prices for domestic and cross-border calls and SMS, so that consumers will be able to do business and speak with friends and colleagues living in another country without worrying about excessive bills at the end of each month.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: for the ECR Group. - Madam President, although I am not in favor of major European regulations, unfortunately, in the case of roaming, this administrative intervention has proved necessary. The market in these cross-border telecommunications services has not been able to find reasonable parameters for a long time. I believe that the introduction of the roam-like-at-home principle and reasonable prices, especially for data services, will not only benefit citizens, but will help the development of the digital economy as a whole. I would like to commend the great work done by Miapetra Kumpula-Natri as rapporteur and the whole team of shadow rapporteurs, my colleagues, and I am very honored to have been able to take part in this work. And I am glad that, after many hours of negotiations, we have been able to find a solution with the Council on wholesale data ceilings that will allow roaming to end. I think that the compromise found is, in the end, a sensible solution. As the volumes of data transferred increase in the coming years, the maximum price caps may fall significantly. But we should also educate our citizens, and I would expect the Commission to take an active approach in this regard to the restrictions associated with the so-called fair use policy. Congratulations once again to the rapporteur on her excellent work.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: for the ALDE Group. - Madam President! To begin with, I would like to congratulate Mia-Petra Kumpula and all her colleagues, regardless of political color. We are now many, including ALDE, who would like to take the opportunity to say that this was our idea, but it would not have been possible to implement it if the Commission had not been a part of it, and if it had not been for all political groups in fact wanted to take these steps. What is also important in this process is to see that the debate that has been going on all the time has also affected the market. We can see at home in Sweden how large telecom operators are already starting to get rid of roaming charges, so that before the legislation is even in place, big things are starting to happen in the European market. This can also be a good foundation for much that we need to continue to do. In one of my first debates in this House, they wanted to break Google's monopoly position. To me, it was so surprising that no one in the House asked why we do not have a European-based Google. The answer for me there is quite obvious: we have not been able to create a common market where there is competition and where there is growth opportunity for digitally based companies and telecom companies to a sufficient extent. Several telecommunications companies have been able to make a lot of money by reducing roaming charges, but here we have said that it is important that European citizens have the opportunity to move across borders to work, move across borders to travel and visit other parts of Europe. , without coming home and having to spend the entire next monthly salary on paying bills. This of course creates new digital opportunities, but the work is not finished. We must ensure that we go further with the digital agenda for the whole of Europe. We see a lot of competition today from the USA. Asia is around the corner. India will not wait for Europe to have a single market before taking action. This is a first step on the road - many important parts remain - and of course we must also follow the implementation process to see that it becomes serious and good.

name: João FERREIRA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, in October 2015, when we discussed the European single market for electronic communications here, we recalled the alerts made by several national regulatory authorities, according to which, in view of the dominant tourist flows in Europe, the countries of the south would be harmed by the end of roaming charges in the European Union. We then warned that there was still no convincing response to these alerts. A year and a half later we continued. Without a convincing answer, without the certainty that consumers in the southern countries will not pay the costs of ending roaming in the European Union in their domestic tariffs. We intervened in this process with a clear objective: to enable the end of roaming surcharges at the retail level, that is, the end of roaming charges for consumers in the European Union, while eliminating, at the same time, the risk of costs resulting from roaming. , namely the costs resulting from increased seasonal pressure on national networks are passed on to national domestic tariffs. From our point of view, there were and are more effective ways of ensuring this than the provisions that were adopted. But it was the option, both of the Commission and of the rapporteur, not to consider them in this regulation. The logic of liberalization and the miraculous free competition underlying the single communications market, in this as in other sectors, I conclude, serves the interests of large economic groups and monopoly concentration on a European scale. It serves neither consumer interests nor national interest.

name: Michel REIMON
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! I too would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs and also the Commission. The negotiations were very good and very constructive. We can be so far satisfied with the result, even if the parliamentary side would have liked to have wanted even more and we as Members of the House would have wanted our citizens to stop roaming this summer, or at least as soon as possible, and to get in move all of Europe like at home. That would actually have been our political goal. The previous agenda item was about fake news, populism and so on on the internet and social media, it was about the negative side of this phenomenon. But we must be clear that we are talking about the new public sphere of democracy when we are talking about digital media, when we are talking about being online and that this is first and foremost a question of democracy and only secondly a question of Market - at least that's how we should see it in politics. I would also like to point out: there is so much criticism of the European Union and its over-regulation and whether it has to interfere in everything. This is an example that we should proudly use to point out what positive effects European regulation can do. We need to point out that the market has failed and failed miserably in this area for decades. Why? Because a consumer can only make a purchase decision if he or she is firstly informed and secondly has a choice and a choice. But nobody signs a telephone contract because maybe three years later, four years later, they are going to Serbia on vacation. When he gets there, he - colleague Kumpula-Natri gave the example - suddenly has to pay 1,000 euros per gigabyte with his contract because he doesn't have any Buying decision has more about it.A market cannot function like that.That is why regulation works in this area.That is why regulation in this area is necessary, good and democratically correct.You can see the difference between an internal market and a free trade area here quite well.If we agree on common legislation, if we jointly ensure that we get the best out of the consumer, then this European Union has more than just a right to exist, and I believe that is an example that we should blow out as loudly as possible.

name: David BORRELLI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, from 15 June the telephone companies will abolish the cost of roaming. It will be possible for all European citizens to surf and make calls throughout Europe at the same rate at home. Great, it looks like a commercial. Because what escapes us is precisely the attention to the national tariff. Because the risk is that the telephone company can somehow compensate for the lost revenue from roaming by increasing some specific service at a national level, a service that then affects all citizens, even those who may never set foot abroad. Why is this? Because the tariffs for wholesale services are still too high, and certainly not the fault of this Parliament which, thanks to our amendment, had even halved them. It is the Council that has doubled them, not Parliament. It is the Council that has doubled them, choosing once again to be on the side of the strongest, that is, of large mobile telephone companies, penalizing small entrepreneurs and all citizens. So on this, President, let me be very clear: the abolition of roaming is welcome, as long as it does not turn into a hoax, with increases at national level for all citizens.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we promise Europeans virtually free roaming. Unfortunately, in economics, nothing is really free. Everything has a price. We will give this initiative a chance. Nevertheless, is there not a risk? On the one hand, the increase in national tariffs to compensate for the losses recorded in roaming. Does the poor who do not travel pay for the rich who travel? Is it for those excluded from globalization, who live in poverty and precariousness, to pay for those who benefit from it, who are lucky enough to be able to be connected to the world? In France, only 40% of the population benefits from globalization. The second risk is the decline in network investments when we have to prepare for 5G and fiber optics. Finally, the decrease in spending on research and development when we are already left behind from the rest of the world.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Madam President, the proposed abolition of roaming charges for mobile phone users has become an icon of how slow and cumbersome the European Union has become in its ability to make decisions. This agreement has taken 10 years. In part, progress has been made, but the fact that the telecommunications industry has such huge lobbying power in Brussels has acted as a drag anchor on the progress that could have been made. What brings down prices is rarely legislation. That is why light-touch legislation around the world is so much more effective. What brings change is competition. If the European Union had allowed for a truly free and competitive market then the charges would have been zeroed probably decades ago. As ever, the EU has drummed up regulations, and we have heard already from a number of previous speakers that all will happen is that income revenue for the companies will then be derived from charging domestic customers much, much more. This is hardly fair, it is hardly equitable. I think this ought to go back for review again by the committee to try to look at a more lighter-touch approach and one that is speedier in terms of delivery. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: blue-card question. – Besides the fact that you think it has taken far too long and you think it is bad, but also good, how would you like to say that we could have achieved this without the European Union? Because without the European Union we would not have a Union and you would not have a European system. So please explain for us all how things could have been faster without the European Union and how this could have been achieved without the European Union. I think this is a tremendous occasion to tell us all.

name: Diane JAMES
text: blue-card answer. – I do not think that you listened to the whole of my speech. The point that I made was that the lobbying power in Brussels, which is actively encourage, actively interacted with by the European Union, has proved to be a drag anchor. That was the critical point that I was making. I was also making the point that, across the world, a lighter touch in terms of regulation, one that does not involve trilogue: Council, Commission to the Parliament and then back all the way round things, would not have achieved where we are. The point I am making, therefore, is let us just put together three components: stop the lobbying, stop the drag anchor and stop the trilogue.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: - Mr President. Colleagues! I ask the question, "Which of us can do on our own?" There are people who, say, live in rural areas, who may take care of their own food, grow it. They say, "Well, I can do it myself!" But then the question has to be asked: “How do you dress then? Do you shop at the store? ” No, it is also theoretically possible for someone else in Europe to sew all their own clothes. But sooner or later that person will have to buy either a sewing needle, or a thread, or a plow, or something else. He will be partly dependent on others. And we call this system trade. And in Europe, the advantage of our giants, and the greatest advantage of the European Union in particular, is that this trade takes place between 500 000 000 people without internal borders, without tariffs, without customs duties, virtually without problems. This is the European Union's greatest asset to most of our citizens. But there is one area that is absolutely missing. That's when we go with these devices, which almost everyone, even school children today, have in their pockets - with mobile phones - outside our country. Suddenly, it seems that the single market no longer exists. We pay much, much more expensive. Now this bill, which we will be voting on tomorrow - on wholesale prices - will put an end to the 'i' and destroy so-called roaming, which, by distorting the single market, makes us pay much more abroad. And we will be able to use the telephone abroad and pay at home, completing the internal single market. We do not live alone, we need a common European market, including a digital market. Thanks! (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: question with blue card. - I think it is difficult to defend the view that roaming charges should not be reduced. But there are arguments that are logical and say that companies are very likely or absolutely certain that they will pass on their losses to local consumers and, given that only 30% or 20% or 40% of people from different countries move to other countries, this will be to the detriment of some others. I just want my colleague to answer that question. Madam President, because I have asked to speak during the 'catch the eye' procedure, please remove my name from the list, as I have now spoken.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: answer to the blue card question.- This is where the salt comes from in this legislation: we are imposing wholesale price caps on this legislation, which means that if there are operators who would like to make domestic people pay more, they will have no such excuse.The second is competition.I do not know how in your Member State, but there is very fierce competition in my Member State.If one of our operators suddenly increases its prices, the other operators will take its customers by lowering their prices.It is in Latvia that we currently have one of the most advantageous, e.g.i.e. the lowest tariffs across Europe - it already offers a single price across Europe and is lower than most countries even domestically.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I want to thank my colleague Kumpula-Natri who worked with you for this result, which is certainly only the first step, as the Commissioner said in some interviews, but it is certainly a very important step. We have worked on it for many years, Pilar del Castillo, Catherine Trautmann, whom I want to remember here in this House for the work I have done, myself, on the Single Telecom Market and so on, to arrive at this coveted like-at-home rate. However, this good result - we heard it even before, in this House, in an intervention by the 5 Star Movement - is downplayed, and it is said: "Why, there is the like at home but then they will raise the home, they will find tricks ... ". Here, these colleagues who even in the Italian press have minimized this result forget that we have placed safeguards and cautions in that provision and in the previous ones. There will be control, in addition to competition, dear colleague Kariņš, and I really ask the Commission, BEREC and the national authorities to be very vigilant and attentive, because we have done it seriously, this revision of the wholesale market, to arrive at the result of the abolition of roaming, and we will not allow games, nor will we allow anyone to debase this provision, as if it were not needed. I want to take the opportunity to say a second thing to the Commissioner. Step forward: we must show that we are serious, without uncertainty, not one step forward and one step back. This is a road traced that must go all the way, otherwise this institution will lose its credibility. In this regard, last week some doubts arose: the BEREC guidelines came out which gave some cause, some unclear interpretation on the fair use clause. Fortunately, the Commission intervened promptly to clarify matters. Here, Mr. Commissioner, I ask you, Mr. Vice President, that with Parliament's support should be vigilant so that no one steps away from this path that has been traced, which will also rightly look at the financial results, at the keeping of the corporate balance sheet, but substantially look at the citizens with a gesture and a choice that was very symbolic, because thisit is something symbolic of Europe's action for the interests of citizens and for the unity of European citizens.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: - Mr President, it is good that the wholesale roaming market in Europe will have a price cap next summer.However, the presentation is problematic.In Finland, it means rising prices.At the same time, it is a transfer of income to operators with a large number of travelers to their territory.If the price of mobile data transmission rises, the proposal will have an impact on data flow and other economic activities.Concerns have also been raised that there will be income transfers from low-travel and low-income citizens to those who can afford to travel a lot abroad.Irish operators have already identified a loophole in the proposal where they can continue to charge a significant additional price for data in the EU.Despite assurances from the Irish authorities, at least The Independent thinks the authority has little power to change this.It will be interesting to see if operators in other countries find similar loopholes.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Madam President, at long last this final piece of the long awaited end of roaming charges puzzle is concluded. This is a very important decision and conclusion for all Europeans. I am very glad that we, as Liberals, we, as the European Parliament, we, as European lawmakers have pushed very hard to put consumers and the public interest first; to lay a good foundation through the telecom single market for an ambitious digital single market that puts people first. I would strongly encourage telecom providers to keep that in mind. Put consumers/people first.  We will keep the pulse and we will have a review after two/two and a half years. I will say that I too prefer light-touch regulation but if it is necessary we will make sure that the market works well, that it is fit for the 21st century and that we ensure that there is no abuse of the market position by telecom operators or other companies. I think this is an important step and I am glad we can conclude it with our vote.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: - Madam President, we certainly support the abolition of roaming charges, as this will relieve consumers financially. It is clear to us that telecommunications and the Internet are public social goods, to which we must all have equal access. However, the proposal before us involves many risks. Initially, it does not include any provision for restoring the imbalance that will be created due to the different number of tourists that each country receives. Thus, the countries of the South, which receive the largest waves of tourists, will be burdened with a huge cost that will have to be paid by domestic providers. Then there is no guarantee that in the end the locals will not pay the cost. On the contrary, it is certain that in order for domestic providers to survive, they will pass on costs to consumers, increasing domestic charges. Countries with a small market, such as Cyprus, will be particularly hard hit. The costs that local companies will have to pay in the summer months will be unbearable, with unforeseen consequences. That is why I am not going to support a proposal that will fully serve the interests of large multinational companies. (The speaker agreed to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: blue-card question. – There has been a lot of talking. Mr Sykliotis, as a former Minister from Cyprus, may I ask you a question? You are not supporting this result in the end. How then would you regulate markets – which, in this case, I think should be the only solution – if we were to allow visiting operators and visited operators – both sides – to charge consumers more than is necessary? Nowadays you can even have to pay EUR 10 000 for one gigabyte when travelling because, if the regulators are not regulated, they can both charge the consumer too much. What is your solution?

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: answer to a question with a blue card. - As I said, we consider this element important, but a fund must be created to support small countries, such as my country, and small producers in these countries, which will collapse under this system. Especially in Cyprus, the public company and the small companies will not be able to bear this unbearable burden. They will either pass it on to domestic providers or collapse as companies. That is why we are calling for a balance, that is, a provision to support small countries.

name: Roger HELMER
text: – Madam President, once again the European Union is abandoning free markets in favour of central planning. First we regulate retail prices, now we come back and regulate wholesale prices. Will we never learn that regulatory intervention in market prices almost always produces unintended and perverse consequences? Think of the empty shelves in the Moscow Gum department store when they tried to regulate prices. Look at the ETS scheme in Europe that has failed for 10 years to deliver the sort of prices that the regulators want. Several other speakers, including my group colleague Mr Borrelli, have remarked that operators will recover their lost revenue elsewhere, which will have a regressive effect. It is the European Union’s cynical pursuit of any measure that looks vaguely like a benefit for voters or of generating any positive headline. Be sure, this proposal that we are voting on today or tomorrow, will have unintended consequences which will come back and bite our ankles.

name: Georg MAYER
text: - Madam President! As a trained consumer advocate, I am of course pleased that we can make such a significant improvement for people. It is also due to the provider tariffs, and whoever has plowed through them knows: They are not always completely transparent. It's difficult, and I guess it's often not entirely unintentional. In this respect, regulation makes perfect sense here, even if the instrument of regulation should only be used in very targeted doses. And I think we've all had the experience of being confronted with very high bills from our providers. It only happened to me recently in Mongolia. I switched off data roaming on the plane, but it still logged into the network and I had to pay 400 euros for data roaming. In this respect, even if you are tech-savvy, it is not always clear to people when costs arise. That is why this is a sensible measure, and I will say it very clearly: this is a strength of the Union that is now being used here. One should concentrate less on other things and more on these things, and that is also for the good of the people.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: - Madam President! It is a great day if we can talk about the fact that additional roaming charges will disappear in a few months. We will pay everyone as in their home country when going to the countries of the European Union. We've waited ten years for this. I watched this because I have been a member of this committee for many years, and now I am speaking on behalf of the ITRE Committee. It is important that we have carried out this process in ten years. We figured out three times what we have today to make these charges disappear, extra charges. This is important because we watched how companies behave during this time, whether they do not use this situation to burden customers, and therefore, among other things, it was a three-step process. I also wanted to respond to the absurd allegations made by one of my non-attached colleagues (she is not in the room) that the European Union took a long time and that there was some misunderstanding that we are doing it within the Union. Please state! When we leave the EU, we still pay roaming charges outside the EU. It follows that if we extended the Union to other countries, other countries would be deprived of these fees for us, for the inhabitants of the European Union. So is it good to expand the European Union or not? These are absurd allegations that are actually difficult to answer. I would also like to reply to my colleague Helmer from the committee that one of the basic elements of free market regulation is, for example, antitrust law and that is what all countries apply. I am not going to talk about the dozens of other regulations that we have all over the world. Unfortunately, the free market is not completely free as it would be a jungle then. On the other hand, I wanted to say that our work is not over, everything that we have agreed must be implemented and that it must be implemented well and supervised. I would like to congratulate my colleague Kumpula-Natri, all the shadow rapporteurs, including the predecessors: Ms Pilar de Castillo Vera and others, the President, Vice-Presidents of the Committee and predecessors on this position and the Maltese Presidency, the previous Presidency, which were also working on this.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: - Madam President, as of the 15th of June, European citizens will be able to access data, voice and text without paying roaming fees, as long as their consumption is in accordance with normal standards. Thus, they will have access to telecommunications services anywhere in the European Union, as if they were at home, and this is an excellent measure. But, Commissioner, it has to be applied fairly and effectively, and there are two conditions for that. Firstly, national operators, based on the rule that allows to recover losses demonstrated as a result of the measure, cannot allow operators to charge citizens who do not travel costs that result from responding to the demand of displaced citizens and, secondly , European systems to encourage investment in digital networks should give priority to territories that will have to increase their capacity to respond to seasonal demand. In this report, I signed it myself, there are instruments and procedures that guarantee these two conditions. It is essential to ensure that this is an effective and fair measure.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: - Madam President, setting maximum roaming charges is a classic price regulation that is unnecessary, harmful and never intended.I am all the more surprised that the emergence of this regulation is justified by the need to ensure that the market works, and it is this regulation that disrupts the functioning of the market.In fact, operators will pass on their costs to home users, who will see the price fall more slowly or not at all.Of course, roaming ceilings sound pleasing, but they will actually hurt people who travel less, such as pensioners, and help people who travel more, such as MEPs.These are the unintended consequences, and, of course, this regulation then requires more and more additions and complications, and this is how we complicate the world here, and then we are surprised that we live in an over-regulated world.It remains to be hoped that this regulation will end in five years' time.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, we have had a debate on fake news and hate speech. Well, this is not a fake, this is reality. But still, while we do not hear any hate speech, we have seen and listened to some disappointing speech, making out that this is not real progress in terms of enhancing the internal market. We hear stories, for example that Brussels is being lobbied. No! It was Brussels and the efforts of the Commission and the Parliament that made it happen. The lobbies are working in the capitals. The Council is, and was, the bottleneck. So let us finish with this fake news and face reality. There is, of course, a long way to go. This is an important step but, if we want to build a real digital market, we should be encouraged and pursue this in other sectors. That is certain.  Finally, it has been said that this is just for the globalists but, come on, this is absolute rubbish. The Czech Republic must be a rich country because millions and millions of Czechs travel on an annual basis. This is the reality for all the people around us. So, yes, there is a certain amount of concern, but that concern can be taken care of at a national level with anti—monopoly efforts, and of course with competition and enhancing the internal market. This is the way to go and we will proceed in this direction, whether we like it or not. This is reality and not fake news.

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice President, ladies and gentlemen, on June 15, when any citizen of the European Union uses the telephone, accesses the internet or sends a message, they will not have additional charges for being roaming. This is a huge step forward that benefits all citizens of the European Union, those who leave more and those who leave less, because it constitutes an instrument to give the possibility that our companies, our professionals, our students have greater freedom of movement, have more and more opportunities in the European Union, in all the countries that comprise it. This is what you really have to keep in mind. It was this Parliament that proposed it. It was this Parliament that approved it and negotiated it with the Council - in close cooperation with the Commission, of course. And in this Parliament we have to be very satisfied to have achieved that, on June 15, these additional charges do not exist and, therefore, we have taken a step in the development of a European digital market, in the development of a more Europe integrated and with more opportunities. Besides that, it will be necessary to be attentive - as some lordship has said - to whether or not distortions occur and it will be necessary to see whether or not they have an impact on the national market, because perhaps they are other factors and not precisely those of roaming . All this can also be taken into account, but today is a moment of real satisfaction, because we have taken a step forward in European integration, in responding to the true demands and needs of the citizens of the European Union.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: - Mr President, the Union brings us many things in almost all areas of our life: in security, in well-being, in defense of our rights and freedoms, but also in our day-to-day lives.This agreement is a good example of what we are talking about.The Union is synonymous with mobility and, with this agreement, roaming will be history.This agreement will allow European consumers to benefit from affordable prices and travel using their phones without fear of exorbitant bills;they will use their phone, send their messages, use WhatsApp as if they were in their own home.I sincerely believe that the disappearance of roaming is going to play a key role, a key role for the development of the entire digital ecosystem in Europe.That is why I want to congratulate the rapporteurs on this agreement.But above all, today, those who are in luck are European consumers.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I welcome this proposal, which is the final piece of legislation required to ensure that mobile roaming charges will be removed by this coming June – something we have promised for a long time and something that the EU has delivered for its citizens. As an MEP who campaigned with others for the abolition of ... (The President interrupted the speaker because of a fire alarm)

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: There is a fire alarm. Please let us suspend our debate until the situation is clarified. (The sitting was suspended at 18.05 and resumed at 18.25)

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I would like to apologize for this incident, we do not know the reasons yet. It was certainly nothing serious. I would like to thank all the ladies and gentlemen for their behavior in accordance with the rules. Threat announced - you should always leave the building, stay safe, leave job opportunities to the relevant services. It is a kind of paradox that I am responsible for Parliament's security in Parliament's Bureau. Sometimes it so happens that whoever responds does not know what the cause was right now. I don't know the reason yet. We resume our proceedings. The next item on the agenda after the fire alarm is the continuation of the debate on the report by Miapetra Kumpula-Natri, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 531/2012 as regards provisions in wholesale roaming markets (COM (2016) 0399 - C8-0219 / 2016 - 2016/0185 (COD)) (A8 = 0372/2016)

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I did not realise that my Kerry accent was so magnetic that I would set the alarm bells ringing in Parliament, but I do hope that you enjoyed your roaming free of charge around the Parliament. So now to this topic. I welcome the proposals, which are the final piece of legislation required to ensure that mobile roaming charges will be removed from this coming June. It is something we have promised for a long time and something the EU has delivered for its citizens. As an MEP who has campaigned with many others for the abolition of roaming charges for the last seven years, I am delighted that we are now nearly there. It is already eighteen months since, in 2015, it was proudly announced here in the European Parliament that, after a long process, ‘roam-like-at-home’ was to be introduced by June 2017. It was a very high-profile and important announcement. While tomorrow’s vote might not have the same fanfare, its importance cannot be overstated. The introduction of this wholesale roaming cap is an absolutely essential piece of legislation, as it allows for ‘roam-like-at-home’ to happen in a cost-effective manner this June. The caps that we arrived at in the end: EUR 0.032 for a voice call, a gradually-decreasing cap from EUR 7.75 in 2017 to EUR 2.50 in 2022 per gigabyte of data and EUR 0.01 for text messages represents a fantastic result for the European Parliament, particularly given that the majority of Council favoured higher caps. Wholesale data prices are declining by around 40% annually across the EU. The overly-cautious Council position just did not reflect reality. I feel the final result could have even been better, but such is the nature of compromise. In my own country we are very pleased with the outcome, because it means that the higher caps, which would have put artificially-high costs on to Irish producers – this will not happen now. It is a good day for the European Parliament, especially when we speak about Brexit – again an indication that the United Kingdom citizens will not benefit from this. It is no wonder Roger Helmer and his colleagues were so agitated.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Referring to your first words, I think it was probably not your words that triggered the alarm, because even today much heavier words were heard and the fire alarm was silent.Well, but we appreciate the weight of your words.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: - Nixtieq nibda mill-ewwel billi nagiti prosit lir-rapporteur Miapetra Kumpula-Natri għaliex naf kemm kiena biogaol kbira biex jintlaħaq dan il-ftehim. Imma dan huwa pass kbir ʼil quddiem għaliex il-ftehim li ntlaħaq dwar il-ligi tar-roaming kien sfida interestingly fi żmien movimentat mhux ħażin għall-Unjoni Ewropea. U bosta kieni fir-realtà xettiċi kemm l-Unjoni Ewropea se tikseb ir-riżultati f'aspetti daqshekk importanti għaċ-ċittadini tagħha. In the case of the European Parliament, the European Parliament and the President of the Republic of Malta shall be notified. For the purposes of this Regulation, the European Union shall take the necessary measures to ensure that, in the case of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, the former Member States do not enter into force. Kellhom jgħaddu disa ’snin biex nilħqu ftehim policy finali, idada finalment, it-tariffs tar-roaming huma xi ħaġa tal-passat. U bit-tne Eija ta ‘dawn it-tarifffi, għandna Ewropa aktar maqgħuda milli kellna lbieraħ, u din għandha tkun it-triq‘ il quddiem fuq temi oħra ewlenin ukoll.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: - (FI) Mr President, the long-standing goal of the European Parliament will be achieved next June with the complete abolition of roaming charges in the European Union. In fact, since 2007, when roaming was first introduced at EU level, prices have fallen by as much as 90%. It is a very significant achievement for consumers. It is important that when we want to promote digitalisation in Europe, consumers are encouraged to use digital services and also mobile data. In that sense, this outcome of the negotiations on the wholesale price cap, which has now been achieved and in which Parliament did an excellent job in the negotiations, was very important. Especially in the countries of Northern Europe, Scandinavia and the Baltics, where mobile data is used very much, it is important that operators cannot charge each other too high prices for roaming. In my own country, Finland, mobile data is used the most in the world and even ten times more than in other European countries, and there this is of great importance to consumers and operators. Otherwise, the threat would have been that consumer prices might even have risen in Finland as a result of the abandonment of roaming charges. It is important that strong efforts are now being made across Europe to promote the use of mobile data, and that this can be done by investing in good high-speed networks and promoting fair competition. When we have a functioning market in Europe, it means that consumers will receive better services and lower prices, and so digitalisation will move forward in Europe.

name: Eva KAILI
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to congratulate my colleague, Miapetra, on her excellent work. We all know how difficult the process of drafting this text and considering all our amendments was, while there was a lot of pressure in the tripartite negotiations with the Council. Regulating the wholesale market is a very important step for a competitive single digital market that benefits European citizens and creates the conditions for healthy competition, but most importantly, Europe is finally delivering on its promise. As we also approach the mid-term evaluation of the digital single market, we need to show that this effort continues. We need more protection and security as a default for users, especially when it comes to our personal data, easy and reliable e-commerce, so that everyone, consumers and businesses, can easily, without discrimination, within the European Union, of course, invest in countries and areas that need it most, so that no one is left behind in this new digital age, but also innovative solutions, such as Blockchain technology, which can give back control of data to citizens, while also offering many solutions to many different challenges. So this regulation comes at a critical time and sends a very important message to Strasbourg and Brussels that we are working for a truly single digital market with more security for European citizens. (The speaker agreed to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mister President!My question relates to the positive effects that can result from roaming.Do you think that tourism can also be stimulated and that exports can play an important role for small and medium-sized businesses?Roaming could also be a significant positive factor in the economic recovery, I believe.

name: Eva KAILI
text: answer to a question with a blue card. - Thank you very much for the question. Of course, not only are we trying to create a more single market and feel more European, especially when traveling, but it can also help small and medium-sized businesses and all professionals feel that they are heading for a single market. But we have other actions that follow, WiFi for Europe, Free Data Flow, EFSI, Juncker plan 2 that will support and strengthen funding to achieve this single digital market. There we have changed a lot and the priorities from the Commission, with which we work. So the opportunities that are given are very important. What we need to be careful about, and it is very important, is not to give social platforms the ability to control or touch the content and not take the location, position or data more than the citizens want. So by default we make sure everything is safer for European citizens. This will make this market safe and important.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, for me, to achieve a truly European telecom market is one of the most important priorities for the European Union, because that is a precondition for a dynamic and vibrant digital economy in the European Union – a pre-condition for us to be in the lead regarding 5G regarding all the new services that can revitalise our economies. And in that perspective, this step, with a regulation regarding the pricing between wholesales operators, are of fundamental importance. It will mean that from 15 June we can use the different services via the internet all over Europe. It will mean that citizens can travel, but it will mean that we can reach a new level of our digital economy. I think we need now to proceed in order to create truly trans-European networks to ensure that there are no negative effects coming out of this, only positive effects, and that is something we should call on the Commission to do: to ensure that we can proceed to a truly European telecom and a truly digital market in the European Union.

name: Olle LUDVIGSSON
text: - Mr President! Getting rid of roaming charges has long been a priority. The work extends over several terms of office, and without hesitation it has been a long journey, but we are finally approaching the terminus because roaming charges can be phased out within the EU. Tomorrow we will be voting on the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the wholesale roaming market. In my opinion, it is very much a good, balanced agreement, which ensures that Europe's consumers will soon be able to enjoy roaming 'like at home'. Having said that, I really hope that a large and broad majority supports the agreement. The EU is an important tool for strengthening consumer rights. It is a fact that we are about to put the last piece of the puzzle, which enables the roaming charges to soon be a thing of the past. It also shows concretely how we in EU cooperation can jointly achieve positive outcomes, which Europe's consumers can actually benefit from. A big thank you to those who have negotiated through this.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: - Mr Chairman! In two months, roaming charges in the European Union will go down in history, in two months, everyone traveling in Europe will pay the same for telecommunications connections as in their home country. Tomorrow's roaming vote will remove telephone borders between EU member states. This is good news primarily for consumers who will pay lower bills, but it is also good news for enterprises that will have lower operating costs, and in particular for innovative small enterprises and start-ups that will want to participate in the telecommunications services market. For me personally, this is a very important day, because ten years ago here in the European Parliament, I personally got involved in the first cut in roaming charges, and it was not easy, but the European Parliament decided that rates would be reduced against the resistance of telecommunications companies. And I am glad that today or tomorrow we will be voting to end roaming tariffs completely. It took a long time, but it was worth it. I would like to say that today's debate and tomorrow's decision show that the European Union is capable of making decisions that serve people and that serve the economy. This is especially important at a time when Eurosceptic and populist sentiment is spreading across Europe and the European Union is often criticized quite wrongly by all those who do not see the concrete benefits of European integration.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: - Sir. Chairman! I must also say a big thank you to our dealers for the good result. When we vote tomorrow on a cap on wholesale prices, it is the end of more than 10 years of work to ensure that consumers are not penalized for traveling around Europe and using their mobile phones. It is a very big victory for consumers and for the work we have put in here in the European Parliament. It is mainly us who have put enormous pressure on the industry to ensure that it got here. However, it is also a good deal for other reasons, as it actually means that by putting a cap on wholesale prices, we are also doing something good for the industry. Now it is no longer just consumers who can be sure not to get shock prices. This also applies to industry. I therefore think it is a very balanced agreement. However, I think maybe 10 years is quite a long time. I hope that in the future we can become a little quicker in ensuring something that benefits both consumers and businesses.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Mr. President, June 15 will be a great day for me personally, but also for all those who want to travel in Europe, who want to do business in Europe and who want to reduce the differences that exist between us in European countries, either north and south or east. and the west. These days as we struggle to equalize product quality in the East and West, here’s finally an example. Is there a better example than abolishing roaming charges to show and prove that the European Union is capable of making decisions in the interests of our consumers, in the interests of our citizens. This is a concrete example on which we can prove just that. That is why I am grateful to all those who have been working on this project for years and who have managed to reach such a good agreement. I hear that there are differences between the northern and southern countries, that telecom operators will use the increase in the prices of their fees. However, all this is negligible compared to what we got. There is no more reason for some from the east to feel worse than those from the west, when we drive in the same car, so some can surf and others can’t surf, because it’s too expensive because they have too high a price in their country. Therefore, once again I want to thank you, roaming is becoming history and I hope that in this way we will show those who think that the European Union is not functional that it can work on this example.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: - Mr Vice-President, the abolition of roaming charges is an indisputable and key victory for us as consumers in the European Union. I am glad that with tomorrow's vote, we will be able to finalize the process, and this summer we will be able to be part of a stronger digital single market and a single market. The new maximum wholesale roaming prices mean several other very important things: first, they create competition between operators and open up markets to smaller operators who need our support to be an active part of our economy. They also give us the opportunity to use the Internet more while traveling, working, shopping. The abolition of roaming charges also coincides with the mid-term evaluation of the progress of the digital single market strategy. That is why it is important to build on what has been achieved so far by ensuring the portability of online content and eliminating unjustified geo-blocking. It is also crucial that we actively work for the free movement of data in the Union and thus have another victory for our consumers and businesses. I believe that, by working together, we will provide adequate protection for the online activities of all European citizens, administrations and businesses.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: - Mr Chairman! As we are talking today about abolishing additional charges for roaming calls, I recall the recently spoken words of Donald Tusk that either the European Union will be strongly united or it will not be at all. And we need to unite with very specific actions, such actions are precisely the removal of barriers that divide our common European market into 28 different smaller markets. Our common European market where we all function, operate, work, buy, sell and learn. And this long-awaited release from additional ... freeing ourselves, because it is our joint decision - all who have worked hard on it for many years - freeing ourselves from additional roaming charges, it is like opening the gate to to put up with further barriers in this common market, mainly our digital common market, where we are trying to unite this market together with Vice-President Andrus Ansip. And the next barriers that are still ahead of us are both online shopping, access to cultural goods, and all digital goods that we all want to have access to and give access to others. So, once again, thanks to everyone: from Viviane Reding who started this whole roaming process all the way to Mrs. Natri today. Congratulations to everyone and thank you very much, and let's move on in this direction!

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: - (FI) Mr President, the European Parliament is to be congratulated and, above all, to thank all the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs who have been working for more than nine years to eliminate roaming charges in the European Union. The Commission has also shown a great deal of backbone and goodwill in achieving a digital single market. At no point has it been easy, and the national interest has been robbed many times to justify the questionable behavior of the operators and has also been used as an unfair means in this debate. In the initial phase, there has been almost cartel-like behavior from operators and outright robbery of each other at a later stage, as roaming charges have been moving forward. All this has prevented and slowed down the emergence of a true European digital agenda, digital union and consumer services. This is an excellent example of why we need the EU. An excellent example of why we need market supervision and regulation, and an excellent example of why we need common European rules of the game. I can't really find anything better. And finally: the compromise must be satisfied as always in life. According to the information I have received, wholesale prices are still quite well above the actual costs, so there will be enough work for both Parliament and the Commission on this issue.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Mr Chairman!The end of roaming charges is without doubt a clear, tangible example of the benefits that the European Union brings to our citizens.Therefore, I am glad that, by adopting the provisions on wholesale roaming markets, we are just completing the work on the final step in the process of abolishing these charges.I was pleased to hear that, as a result of the failure to negotiate, it was possible to achieve a significant reduction in the wholesale price ceilings in relation to the original proposal.At the same time, I would like to emphasize the importance of regular monitoring by the European Commission of changes taking place on national markets and the effects of the introduced regulation in order to identify any possible irregularities that are a burden for consumers in good time.I would like to offer a big congratulations and thanks to all the people who have led to this success.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the abolition of roaming charges, scheduled for next 15 June, will put an end to the abuses perpetrated over the past year and a half by some telephone companies that have acted by exploiting the gray areas of the new regulation. Exactly one year ago, in a written question to the Commission, I denounced the incorrect practice of the automatic activation of flat rate plans for roaming services, which circumvents the application of the new rates thanks to the lack of transparency on the net cost of calls. For this reason, I believe that BEREC's decision to include the possibility of a 12-month extension for the elimination of roaming in the new guidelines recently published needs to be reviewed. And the denials of the national authorities of these days are of little use, if among the objectionable circumstances is that of economic non-sustainability - an exception, among other things, renewable from year to year. On closer inspection, this is a rather artificial issue, given that the abolition of roaming has been under discussion for about ten years and operators have had all the time necessary to prepare their commercial strategies.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, the use of data traffic is increasing both in Europe and globally.It is clear that this trend will continue, which is good for the European economy, as new opportunities open up in the services sector.The global economy is transforming thanks to new technologies and this process is inevitable.It can be very useful for Europe if we take advantage of all the opportunities that are provided and do not limit our own growth to an excessive regulatory burden.The Commission bases its proposal for a wholesale cap on all data traffic on a rather conservative assessment of data traffic use growth and unchanged market prices, although independent studies show that data traffic use will grow significantly and the market price will continue to fall.Another proof that the supply-demand relationship must be the main regulator of prices, and politics should interfere in this relationship as little as possible.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: - Reducing the cost of calls and mobile internet will certainly contribute to a more comfortable and better life throughout the European Union.Today, we congratulated Ukraine on securing visa-free travel and closer ties with Europe, but the price of a mobile minute with that country has almost doubled in the last few years by all EU operators.We therefore have an interesting paradox: on the one hand, we are promoting European integration in the already established European Union, and on the other hand, we are moving away from countries outside the European Union on everyday household issues.We may ask the question: what will be the cost of mobile communications with the United Kingdom after we have completed the Brexit procedures?I believe that, given the significant reduction in mobile prices within the EU, we should pay more attention to regulating this service, at least with our immediate neighbors.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: - The abolition of roaming will thus reduce costs for those abroad and unify the digital market.Not only to businessmen who spend a lot of time abroad, but also to young people who study abroad and to all of us who come to another Member State as tourists.It is very likely that the operators will increase the price of their subscription packages before June and, of course, adapt them to the market.However, we still have to wait for this and also keep a close eye on it.Roaming will be unified once and for all with the abolition of roaming, as surcharges have been charged by operators, thus creating additional barriers to the digital single market.I welcome the success of the European Commission and the European Parliament, as it has provided a lot of people with cheaper telephony.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, today we have a joy, in addition to the sadness of the Brexit debate: a long-awaited thing, although the regulation provided for the elimination of tariffs in 2015. We hope that it will be a fact if tomorrow we manage to be united in voting for this report. However, the Commission also needs to develop a sustainability mechanism, which must be implemented by the end of the year for some exceptional derogations, and I am convinced that it will deal with this. Finally a normality for a communication at the rate of home with the family, with the employees of the company, when we travel. Consumers, in fact, were not protected, because they could not verify what price was charged to them in a certain country. If the report is voted on, we will enter into an adequate and uniform normality and consumer protection in the internal market. The market will be more dynamic and everyone has something to gain. I congratulate the rapporteur, my colleague, our colleague, Miapetra, and I hope, Commissioner, that monitoring will continue and that we will reach a normal situation and a single market in this area as well.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, a single market cannot function without the digital market, without the digital economy itself. Only in this way can there be growth and strengthening of employment. To do this, the excessive charges imposed by roaming must be eliminated, ie there can be no growth if the roaming charges are not eliminated. Thus the abolition of roaming is a positive development for both wholesalers and the citizens themselves. It is enough, Mr President and Commissioner, for it to be implemented, for it to enter into force without asterisks and exceptions. So uniform prices throughout Europe for citizens who should not have roaming charges wherever they call. In this way, citizens will be able to move freely, without obstacles, to be informed through their mobile phones, to download data. Small and medium-sized enterprises will also be strengthened through free data exchange.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: - Mr President, I would agree with those who have spoken before that the abolition of roaming charges is indeed a positive step. However, Commissioner, the Council and the committee responsible, when examining the Commission proposal, came to some differences. I specifically cite as an example the need for a sustainability mechanism. That is, if there is a serious price difference in some Member States, the maximum price can be adjusted if necessary. The sustainability mechanism is not part of the agreement before us. Who can guarantee and explain to those Member States that have these concerns that their concerns about the absence of this mechanism are being met?

name: Tibor SZANYI
