text: - President!I really appreciate your flexibility in giving you the opportunity to speak almost - or even everything - spontaneously.Although if I would like to say this to you on the phone and say you call me here in Strasbourg about my Hungarian phone number, my Hungarian mobile number, on your Polish mobile number, it will indeed be very discounted.But if I wanted to do it from Budapest, from my own mobile phone, which is a Hungarian mobile phone, in that case I could only call you as an international call, specifically at a dear cost.Well, we have not yet been able to resolve this contradiction, so I ask the Commission to consider doing something about this, because it is very expensive to call abroad from our own mobile phone, even though it is cheaper everywhere else.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice President of the Commission. – Mr President, tomorrow will be a historic vote, as it will mark the final step of a long regulatory journey. This journey was a really long one. We started with this process in 2007, but in the beginning this process was not very rapid. But since last May we have been able to cut those roaming surcharges by 75%. Altogether, in comparison with 2009, we were able to cut roaming surcharges for SMS messages and voice minutes by 92% and for data by as much as 96%. At the same time, domestic prices in all our Member States decreased. This is my message to all those people who are worried about the increase in domestic prices. Exorbitant roaming charges were an anomaly in a continent where people move freely across, and between, countries. Together the EU institutions are now putting an end to the roaming surcharges for our people. At last, people will be able to stop turning off the data on their phones when they cross an EU border. This is how it should be and how it should always have been. The Commission, in cooperation with national regulatory authorities, will continue its close monitoring to ensure that the new rules of today’s deal are strictly observed by the operators. The EU is often criticised for not delivering concrete results to Europeans. This is because the benefits of EU policies are sometimes difficult to grasp and identify in people’s daily lives. Here is one well-identified and very concrete benefit. The Commission strongly urges the European Parliament to adopt the new regulation on wholesale roaming markets. We now need to come together and say with one voice that we delivered on our promise.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: demonstrator. - Mr President, thank you to all my colleagues for today's debate, for their strong support and also for your concern. It was an honor to lead this negotiation on behalf of Parliament. The last piece of legislation on common wholesale market prices will be finalized in a vote tomorrow. The European Parliament would have been prepared for even lower prices, as came up here, because we see that the lower the price caps, the better for the consumer. But even for those operators that already today offer unlimited data usage at a cheap price, three facilitations were obtained in the process. Firstly, the ceiling price was much lower than the Commission's original proposal, secondly, these operators can set ceilings for the use of data abroad, and thirdly, operators can then apply for an exemption if this would still be too costly for them. Here, however, I believe that the market and the competitive market are playing and consumers will be covered by this legislation, so that it is also possible to travel and use the telephone abroad. I do not know of any country whose consumers would benefit from high national prices. I think it would be a good goal if this legislation also increased transparency, because why on earth would we be arguing that the price of data in one country could be 100 times that of another or ten times the price of calls. I think you should all go to your home countries and ask if technology is really that much more expensive or wages or what, because the differences between countries are really big. This can be a good addition to this, as we gain transparency. We are proving that the EU is needed, that regulation is needed and that transparency is needed. We also need additional investment, because each additional investment lowers the unit cost, giving Europeans more access to mobile data and the services it provides.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 6 April 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written. - In future, European consumers will no longer have to pay extra for using their mobile phones abroad. High mobile phone bills for calling in other EU countries are a thing of the past. On the basis of the Commission's proposal, the European Parliament and the Council reached political agreement in June 2016 on the new rules to be applied by operators in the wholesale roaming market from June onwards. The wholesale prices for data roaming have been falling for a number of years. The increase in data usage is one of the main reasons for this price drop. The increased use of data brings clear economic advantages, as it opens up new service options. In addition, the increased use of data is increasingly triggering infrastructure investments, which means that consumers can use even more data. For my home country Austria in particular, investments in broadband infrastructure are of great importance because the country only ranks poorly in the middle of the field in terms of digitization when compared to Europe. According to the Index for the Digital Economy and Society (DESI) 2016, Austria only ranks 20th out of a total of 29 countries when it comes to the proportion of fast broadband over 30 Mbit / s. I therefore support the goal of abolishing roaming charges for retail customers in Europe, as this benefits consumers and means that the telecommunications markets remain competitive.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: signed up. - The debate on "wholesale roaming" is natural in the context in which the European Union aims to eliminate roaming charges by 15 June 2017. We, policy makers, must take into account the interests of citizens first and foremost. the interest of European citizens is to have zero costs when traveling in any Member State. Citizens want to see the European Union pay more attention and propose more concrete solutions to their day-to-day problems, sometimes even to the detriment of the private or national interest. Therefore, national wholesale roaming markets need to be competitive and propose wholesale roaming tariffs that allow operators to offer retail roaming services in a sustainable way, at no additional cost. The solution I propose is to regulate everything related to "wholesale roaming" at European level, whether we keep the current tariffs or decide together to reduce them substantially, with the main aim of eliminating the total costs for ordinary citizens by implementing Roam Like At Home (RLAH) rules.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - On June 15, 2017, European citizens will no longer pay additional costs when using their mobile phone outside their country. This victory, which we obtained following a long standoff with the operators, will significantly lower the telephone bills of millions of cross-border workers and tens of millions of European holidaymakers. However, to ensure the disappearance of these costs for individuals and to ensure that operators do not try to catch up elsewhere, it was also necessary to reduce the wholesale prices of roaming, that is to say the cost that telecom operators bill each other when the customer consults the internet abroad. The decision voted today in the European Parliament goes in this direction. Thanks to this agreement, the citizen is a double winner. On the one hand, he can be sure that he will not pay additional costs for using his mobile phone outside his country (as long as he does not use the service excessively, a threshold yet to be set). But that's not all. These lower caps for data transfers will allow European consumers to access more audiovisual content when they travel beyond their borders.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing. - Mr President, the report we are debating today is of great importance to all citizens of the European Union, as it concerns communication preferences. In 2015, an order was passed that provided for the abolition of roaming charges on all types of traffic, including voice, within the EU. The entry into force of such a system requires the introduction of rules governing wholesale charges for roaming services. At the same time, it will be possible to abolish retail charges for roaming in Europe. This solution needs to be introduced as soon as possible, as it is definitely valuable for all consumers, and especially for those traveling to different European countries. It will also contribute to reducing charges for communications, provided that a "fair use policy" based on non-charging for ancillary services of operators and data transfers outside the country where the service was purchased is ensured. In this context, the protection of competition in the telecommunications market needs to be addressed in the implementing acts, as this is necessary to maintain potentially low service prices. Provisions and rules eliminating roaming in the EU are needed as soon as possible in order to consolidate and facilitate a homogeneous digital market process in the Union. It will also affect the reduction of consumer taxes. The rapporteur's position urging the Commission to take action on this as soon as possible is therefore entirely justified.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Maria Gabriel, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 listing third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing bordersexternal, and those whose citizens are exempt from this requirement (Ukraine) (COM (2016) 0236 - C8-0150 / 2016) - 2016/0125 (COD)) (A8-0274 / 2016)

name: Michał BONI
text: deputising for the rapporteur. – Mr President, on behalf of Mrs Mariya Gabriel, Rapporteur for the Report for the visa liberalisation for Ukrainian citizens, allow me to address some words. First and foremost, the rapporteur would like to thank the Commission and the Council for the excellent collaboration that has existed all through the process. The rapporteur would like to highlight the remarkable work realised by the Slovak and Maltese Presidencies in order to achieve the completion of the visa liberalisation process so dear to the Ukrainian citizens. The rapporteur would also like to thank the Ukrainian people and the Ukrainian government for all their efforts, determination and patience. Indeed, on 28 February an agreement was reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the visa liberalisation process for Ukraine. This agreement was confirmed by the COREPER meeting two days later. On 9 March 2017, an overwhelming majority of MEPs on the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) voted in favour of the visa waiver for Ukrainian citizens, sending a strong message. In the words of the rapporteur, Ukraine has achieved all the benchmark criteria set out by the EU and has even gone beyond expectations in terms of sustainable reforms. Important advancements have been realised in the areas of document security, border and migration management, public order and security, and external relations and fundamental rights. For the rapporteur, it is these criteria and this methodology that are extremely important in the benefits that they produce. On the one hand, citizens benefit from the implementation of reforms that impact their daily lives. In fact, the visa waiver is a remarkable tool that allows to connect people and build bridges among populations. On the other hand, it is a strong message for the citizens that see their country engaged in a European path. Given the commitment of Ukraine to pursue in the way of the reforms undertaken and the consolidation and sustainability of its compromises, the rapporteur calls on us to confirm today the principle that the European Parliament so heatedly defends: that every country that meets the criteria set out by the European Commission should benefit of the visa waiver for its citizens. Finally, the rapporteur would like to stress that Ukraine is a key partner for the EU in the Eastern Partnership in the fight against organised crime and terrorism, the fight against human trafficking, and the fight against corruption. Our vote tomorrow, supporting the visa waiver for the Ukrainian citizens, would constitute in this sense the concrete realisation of their aspiration and engagement in favour of peace, stability and European ambition. On her behalf, I thank you.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I would like to thank you for all the efforts you have put in this important file. Very soon, Ukrainian citizens holding a biometric passport will be able to travel to the Schengen area for short stays of up to 90 days without a visa, and I am very pleased that we are nearing this important moment for Ukraine and its citizens, for its neighbourhood and for the European Union. We are seeing the results of the hard work of the Ukrainian authorities over the past three years. It has been a long process, but we are reaching the end. Already in December 2015, the Commission confirmed that Ukraine had implemented all the benchmarks set out in its visa liberalisation action plan. Following this positive assessment and taking into account the overall EU-Ukraine relations, we proposed in early 2016 to lift the visa requirement for Ukrainian citizens holding a biometric passport. I am very pleased that we can now finally conclude this process. In parallel, the revised visa suspension mechanism just entered into force at the end of last month. The visa suspension mechanism will be an important tool to further enhance security for the EU but also to strengthen our visa liberalisation policy. Under the new mechanism, the Commission will monitor the continuous fulfilment by Ukraine and all visa-free countries of the visa liberalisation criteria, especially in the fight against organised crime and corruption. Honourable Members, we are almost there. Visa liberalisation for Ukraine will be an essential contribution to strengthening cultural and economic ties between Ukraine and the EU for the Eastern Partnership and our neighbourhood in general. In times of rising nationalism and xenophobia, insular and exclusive thinking, this will be another signal that the EU remains open and connected to this, its neighbourhood. Dear Members of the European Parliament, I call on you to demonstrate this openness and support the proposal on the table during the votes.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Draftsman for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. - Mister President! I am speaking today as the European Parliament's standing rapporteur for Ukraine. I took on this task from our colleague Saryusz-Wolski, who, as rapporteur, drafted the Foreign Affairs Committee's opinion on this report. I thank him for his work so far and I am sure that he will share my remarks. Today we congratulate Ukraine. With the decision of the European Parliament, we are exempting Ukrainian nationals from the visa requirement. At the same time, we are strengthening the connection between the European Union and this country. The visa waiver was made possible through the work of the Ukrainian government and the Verkhovna Rada. You have met important technical requirements. They also have the political will to modernize their country democratically and according to the rule of law, that is to say, in this context, to use an efficient readmission mechanism. Today, however, I also say critically to our own address: We as the EU have delayed this decision for far too long. The Commissioner said by December 2015 the country was ready. The Ukrainians deserved a much earlier decision. Because we also have to see: Ukraine steers this important reform course while it is at war and parts of the country - the Crimea, Donetsk and Luhansk - are occupied. The Russian President does not allow Ukraine these successes. I therefore say to those responsible in Ukraine: You have to safeguard the progress that has been made, even after the visa requirement is no longer applicable. I am therefore concerned about the latest attempts to make the work of anti-corruption activists more difficult. Traveling in the EU without expensive visas and time-consuming procedures will bring Ukrainians and EU citizens closer together. The Ukrainian passport will now be one of the first-class documents in Europe. Unlike documents issued by Russian occupation authorities, it opens all doors.This message should also be heard in the Donets Basin.Ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues!Do you remember?Twelve years have passed since President Yushchenko lifted the visa requirement for EU citizens in Ukraine.The occasion was the final of the Eurovision Song Contest in Kiev at the beginning of May 2005. I am pleased that in a few weeks, from May 9th to 13th, Ukraine will organize such a happy and peaceful festival for all Europeans.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs. – Mr President, when Mr President Poroshenko was in the Eastern Partnership Summit in Riga two years ago, he was referring to demonstrators outside the window who had banners saying ‘I was born visa-free’, and he repeated those words, and I think it was excellent food for thought for us. So now, finally, we are approaching the day when Ukrainian citizens can make short-term visits without a visa to the European Union. I am speaking on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, which has paid close attention to the developments in Ukraine: visiting the country and also organising a hearing, together with the Commission, with the EU Advisory Mission Ukraine and with the Council of Europe in Brussels, where we studied the state of the reforms in the judiciary. And while we are rejoicing with the Ukrainians that they finally have this visa-free access to the European Union, we should not give up reminding them that the reform of the judiciary and especially the measures against high-level corruption must continue, and we have with great concern read news that there would be a total misunderstanding that also those fighting corruption would have to be put on the same line with those who actually are in the position to conduct corruptive measures – that they would have to declare their assets and situation. I hope that it will be set right in Ukraine.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr. President, the visa-free regime for Ukrainians traveling to the European Union is just another proof of the European Parliament's continued support for Ukraine. This Parliament consistently shows solidarity and condemns Russian military engagement and the illegal annexation of Crimea, and encourages the promotion of political and economic reforms in Ukraine. In the last two years, Ukraine has embarked on an ambitious and comprehensive reform process, the real goal of which is to create a truly democratic political system and a properly functioning economy. The success of all reforms should enable Ukraine to move from a post-Soviet to a European state. Ukraine has been making unprecedented efforts since 2014 to implement reforms and the current EU visa refusal rate for Ukrainian citizens is less than 2%. This is an opportunity to call on the Ukrainian government to remain determined to pursue further reforms. They must show determination in implementation and achieve political stability, which together with the support of the people is extremely important for its success. The fact is that Ukraine has met all the conditions and also that all these conditions allow for visa suspension to happen but also allow for stability, security, prosperity and I personally believe that Ukraine deserves this treatment and I hope we will vote in that regard tomorrow. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: blue card question.- Colleague, thank you for accepting my question.I wanted to ask: do you think that Ukraine is able to assure us that what happened to the Ukrainian passports will not happen to the Syrian passports that were forged in thousands of copies and taken by Afghans, Pakistanis, Bangladeshi nationals?Furthermore, how can we be sure that these passports will not fall into the hands of organized crime people, who will use them for illegal activities?

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: the answer to the question posed by raising the blue card.- There is crime everywhere and it can happen in European countries.These are biometric passports and, as I said, Ukraine has met all the conditions required of it.The process has been going on for many years and this is a way to help Ukraine slowly integrate into Europe and get rid of Russian influence.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne KAUFMANN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mister President! More than 1.3 million Ukrainian citizens received a visa for the Schengen area last year. Ukrainians visiting their families in Europe, tourists, business travelers or interns. These and all citizens of the country will benefit in the future if we give the green light for the visa-free regime for Ukrainian citizens tomorrow. From this summer, stays of up to 90 days are exempt from the visa requirement if you have a biometric passport. This facilitates contacts between civil society, reduces bureaucracy and is also good for the economy in both Ukraine and the EU. In addition to all of these practical advantages, I believe that the decision also has a high symbolic value for Ukraine and the European Union. It is a recognition of the reform efforts in the country. As early as the end of 2015, the Commission determined that Ukraine had met all of the criteria necessary to abolish the visa requirement. Our yes to the visa-free regime tomorrow sends a clear signal: Ukraine can count on the EU as a partner in difficult times. We are opening the door to Europe a whole lot wider. (The speaker declined to answer a question from Mr Rübig about the "blue card" procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Ladies and gentlemen! Twelve years of asymmetry, one could say, of course, this can be explained by this state of affairs, but I think that we endure this visa requirement a bit too late. We promised it earlier, a few months ago we lifted visas for Georgians, it is a pity that we did not do it at the same time for our eastern neighbors, who have indeed made a great effort over the last few years to "Western", "Western" their country. Of course, we can talk about neglect - they were mentioned here by previous speakers, but first of all, we need to see not only the efforts of the authorities, but also the Ukrainian society itself, which really wants to be part of the West, also in the cultural and civilization dimension. There was talk of a green light, I think it was red, but also the orange light was on for a very long time. I would like this decision to be just a prelude to strategic and close cooperation with Ukraine, which will one day end with Ukraine joining our European family. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- Honorable Member!Thank you, too, for accepting my question.Indeed, we are talking about visa facilitation now, but obviously the European Parliament is helping Ukraine in a number of other ways, and even in other ways, not least through preferential trade instruments and, and I must say here, an embargo on the Russians.What do you think of the voices here in the European Parliament that may be aimed at easing the Russian embargo?

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: answer to a question asked by raising a blue card.- I would like to thank the deputy for this question.This is a question from a Member who knows the East well, has been there many times and I think he is one of our experts on this matter.I think that Ukraine must be helped, also through economic instruments, but it is not a question of charity or our charity.This is a question of our economic and political interest.These economic bridges need to be built while observing the actions of the increasingly stronger pro-Russian lobby, both in the West here and in Ukraine.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Ukraine fulfilled all the criteria for the visa-free travel of its citizens to European Union. It is perfectly sufficient for granting it. But besides that, Ukraine was dragged into a difficult situation, and it deserves our support. Years ago, when Berlin was divided and also in a difficult situation, a great US President proudly declared himself a Berliner. The democratic countries stood by Berlin and the principles of the liberal world. Also thanks to that, Berlin made it; it is united, and Germany and Europe as well. I see a similarity with the current situation in Ukraine. The people of Ukraine suffer, and key principles are also heavily present. Nowadays I would say that people, wherever they may live, who want a peaceful world and the rule of international law, are, in a way, Ukrainians. I am proud that the European Parliament and the European Union are leading efforts to support and encourage the people of Ukraine – for their future and for ours as well.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, I am clearly in favor of abolishing the visa requirement for all European countries. Therefore, I also agree with the inclusion of Ukraine in Annex II to Regulation (EC) No 539/2001. You will not find any of the larger European countries in this regulation. But there are Brunei and thirteen Latin American countries. It is time to start intensive negotiations with the countries of Europe on visa facilitation. In each of these states we can find controversial facts, specifically in Ukraine, it is about preventing the activities of the Communist and Socialist Party, about physical violence against the leading officials of these parties, about burning down their offices. Dozens of people died and were injured during the peace demonstrations on Maidan. The Odessa massacre has not yet been investigated. The rapporteur clearly does not recognize the results of the referendums in Crimea and Sevastopol. The current regime in the visa area has placed only symbolic obstacles for criminal elements in penetrating the European Union. It is therefore right that we are releasing the regime, which will certainly be used by those who want to work, trade and develop cultural relations. I believe that other European states will soon follow. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Dear colleague, why do you think it is wrong that Ukrainians have banned the Communist Party?Thank you for answer.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- It's easy.If we assume that we are moving towards democracy in Ukraine, then it is not possible to exclude left-wing forces from the democratic spectrum and prevent them from running freely, within the concept of political forces, to the Verkhovna Rada, that is, the Verkhovna Rada.And this, unfortunately, has happened in Ukraine.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to say to the Commissioner that tomorrow will be a joyful day for Ukrainian citizens, when Parliament votes for visa-free travel for Ukrainian citizens for three months to the EU. This is something which my political group, Verts/ALE, has been fighting for for all the countries in the neighbourhood. It has taken some time, and I would like to thank the rapporteur for the very good cooperation and the Commission for its support. As Parliament, most of us would have preferred to have had that rule entering into force earlier. Council wanted to have the suspension mechanism, but finally we got it, and now there will be visa-free travel for Ukrainian citizens. So this is a really joyful day. Nevertheless, I would like to make two criticisms about what is happening in Ukraine at the moment. One thing – which is not really a criticism – is that having the Eurovision Song Contest in Kiev in May is something that I fully support. Nevertheless, I personally do not think that it was a very wise decision not to let the Russian singer participate. The song contest should be something joyful for citizens from whichever country, and it should overcome the fears and the problems which exist in Ukraine with Russian warmongering, etc. The other point is even more serious. It is about the draft law on e—declarations, where civil society organisations will be obliged to submit e—declarations on their financial interests and assets. This is something that should go, and is going, for politicians and public officials. Yes, we as elected people also have to very clearly declare our interests, salaries and assets. This has been happening in Ukraine, but now legislators are going against civil society organisations – people who really fight for equal rights, more democracy, media freedom, etc. So this requirement is seen – and has to be seen – as a matter of intimidation that needs to stop. Let me make one final remark about another country that I am rapporteur for here – Kosovo – which still does not have visa liberalisation. I do hope that, as soon as the Kosovo Assembly votes for the two last requirements, that in Parliament and in Council we will have a fast move forward to give the green light to all of those citizens in our close neighbourhood.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. -  Mister President! So we are now talking about visa-free entry to the European Union for citizens of Ukraine. Unlike Poland or the Baltic States, Ukraine has not implemented any democratic or constitutional reforms. Ukraine is about as free economically as Ghana or Burkina Faso. The poor house of the euro zone, Greece, has a five times higher economic output per capita than Ukraine. It's civil war in the country. The president is a billionaire oligarch, and his mailbox companies have now become public through the Panama Papers. And he's not on good terms with journalists. He prefers not to let them enter, especially those who want to report on corruption. They then have to reveal their financial circumstances, so they are harassed in a special way. The fact that the Netherlands rejected the association agreement with Ukraine does not seem to interest anyone here, it is simply ignored. The EU wants to bind Ukraine more and more to itself and - as has already been said here - ultimately get it into the EU, even if the rejection of the Netherlands is there, for example. And that goes step by step - salami tactics - with money and without a visa. Billions of dollars are flowing into Ukraine, but the European Court of Auditors has stated that we don't know where. You just don't know. The money is gone. But that doesn't bother anyone, although this country - this has also been said several times - could become world champions in one discipline: corruption. The question is: by what yardstick do you measure visa-exemption? (The speaker declined to answer a question from Mr Gahler about the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group.- The European Court of Auditors calls Ukraine the most corrupt country in Europe.Ukraine is a country at war.It has to be kept going with billions in aid, it struggles with democracy and oligarchs rule it.Visas and passports are widely forged and you can already buy long-term visas, residence permits and even entire EU nationalities.So if there is one country that should not be eligible for a visa waiver, it is Ukraine.But Brussels sees Ukraine as a future member state, does not want to know about these facts and throws the borders wide open, while every normal person sees that with such a country you must have very well-guarded borders.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Mr President, a constitutional diversion took place in Ukraine two years ago. The Maidan movement, instigated and aided by extraterrestrials, overthrew President Yanukovych's legitimately elected government. The seizure of power by a fundamentally neo-Nazi party representing oligarchs and extremist groups is far from a rule of law. At the moment, the European Union, aiming to reduce Russia's influence, is negotiating and concluding agreements with a government that emerged from a coup. A direct contrast to the supremacy of international law as a basic principle of the Union. At the same time in Ukraine, corruption and entanglement are high. The political world is embroiled in a number of scandals, justice is going blind and there is a complete lack of European structures. The Union must pay close attention to its relations with a country which is unable to maintain order and in which intolerance, extremism, lawlessness and chaos prevail. Under these conditions, any approach to the current government of Ukraine is at least unfortunate. I think that the subject of your report is directed by the interests and not the reality. Of course, this is exactly what is happening in this room.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, sometime earlier this year, a Ukrainian newspaper asked me for an interview. The first question the editor asked me was, 'Why did you - the European Union and the European Parliament - throw us overboard?' Still just promises and words. After all, Ukraine is also defending you. People are dying. And you will not be able to solve a matter as simple as visa-free travel for the second year in a row. ”The EU-Ukraine visa liberalization dialogue began in 2008. The Commission presented Ukraine with a liberalization action plan in 2010. In December 2015, the Commission considered that Ukraine met all criteria for visa-free travel. The journey to visa-free travel took eight years. Meanwhile, Maidan took place, Russia annexed Crimea, and war broke out in the east. Even these shocks did not destroy the idea that Ukraine belongs to Europe. In September 2014, our European Parliament and the Ukrainian Parliament ratified the Association Agreement, and tomorrow we have to approve visa-free travel for Ukraine. It is not just that a Ukrainian citizen can visit the European Union for a full ninety days without a visa, but tomorrow's admission will be crucial in symbolic importance. Ukraine belongs to Europe. It was not forgotten.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - The dialogue on visa liberalization between the European Union and Ukraine began nine years ago. The Commission has published a number of positive reports on the implementation of the Visa Liberalization Action Plan, demonstrating significant progress since 2014, given the country's internal situation and external pressures. In its latest report, the Commission concludes that Ukraine has made the necessary progress and met all the benchmarks set out in the action plan. This decision should not be communicated as a unilateral concession by the European Union to Ukraine. Ukraine is our key partner in the framework of the European Neighborhood Policy and the Eastern Partnership. The principle of reciprocity of visa liberalization is reflected in the mutual benefits for both European and Ukrainian citizens. It will contribute to expanding the network of contacts, strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on vital issues. In conclusion, I am extremely pleased that the European Parliament is finally voting on this decision, which represents much more than the technical aspect of our relations. It is a much-anticipated symbolic, but also a very concrete act of the European Union's support for Ukraine and its citizens. I hope that the Council will soon confirm this decision, because, although it is clear that there will be no new enlargement of the European Union soon, our support for Ukraine must not stop gradually, with the obligation to meet all necessary standards to achieve one of the key certainly membership in the European Union.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: - Far from here is written a scenario of quarrels between Poles and Ukrainians, my answer is straightforward - I support visa liberalization, fight against aggression and difficult reforms.However, if the word of a Pole, a friend, a person who can go against the tide, has any meaning for Ukrainians, I want them to know that the memory of Stefan Bandera raises my greatest concerns.However, I believe that we will overcome all obstacles together.Acting in good will, we will lead to the fact that we are in one European family.

name: Johannes Cornelis van BAALEN
text: – Mr President, first, a correction: the Dutch Parliament, having two houses, is now in the process of ratification of the Association Agreement with Ukraine. I hope, because the House has passed it already, that it will also pass in the Senate soon, and then the Dutch will be part of the Association Agreement, and I favour that very, very much. Secondly, should we punish the people of Ukraine for the fact that their country is under threat of Russian aggression and that there is illegal annexation of the Crimea and illegal Russian intervention in Eastern Ukraine? Should we punish them for that? No, of course, and it means that tomorrow we will vote and I am sure we will vote in a positive manner for visa liberalisation, because the criteria have been met. There is this safeguard and the emergency brake in the biometric passport, so it is now time to say ‘yes’ to free people in a free country.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: - After discussing the sad issue for the whole of the European Union this morning, Brexit, we now have the opportunity to do one thing that will contribute to building a bigger and better Europe: the abolition of visas for Ukrainian citizens.Visa waiver and the right to travel freely within the European Union are one of the most effective instruments of the European Union's external policy.We need to apply it carefully and in a measured way, especially to those countries that want to be European.Ukraine has long shown that it deserves to take advantage of this opportunity offered by the European Union.At the same time, it will be our best gift to all pro-European forces in Ukraine, with the clear message that it can receive more in exchange for the country's Europeanisation.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: - Mr President, the Commission is proposing to exempt Ukrainians from the visa requirement to enter the Union. I am resolutely opposed to this proposal, because the Commission itself presents it as, and I quote: "a development of the Schengen acquis". However, I am against Schengen, the obvious failure of which has just been noted by a report from the French Senate. I condemn, on the other hand, this eagerness of the Union to collaborate with the sinister regime of President Poroshenko. The UN Human Rights Council has revealed that it practices torture against those suspected of separatism. More generally, Ukraine no longer meets European standards. The law is poorly respected there. Prosecutor General Lutsenko has recorded a 25% increase in crime in the country. As for corruption, it is doing better than ever. President Poroshenko unfortunately sets a bad example by signing contracts with company boss Poroshenko, that is, with himself. According to Forbes magazine, his personal fortune increased by $ 320 million in two years. Under these conditions, it is unacceptable to award such an award to Ukraine. The Union must come to terms with itself and stop being blinded by its hatred of Russia.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Mr President, we have just heard the infiltration of Putin in this European Parliament from my colleague in ENF. Finally, the people of Ukraine will be granted visa-free travel. It is about time. It is a concrete step to fulfil the Maidan dream. The aspiration of a Ukraine closer to Europe for the people, by the people. Ukraine has fulfilled all the criteria in record time; even more impressive, they made it while under attack by Russia, which is waging a proxy war. Let us be honest: few countries today pay such a high price for its democratic aspiration. More than 10 000 Ukrainians have died defending our shared values of peace, democracy and freedom. More than 1.5 million are displaced, many of whom are children fleeing for their lives. With visa-free travel, finally the EU delivers visible results for the people, showing them that there is progress. Visa liberalisation is about people-to-people contacts, facilitating mutual understanding, respect and friendship. Now a Ukrainian entrepreneur can meet his business partner in the EU without tiring paperwork. Tourists, young people, can travel to Europe without waiting in line in embassies, and parents can spontaneously go and meet their children living on the other side of the border. This exchange is in our common interest. It has strengthened our partnership and our economy, and the EU should now give the green light and implement the visa-free regime without delay. Ukraine has done its part; we have to do ours.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs where I am rapporteur for the report on the Visa Code, I have always been in favor of visa facilitation and voted in favor of the Visa exemption for Ukrainian citizens with biometric passports, as Ukraine has long granted such a visa exemption to European citizens. Ukraine has passed the six progress reports that have been necessary to complete this file, the latest in December 2015, within the framework of the Association Agreement that was solemnly signed here, in this European Parliament, and simultaneously in the Verkhovna Rada - the Ukrainian Parliament - in September 2015. That does not mean that there are no problems. Among them, that legislative procedure that tries to impose electronic declarations of interests and assets to civil associations that fight against corruption, as if they had to have the same treatment as politicians, how much commitment they have to show against corruption in a country like Ukraine. But the truth is that this Parliament has an obligation to enforce the rule of law, as it did when it protested the annexation of Crimea or Sevastopol by the Russian Federation.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: - Anyone who knows me will know that I have always been a supporter of a short-stay visa waiver for citizens of Ukraine. The Visa Liberalization Action Plan has been the engine for far-reaching reforms. Not least in the fight against corruption. In late 2013 and early 2014, I stood several times on Maidan Square in Kiev, next to a multitude of people who yearned for a society without corruption, for respect for the rule of law. We must recognize that a great deal of effort has been made, but also that there is still a long way to go. And it is precisely with visas that is unfortunately still cheated. In Kiev, shadowy businesses that sell visas, which openly advertise on the internet and circumvent the Schengen rules, remain active. They are shifting their scope to long-term visas with a view to visa waiver. I call on our Ukrainian friends to really speed up the fight against such rogue practices. All our Member States and the European Commission must also cooperate to ensure that the rules of the game are respected for all and to stop visa fraud.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: - Mr President,I am very pleased that the negotiations are nearing completion and that Ukraine will finally receive the long-awaited visa waiver.By voting in favor of visa liberalization tomorrow, we are, in fact, acknowledging Ukraine's reforms to date, especially judicial and administrative reform.An e-procurement platform has also been launched and corruption is being fought.These developments are not only due to public officials, but very much to civil society.We are very often told that one of the things that works better in Ukraine than elsewhere is civil society - it is the people's own activity and volunteering that makes officials act.I am therefore saddened by the confusion created by e-declarations and the recent decision by Ukraine that non-profit organizations and civil society organizations must also disclose all their assets according to the same rules.I hope that the Ukrainian Government will find a solution and that these associations will be released from this obligation.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: - Mr. President, always more, always more demagoguery, always more excess. In the end, the European Union is not teaching us anything at all. All that can be said is that after enlargement to twenty-eight, soon to thirty-four with Turkey and visa liberalization, the European Union is ultimately a place where the we accept everyone without looking closely at the provenance. In any case, our group is quite clear. As with Turkey, we are against, resolutely against visa liberalization. We believe that Ukraine is not a friend of Europe. We cannot accommodate everyone and we cannot pay for everyone. In fact, Mr Rapporteur, what you want in your report is only to keep Ukraine away from Russia. This is what you want to do. You don't want to integrate it, but move it away from Russia. We are therefore continuing on bad roads and, in my opinion, the European Union will suffer from this excess of migrants and the liberalization of visas.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr. President, granting a visa-free regime is a very tangible act of support from the European Union to citizens of Ukraine. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur for her continuous efforts to make it happen. I closely monitor the current state of reforms, and I must say that the progress made in the past two or three years is truly unprecedented. Ukraine is on a very ambitious path to create a properly-functioning economy in a democratic political system with the ultimately aim to finish the transition from post-Soviet to European state. A lot of progress was made regarding the required reforms, especially in the field of judiciary, the fight against corruption, strengthening the democratic institutions, and the rule of law. There is a lot of work ahead for the full implementation of these reforms, especially considering a very difficult fight to regain full territorial integrity of the country. Therefore, I am very happy that this House is taking an important step to enable Ukrainian citizens to travel without visa. By this, we are showing to the Ukrainian people, but also to the outside world, that you want stronger connection and more shared experiences, and I firmly believe that it is going to be to the mutual benefit of us all.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, I don't understand why we still use such atavism as visa regime for our European neighbours. What is the reason of keeping it? We have a lot of security lists of terror suspects, criminals and other persons that are for any reason denied entry to the EU. Border guards have access to these databases, and any people from these lists will not be allowed to cross the border. Other countries’ citizens who wanted to travel to the EU without visas are required to have very well-protected biometric passports, which many of the European Union states’ citizens do not have. Individuals may be asked to show documents proving purpose and conditions of stay; for example, tickets for further journeys and return tickets, reservation of accommodation and invitation letter, as well as evidence of sufficient means of subsistence. In case of doubt, the person could be not allowed to enter the EU. Now we have a special suspension mechanism, when the Commission can pause a visa-free regime for a concrete country if some migration criminal or some other concerns will appear. What additional options to this list of protection measures give with the regime? At the same time, millions of migrants come through the Mediterranean without any visas or documents from very problematic from the security point of view regions, but we are still afraid to grant a visa-free regime for such states as Georgia recently, Ukraine or Belarus in the future. It reminds us of a door with twenty locks, but there is still a huge gap in the wall nearby.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: -  Mister President! Yes, there is a lot of talk about so-called reforms in Ukraine. But the constant exchange of government members alone speaks a different language. And the mere fact that around a third of Ukrainians, namely 15 million, apparently want to leave their country acutely speaks open words and open volumes. With this visa liberalization - this is what this report also says - the course is clearly set in the direction of full membership in the Union. I think this is very flawed for several reasons. Apart from the unanswered questions such as corruption, nepotism, fundamental freedoms and human rights, the necessary development costs for the member states and especially for the net contributors would amount to horrific billions and would mean an additional budget burden. The Union is therefore well advised to actually take the Copenhagen criteria that it has set itself seriously and to draw lessons from the enlargement problems of recent years. Ultimately, this step is not suitable for improving relations with Russia. On the contrary: the Union risks being drawn into the ongoing conflict between Russia and Ukraine as a partner.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: - Dear Mr. PRESIDENT! I am pleased that tomorrow we will finally be able to vote on the visa-free entry of Ukrainian citizens into the European Union. This can be a successful completion of a long process, for which a lot of Ukrainian citizens have sacrificed and worked hard. With visa-free travel, hundreds of thousands of people have the opportunity to travel freely and study abroad. The contact of the Hungarian, Bulgarian, Romanian, Slovak, Polish and other minority communities living in Ukraine with the motherland may be simplified. However, it also has physical limitations: the backwardness or lack of border infrastructure, the road network and border crossings, so if we want to provide tangible help to citizens, the EU must develop an effective plan and provide funding to improve them. This would eliminate the hours of waiting at the borders, and we could ensure entry conditions of European standard. Ukraine needs to be supported in implementing the necessary reforms through foreign and domestic policy and economic stabilization. The EU must send clear signals to Ukraine that democratization and the pursuit of European integration are not enough to be declared, but must be borne in mind in the measures. Thus, for example, it is unacceptable for the linguistic and educational rights of minorities living in a country to be curtailed in a discriminatory manner or to allow extremist groups to create tensions between the majority and minorities. Therefore, the aspect of social consolidation and peaceful coexistence based on mutual respect and the development of legal certainty must play an important role in the work of legislators.

name: Kati PIRI
text: - It is good news that the visa waiver for Ukraine is finally being finalized. The country has undertaken difficult reforms to meet all the conditions and it is only natural that the EU will also keep its side of the bargain. These are difficult times for the Ukrainian people. Part of the country has been illegally annexed and in the east, Russia is doing everything it can to disrupt the country. Ukraine's continued focus on closer cooperation with the EU contributes to democratic development in the country. Hopefully, this agreement will motivate the government to pursue the reforms in the field of rule of law and the necessary fight against corruption. The new legislation that makes work more difficult for anti-corruption activists and journalists must therefore be dropped. This visa waiver is not a gift to Ukraine, but a tangible result for the people of a country, which means that cooperation with Europe goes beyond purely economic interests. In other words, Europe is more than just a market, and with a targeted foreign policy it can certainly ensure positive and democratic developments in the countries around us. For all these reasons, I would like to congratulate the Ukrainians on the fact that they will soon be able to easily travel to the EU to visit family, go on a business trip or to go on vacation, without having to go through a lengthy and often derogatory visa procedure . That is why I say “Congratulations!” Here, also in Ukrainian: “Vitajoe!”.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: - Mr President, Ukraine experiences such levels of misery and corruption that a large part of the population has come to regret the Soviet yoke, that is to say. The fact that Ukraine was awarded by the European Union, last November, more than 300 million euros and, again this week, a billion dollars by the IMF, is only a chance for the oligarchy, which diverts 15% of the national budget. Visa liberalization on the ridiculous pretext of deepening people-to-people contacts - this is in the Commission document - cannot hide a new political maneuver. It will be devastating for the workers of the Union, who will be subjected to increased competition from an illegally exploitable workforce, at any cost, since the average salary there is 180 euros per month and pensions of 64 euros. It will be devastating for European citizens, ideal prey for criminal gangs, whose activities will be facilitated. Finally, it will be devastating for Ukraine, which will end up draining of its vitality after the country has already lost more than ten million inhabitants.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Mr President, Ukraine is a special partner for the EU, not only because it is a very important country in our Eastern Partnership, but also because of the way the Ukrainian people were outstandingly clear in showing their support for European values. I have to say that many doubts could be cast on how the EU has actually reacted following the Euromaidan, but what matters today is the result. Better late than never, the moment has finally come to grant visa liberalisation to Ukrainian citizens. This is the minimum reward the EU can grant for their attachment and loyalty to the EU and European values. We need to praise Ukraine for managing to undertake the necessary reforms in an extremely difficult environment – I would say wartime – imposed by Russia, considering that it has to dedicate great efforts and resources to a conflict that is in fact a direct consequence of the European choice that the Ukrainian citizens have made. Now that the time has come for the free visa regime, I hope that the next step can be the ratification by the Dutch senate of the EU—Ukrainian Association Agreement. We cannot allow such an important agreement – another sign of reciprocal commitment between the EU and Ukraine – to continue to remain under a big question mark. Ukraine desperately needs and deserves, first and foremost, our support to end the conflict in eastern Ukraine and to preserve its territorial integrity, which was not only challenged but destroyed by Russia. But they also need to advance reforms in several fields to enhance their economy, and it is evident that to do so they need clear and tangible signs from our side.

name: Michał BONI
text: - I am not only replacing Maria Gabriel today, but I also have my own speech. This is a very important day. Let us recall the civic courage and tragic heroism of Maidan, which in 2014 became the true heart of Europe, renewing the meaning of the European Union in its freedom and economic dimension. And let us remember the choice that the Ukrainian people made during this Revolution of Dignity. This is the way to Europe and together with Europe. The reforms implemented in Ukraine are difficult, but as much has been done to fight corruption, transparency of the banking sector, decentralization of the state, increasing energy independence, digital administration services, economic recovery, in order to achieve: -9% of GDP from: + 2% of GDP. There are still many difficult tasks ahead of Ukraine, but we must remember a simple fact. Ukraine is changing for the better under the conditions of war. Russia took Crimea and occupied the eastern part of the country. Almost two million people have lost their homes and are wandering around the country. Which country would be able to change so wisely and efficiently under the pressure of war? Which country would be able to meet all the visa liberalization requirements under such conditions? That is why we are pleased with our decision on visa liberalization for Ukraine. This is not a gift. It is an expression of our respect for the European path that Ukraine has chosen. And this is a right for Ukrainian citizens, developed by themselves.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, at the last plenary session I made an intervention in this House on the constant aggressions to which Ukraine and its citizens are subjected by their Russian neighbors. Here, too, I had the opportunity to warn of Russia's expansionist threat in Ukraine, which at that moment was revealed by the assassination, in Ukraine, of the critic of Putin's regime, Denis Voronenkov. Denis Voronenkov was, nothing more, nothing less, than one of the main witnesses of the Russian aggression against Ukraine. I also had the opportunity to call for the immediate entry of visa liberalization to Ukrainian citizens who three years ago in Maidan Square fought for Ukraine to become more European. Tomorrow we will finally vote in this House for an instrument that will allow for easier movement, or better, freedom of movement for Ukrainian citizens within the European Union. I hope, therefore, tomorrow, and on behalf of the thousands of Ukrainians who have chosen my country to live in, Portugal, to be able to congratulate my colleagues in this assembly for making this important strategic instrument feasible for a more prosperous, safe and stable neighborhood.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, it is no coincidence that I am already the fourth Member of the Czech Republic in today's debate on visa liberalization, because the Czech Republic is recruiting thousands of Ukrainian workers.We have experience with them and we have a great understanding for them.I think that by adding Ukraine to the list of countries whose inhabitants are exempt from the visa requirement, we are sending a clear signal that we are counting on Ukraine, and it is also an appreciation of the reform efforts that Ukraine has had to fulfill.Visa liberalization is not free, they have reformed the judiciary, public administration, anti-corruption measures, legislative changes, all in a very difficult political and especially security situation, because in eastern Ukraine is still fighting and there is no peace.I very much wish Ukraine this success and it is also the fulfillment of the wishes of the young generation who want to live together with Europe.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, before reaching visa liberalization with Ukraine, the progress made by the country of the former Soviet Union in political and civil matters and its approximation to the fundamental principles of the European Union were the subject of constant scrutiny by the European institutions. Since the start of the dialogue, which started in October 2008, the Commission has published 6 progress reports on the progress made in implementing the plan and Ukraine has embarked on an important path of democratic transformation following the 2014 presidential elections. significant progress in border control, the fight against corruption, organized crime and money laundering and the support of the European Union has been a lever in addressing such serious problems. The issuance of biometric passports made according to international standards will allow Ukrainian citizens to enter Europe and vice versa, according to the principle of reciprocity. The European Union will have to undertake to ensure and monitor compliance with the partnership conditions even after liberalization, maintaining a solid and fruitful relationship with Ukraine.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Mr President, thank you for your gesture as well, because it is not entirely normal, and thank you very much for that. Let me also say a few words about what we are discussing here today. I think we should first and foremost think about the security of our citizens and the citizens of the European Union. And the fact that paper can withstand everything is simply a fact. Let's look at the reality in Ukraine. Without international financial assistance, it would not be able to survive and go bankrupt. Without different security forces paying attention to different security forces today, none of them would work there. Teachers do not receive salaries, doctors do not receive salaries and, above all, no one is able to ensure that passports that are allegedly issued to Ukrainian citizens are really only issued to Ukrainian citizens. I understand the political gesture that you want to help Ukraine in some way, but I am not sure whether this is help or rather evil for Ukraine itself and for the security of European citizens. You will only allow the Ukrainian citizens to leave Ukraine, and those that Ukraine will one day need, so that they simply do not stay there and are in Europe. And even with a security risk.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, from this interesting debate I dare to think that there is a large consensus in this House on the need to keep the promises we made to the Ukrainian citizens. This is also the recognition of the sustained and comprehensive reform efforts which have been carried out by the Ukrainian authorities, particularly in the field of border management, the fight against corruption and anti-discrimination. We will hereby fulfil a longstanding demand by Ukrainian citizens and also facilitate interpersonal contacts and cooperation. With the revised suspension mechanism in place, there is no need to delay this important file any further.  I therefore call on you all to proceed with the vote on Ms Gabriel’s report and to bring us one step closer to the conclusion of the whole procedure to grant visa-free travel for Ukrainian citizens.

name: Michał BONI
text: deputising for the rapporteur. – Mr President, very briefly, thank you for the very comprehensive debate. It was focused on visa liberalisation for Ukraine, but many problems and topics were also raised relating to the future cooperation between the European Union and Ukraine. Those key topics are: implementation of the DCFTA; the next steps of their reforms; our common cooperation related to border solutions; and also the problem of war and Russian aggression. I think that it was very fruitful and we are thinking about further cooperation with Ukraine. Also, we are considering how to support Ukraine in taking some steps that are important for NGOs, civil society. I know the President established a special working group for solving the problem of this declaration of financial interest which was addressed also to civil society.  All of those issues are very serious, and I have talked about serious interventions during this debate – not the extreme propaganda which was also presented during this debate.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 6 April 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - Honorable Members! Today, it is very important that you send your positive messages to citizens within the borders of the Union, but also beyond. Originally from Serbia, I have personal experience with visa requirements. In the early 2000s, we snaked in long lines in front of consulates and embassies of EU Member States to obtain visas. Mostly young people who wanted to know "Europe". We felt like second-class Europeans, who were afraid of the EU and who were seen as a source of danger. In Ukraine, as in the Western Balkans, there is a great need for the EU to have a presence and increase its influence. If we miss the opportunity to consolidate our position, others will take our place, further increasing the potential sources of danger that could call into question the future of Europe. That is why I am asking everyone to vote in favor of this report. Thank you for listening.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: in writing. - I fully support the unconditional lifting of the visa regime for Ukraine, because it is an important signal confirming the country's pro-European aspirations. The European Commission regularly monitored Ukraine's compliance with the liberalization criteria and concluded that Ukraine met all of them. As a consequence, the European Commission presented a proposal to amend Regulation 539 of 2001, i.e. to include Ukraine in the second Annex covering the countries whose citizens are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external border of the Schengen area. After the entry into force of this regulation, Ukrainian citizens who have biometric passports will be able to enter the territory of the European Union without visas for a period of 90 days within six months for tourist purposes. Visa liberalization for Ukraine is an important step that will help Ukrainian citizens in reforms and bring them closer to us. I am convinced that they fully deserve the right to travel freely to the European Union.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- The decision on visa liberalization is a major step in strengthening EU-Ukraine relations.We have been waiting for this for a long time, because Ukraine is an active member of the EU's Eastern Partnership program, and visa liberalization between the EU and Ukraine will also strengthen relations between people and civil society.The Ukrainian people also need clear moral support for the ongoing hostilities in eastern Ukraine, and the decision to grant visa-free travel is not only a political and practical influence, but also a clear expression of the EU's moral support.In addition, it should not be forgotten that years ago, Ukraine unilaterally introduced visa-free travel for EU citizens.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the situation in Venezuela (2017/2651(RSP)).

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, almost a year ago, in May 2016, High Representative/Vice—President Federica Mogherini was here in this plenary discussing the worrying situation in Venezuela with you. Since then the political, social and economic situation in the country has not improved. The political polarisation and institutional confrontation has further escalated, the economic situation is dire, the shortage of food and medicines has increased, there are reports of alarming child malnutrition, and the insecurity is only getting worse. I would therefore like to thank the Parliament for the continuous attention you have been paying to the situation in Venezuela. Today’s discussion is timely as the dialogue between the government and the opposition has stalled and the country urgently needs to find a peaceful and democratic solution to this crisis. Important efforts by the Vatican and UNASUR facilitators to establish a dialogue between government and opposition have been taking place since May 2016. Unfortunately, although the first two sessions of the dialogue in October and November had encouraging results, the commitments were not respected. The establishment of an electoral calendar, respect for the National Assembly’s access to external assistance to address the most urgent needs of the population, and the release of political prisoners, remain key issues on which there has been little or no progress.  The EU has not been observing the situation passively. We have been providing political and diplomatic support with a view to a meaningful and effective dialogue that can bring lasting and democratic solutions within the constitutional framework and in full respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms. To this end, we continue our constant contacts with countries in the region and beyond, and with international and regional organisations from the United Nations to the OAS and UNASUR, to share views and coordinate actions wherever and whenever appropriate. The EU has repeatedly been calling for respect for the Constitution, democratic principles, the rule of law and the separation and independence of powers which are crucial for the country to achieve a peaceful outcome to the current difficult situation. That is why we reacted immediately to the recent rulings of the Venezuelan Supreme Court suppressing the competences of the National Assembly and the immunity of parliamentarians, calling for full respect of the constitutional role of the National Assembly and for the immunity of its members. For the democratic order to be guaranteed Venezuela needs to establish an electoral calendar, as foreseen in the Constitution, and to organise elections that are free, fair and inclusive. In 2017 the election of governors should be a priority. The EU remains ready to reinforce its support to help address the most urgent needs of the population, thus contributing to dealing with current humanitarian challenges. For the moment, our assistance remains limited due to difficulties of access to the country and it focuses on the distribution of food and medicines to the most vulnerable population, but other possibilities of support are also being explored.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr. president; Thank you Commissioner Jourová. Again the European Parliament must deal with Venezuela. It is an inexcusable obligation and while we do it, ladies and gentlemen, the Venezuelan people with the opposition leaders at the forefront are gassed in a brutal repression of the Bolivarian regime. That the Supreme Court strip the Legislative of its powers and assume its functions accurately describes the totalitarian behavior that characterizes a dictatorship. What happened next was pathetic if it weren't the clearest proof of the absence of a division of powers. The attorney general denounces the breakdown of the constitutional order and restores the previous situation. Unfortunately, ladies and gentlemen, it all seems that the same hand rocks the cradle. How long, Mr. President Maduro, are you going to abuse the patience of a people who own a rich country, who are starving and suffering poverty due to the action of a satrap who will once again accuse the European Parliament of interference? It is time to say loud and clear, in the words of the Secretary General of the OAS, that the defense of democracy is not interventionist; and, furthermore, that "a parody of democracy is not democracy." The next thing to do is denounce that the mission of the mediators who tried in good faith the path of dialogue has failed. It is time to demand from the Maduro regime the immediate release of all political prisoners, the establishment of a channel to preserve humanitarian assistance, the return to constitutional order, with full respect for the National Assembly and its decisions. Finally, it is also the inexcusable time for the European Union and the High Representative to make compatible, ladies and gentlemen, diplomatic forms with a firmer position in which the Venezuelan people feel encouraged by the European Union and regain hope for freedom. And furthermore, Commissioner, you do not have to make elections for governors, you have to make the election of the president of the Republic, which is what the people of Venezuela demand.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (PT) Mr President, Commissioner, on March 29, the Supreme Court of Justice of Venezuela withdrew its powers from the National Assembly and assumed its functions, thus calling into question the principle of separation of powers and seriously offending the main democratic principles. Days later, in the midst of enormous international pressure, the Supreme Court reversed, trying to convince Venezuelans that everything was, at bottom, a kind of misunderstanding. In addition, cynically, Nicolás Maduro sought to appear as a virtuous arbitrator who would have resolved the matter in an expeditious and effective manner. The truth, however, is different. The truth is that the autocratic regime never accepted the result of the December 2015 elections. We cannot forget that soon, on January 11, 2016, the Supreme Court of Justice - which the regime handles as it sees fit - decreed that the National Assembly he was in contempt, and therefore all acts emanating from him were null. And even then, the same court threatened to resort to the Constitution and replace Parliament. What happened was not, therefore, a mere madness. But something is changing in Venezuela. Nicolás Maduro's turnaround reveals that his strategy of antagonizing the opposition has apparently reached its limit. Maduro's turnaround shows that, after all, there is a red line. This red line has been drawn - or is beginning to be drawn, and we believe that - within the officiality itself. This was openly done by the Attorney General of Venezuela, Luísa Ortega Díaz, who spoke of a rupture in the constitutional order, but also in an invisible way, apparently, by some military hierarchies. This is a positive fact. It means that there are segments in the sphere of influence of officialism that do not fully adhere to the strategy followed so far and that, despite everything, are not willing to abdicate some constitutional principles basic.The climate of political polarization in Venezuela today has reached such a point that it can only be clarified through elections.In the meantime, Venezuela's economic, social and humanitarian crisis requires the promotion of a dialogue between the executive and the legislature.We believe that this is the path that must be followed.But in the meantime, we have to make, once again, a very strong and very clear call to promote the release of political prisoners who are incarcerated in Venezuela's jails and to proceed to the marking of the regional elections that should have already taken place.accomplished.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, it is almost a year since we last discussed Venezuela in this House. Given that at the time we had just witnessed the assassination of the opposition leader Mavare, it is difficult to believe that a year on from that situation, the situation in Venezuela is actually worse. National Assembly elections held in December 2015 saw President Maduro’s party lose to the opposition. However, this has led to little change, given Maduro’s and his government’s efforts to block all of the National Assembly’s initiatives. Having initially been achieved by means of using the Supreme Court to strip the assembly of its power, Maduro is now reverting to the far more conventional dictatorial tactics of arresting opposition politicians and sheer brutality. Continuing to cling on to power in these circumstances is concerning, given the situation on the streets, and it is difficult to see that the current situation is tenable until the  scheduled Presidential elections in October of 2017. As Venezuela’s economic model collapses, food shortages and street riots are becoming more frequent parts of everyday life. So therefore, early free and fair elections are clearly a must, and we should do all we can in the European Union to support the democratic process before it becomes a total dictatorship.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr. president; Thank you, Commissioner Jourová, for bringing us Mrs Mogherini's message. Hugo Chávez came to power with a left-wing populist speech, promising little less than paradise. Today, Venezuela is a political prison and a social catastrophe. Let's learn the lesson. Populism is the way to dictatorship: institutions have been assaulted and subdued; crime has taken over the streets and offices. The corruption of Chavismo is total: there is no independent justice, no trace of the rule of law remains. Democracy, finally, has been blown up. The European Union must fully support the Organization of American States in its demand that constitutional order be restored in Venezuela. The dialogue process has failed. Mrs. Mogherini, who refuses to acknowledge that Leopoldo López is a political prisoner is disqualified as a mediator, and I am talking about José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero. Europe must send an unequivocal message to the Maduro regime: all political prisoners must be released, elections must be held now, and humanitarian aid must reach the people in need. The self-proclaimed European left, the Podemos and Izquierda Unida, tried to prevent this debate. They do not want us to remind them of their connection and collusion with Chavismo. Denounce the narco-corruption of the Venezuelan regime, acknowledge the humanitarian crisis that plagues the country, demand an end to the brutal political repression, or do not dare to give us a single lesson in democracy again.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr. President, while in Mexico the umpteenth journalist was assassinated and another mass grave was found, while in Paraguay there were violent demonstrations against the president, Parliament was burned and opponents were assassinated, the OAS, that ministry of colonies, was dedicated to look the other way and continue with the destabilizing obsession of its biggest arsonist, Mr. Almagro. Faced with dialogue, confrontation; in the face of constitutional mechanisms, interference; in the face of the truth, the lie, accompanied by violent protests. Why does the OAS not denounce the contempt of the National Assembly, which incorporates deputies who bought votes, who without constitutional powers try to remove an elected president and who disobeys judicial decisions? Faced with this repeated ignorance of the constitutional order, there was a conflict between the public powers that was constitutionally resolved through peaceful means and dialogue. Instead of holding and supporting the dialogue, the OAS convened the Permanent Council, unaware that the Bolivian presidency suspended the meeting because it had not been notified. Not even so, violating their own Regulations, did they get a majority to continue with their plan against an elected power. Interventionist adventures must be stopped, because to destabilize Venezuela is to destabilize Latin America. The EU must not support violent options: it must accompany the dialogue between Unasur and the Vatican.
