It is up to Venezuela to solve its problems, and to the European Union, to respect sovereignty and international law. The opposite is a great hypocrisy.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr. President, one more debate on Venezuela. I think that, obviously, the decision of the Supreme Court to grant itself the powers of the Assembly was a very serious mistake, and I think we should celebrate that this very serious mistake was corrected. And it would be necessary and it would be more pertinent if a normal functioning of the Assembly could be reestablished, also resolving the dispute that exists over those three deputies who are, at this moment, an obvious element of concern. At this time there is —and our Group shares it— a concern about the confrontational spiral that may come, about the political confrontation that is sensed and that could degrade the situation in the country. That is why it is necessary, at this time - and we want to call for calm - to seek and help as much as possible to have the necessary mechanisms of relaxation. The dynamics of entrenchment between institutions do not help - they prevent a solution - and it is necessary that we can help to find mechanisms of normal constitutional functioning mutually accepted by everyone. Therefore, we believe that it is time to redouble international diplomatic efforts for mediation, especially from Latin American organizations, especially the work that Unasur can do and also the work - which I believe and consider that they are doing very well. - of the three former presidents - Mr. Zapatero, Mr. Trujillo and Mr. Fernández - in order to find a negotiated and agreed solution and to ease the situation a bit. And I would invite - although these calls that we make from my group are usually ignored - that we try, in April II, to present a resolution that helps dialogue and defuse, and not a resolution that, on the contrary, further ignites the situation.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the ENF group.- Mr President, Commissioner, the chaotic situation in Venezuela must call for a measured response on our part.The end of the oil manna has certainly revealed the inadequacies of the political and economic system built by President Chávez.The endless queues for basic necessities are reminiscent of the final decay of other regimes based on economic principles of collectivism.This social crisis is coupled with political instability, of which President Maduro's obstinacy seems to be the main driving force.However, European Union interference is not justified.Let us beware of endorsing opposition movements of which we do not know the ins and outs.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, yesterday the President of Germany made a truly admirable speech in this very Chamber. He said that whoever undermines the action of parliaments undermines democracy. The Government of Venezuela no longer has any legitimacy, suspended in Mercosur, condemned by the OAS, it is really a Government that violates the Constitution, imprisons dissidents, closes the media such as the NTN24 channel and has led to a very rich country economic ruin. Commissioner, he speaks of a peaceful solution. The split face yesterday of the opposition deputies Juan Requesens, María Corina Machado and others is a metaphor for what is happening today with democracy in Venezuela: beaten, battered and bloody, it remains standing thanks to courageous men and women that in jail, on the street and in Parliament they fight peacefully for their freedom and for their dignity and for having a very basic thing that is free elections in Venezuela.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: - Mr. President, it is clear that given the serious crisis that Venezuela is suffering, we have to condemn the abuses of power, without a doubt. But I don't think we can stop at that. If we want to help the dear Venezuelan people, I think we have to do something else. It is also evident that by curtailing the independence of the National Assembly, a new wound has been inflicted on Venezuelan democracy, which is what we have to rescue. The step backwards that have been taken also justifies - I believe - that we give a vote of confidence to the mediation efforts that are underway. I believe that the European Union must continue to support the efforts that seek a solution to the Venezuelan conflict based on law, based on dialogue and based on reconciliation. Precisely because of the high level of confrontation that exists at this time, we tell the Government, we tell the institutions that they have to comply with the Constitution, that the Constitution is there for that, to comply with it, and that democracy is what needs to be done function. Democracy, what for? Democracy to strengthen institutions, democracy for the free exercise of politics and democracy also for reconciliation. For all this, the Government of Venezuela has to take steps; For all this, we need, from the European Union, to reinforce the efforts that exist so that mediation leads to a true reconciliation, because I do not know what the other solution is. The other solution is the confrontation in the streets, probably, and then we will be able to do very little. Today we still have to call for an attempt at dialogue and reconciliation.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: - Mr. President, what we saw last week in Venezuela is not surprising: it is the continuation of what Nicolás Maduro has been doing for years, silencing the voice of the people, undermining democracy to consolidate his power;in essence, taking all the steps to turn Venezuela into a true dictatorship.For two years I have been calling for more action from the European Union.Together with my colleague Teresa Jiménez Becerril, I wrote a letter to the high representative, asking for a change of approach regarding Venezuela.I am very happy to have received an affirmative answer last week.Ms Mogherini rightly acknowledged that it cannot continue as before and that all available options must be considered.I hope that words turn into action and that we can firmly support the Venezuelan people.I ask again that our position be firm and that, in addition, the option of selective sanctions be considered.

name: João FERREIRA
text: - Mr President, at the time of the alternative facts, these are the real facts that the majority of this Parliament insists on hiding. Between 99 and 2006, unemployment fell in Venezuela by more than ten percentage points. At the end of 2015, Venezuela had lower unemployment than the European Union or Canada. Poverty levels and extreme poverty have dropped significantly and more sharply than the average in Latin America. The number of families with unmet basic needs has significantly decreased. Venezuela has risen several places in the United Nations human development index. Social inequality indicators have decreased. According to FAO, Venezuela has reduced child malnutrition and is now a country free from hunger. The number of university students enrolled more than tripled. This is the reality that causes some to distill anger and hatred towards Venezuela and that makes them support, without reservation and without shame, the boycott, violence and economic, social and political destabilization.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - As we have heard from some predecessors and, of course, the last one, we are obviously receiving various information about Venezuela, so what is actually happening in this country. On the one hand, we are receiving information that the country is under a serious test, including humanitarian crises, including political ones. On the other hand, some warn that the situation is not as scary as it seems. In any case, it seems important that in this situation it is also the duty of the European Parliament to get a realistic picture of the situation in the country and that, of course, we are not just subject to provocations that may not reflect the real situation. In any case, the European Parliament must support all those actions that promote and therefore enable democracy, and above all I think that the European Parliament must always go in the direction of supporting peace and stability in third countries and thus promoting development and aid in the case of humanitarian or the economic crisis in which these countries may find themselves. Let me remind you that the situation in Venezuela is very important for the stability and peace of the entire Latin American region, and any conflicts, armed conflicts in this area can of course spread like wildfire to other areas, so it is important that the European Parliament it plays an important role, especially in supporting, as I have already said, missions that will show what the real situation is and what is happening in this country. In any case, every country that finds itself in difficulties and in economically unsustainable conditions needs help and support. At the same time, we must not forget that views on democracy can be different, they can also be explained completely differently, but it is true that in the end always as the greatest monument and of course the fact of democracy is decided or the elections are decided by individual countries, and this is also the case in Venezuela.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, twenty years of Chavez and Maduro’s Bolivarian Socialism has led a potentially rich country to the implosion of both democracy and economy. This must be the end phase of Leftist populism, which as a rule results in economic impotence, cynical disregard of citizens and authoritarian exercise of power. The latest attack on the independence of the Parliament by a judiciary which has lost independence could well become the last straw. Since Maduro took power, almost 7 000 citizens have been detained; there are now 114 political prisoners. The European Commission’s reaction to the suppression of the last vestiges of democracy must be more forceful and determined. Today we must send a very clear signal that the European Parliament stands unconditionally together with Venezuelan citizens, for their dignity and rights.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: - Mr. President, I share with many of you that democracy is in danger in Venezuela. I share it; I could even add myself to almost all the sentences that are being made. But be careful, ladies and gentlemen, because what is also in danger is citizen peace in Venezuela; Attention, because there are two legitimate powers there - beyond the fact that the Government has been delegitimized in the exercise of power - two legitimate powers of origin, facing each other. Two peoples that are beginning to confront each other dangerously and two political projects that are hating each other. What is at risk is the future of that country and, since we want Venezuela and we want peace in Venezuela, what we have to establish is exactly our role. And, ladies and gentlemen, I dare not consider the dialogue for dead. I know it may be very wrong, but those who consider dialogue for dead, what do they offer me? What do we Europeans offer to Venezuela? What do we give them? Because to condemn the Government, we have already done it; support the opposition, we already do. But what else do we do, ladies and gentlemen? Only a political, democratic agreement supported by the international community between these two powers will provide a solution to the future of Venezuela. Only a democratic, but peaceful process that can be agreed upon and supported by the international community. Why haven't the Vatican, the United States and the European Union itself stopped supporting dialogue? Because it is necessary, ladies and gentlemen! Let's work on that.

name: Javier NART
text: - Mr. President, Latin America has suffered the tragedy of going from kleptocratic oligarchies to co-populist kleptocracies transvestite in revolutionaries. In Venezuela, chavomadurismo has impoverished it. Perhaps the highest-income country in South America, a country that swims in abundance due to its oil income. And a country that impoverishes its people is deeply reactionary. But it is also that we speak of a reactionary and dictatorial power. Because talking about a confrontation between the Executive and the Legislative is an aberration, in principle, since the Legislative has its own powers, but in Venezuela the Judicial Power is a scarecrow in the hands of the Government, the Legislative Power is castrated and the only thing that prevails is the Executive Power. There is also talk of avoiding confrontation. We don't like the confrontation, but it already exists and exists in the form not only of repression, but of armed militias: the Bolivarian militias, the Chavista militias. This House must take decisions that mean free elections, the release of prisoners and humanitarian aid.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: - Mr. President, within the constitutional framework, the Armed Forces of Venezuela must defend and protect its people or they will be held accountable to justice and history. Venezuela needs more than ever our political commitment, our solidarity and our help. The Chavista dictatorship in its harshest and cruellest version, oppressive of its people and that has impoverished its noble people, no longer has the speech or the resources to support a corrupt and liberticidal narco-regime. Europe, the OAS, the United Nations and all the free governments of the planet cry out against the oppressors. We are talking about a handcuffed Legislative, a domesticated and open judiciary, a dependent and partial electoral power, and an Executive that imprisons the best. They must go into exile peacefully in a nearby paradise and let Venezuelans regain their democratic destiny. Yes, exile for the Chavista leadership awaiting international justice, and peace and quiet for Venezuela. Democracy, bread, medicines and security. Citizens must suffer no more.

name: Nuno MELO
text: - Mr President, Venezuela, a sister country that welcomes more than one million Portuguese and Portuguese descendants is experiencing a tragedy. There is a lack of medicines, food, bread, light and water, respect. Whoever is opposed is beaten and imprisoned for the crime of opinion. Crime is out of control. Caracas is already the most dangerous city in the world. With Maduro, Christmas is on the first of November. He believes that Chávez appears to him in the form of a small bird and has decided that in the public service he only works two days a week. The Supreme Court's decision was just one more step on a crazy course of a drifting regime. A hundred years after the Bolshevik revolution Maduro shows the world that, every time Marxism - Leninism is power, national resources are transformed into misery and the people are impoverished. The extreme left here is on the side of dictatorial drifts, instead of defending democracy. We do not! Strength and hope for Venezuelan Democrats. Don't call yourself, never! Believe in your struggle because your struggle is just. A hug from the Portuguese Democrats.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: - Mr. President, the process of deterioration in Venezuela has intensified profoundly. Deterioration of the institutional political climate, especially deterioration of the situation in the National Assembly, subjected to permanent harassment since December 2015 and, as we have seen this weekend, the subject of a crazy decision by the Supreme Court, later also corrected in a way surprising. Serious deterioration in the economic and social situation, serious food and health crisis and rampant violence. And more than a hundred political prisoners remain without freedom. My message, Commissioner, to Mrs Mogherini, is that she and the European Union must become more involved in finding a solution to this serious situation. I don't quite understand your extreme containment and the maintenance of a line that has not borne any fruit. It is in stark contrast to the much more active position of the OAS and Mercosur itself. There are many principles that unite Europeans with the American peoples. The Venezuelan people ask the same thing that we have: respect for the rule of law and democracy and respect for fundamental rights. We cannot be silent or inactive. Mrs. Mogherini has to be more active.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: - Mr President, Venezuela is going through a delicate economic situation, with repercussions in political, social and security terms, which cannot leave us indifferent. The Portuguese community, the Portuguese-descendants, my fellow Madeira citizens, send me heartbreaking reports of a scenario of insecurity, extreme poverty, and losses in business activities that affect Portuguese and Venezuelans. I express, therefore, all my solidarity with the Venezuelan population, with the opportunity that the most absolute respect for democracy be exercised in your country, in a veiled fight against crime, unemployment and poverty. In this message, I reiterate an appeal to the European Union, to the national governments for active support, with measures that lessen this state of social and economic emergency and that do not give up any and all support to all who need it in Venezuela. None of us can remain indifferent, under the penalty of seeing democracy succumb and the principle of respect and dignity for the human person.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I want to support colleagues who clearly condemn the current situation in Venezuela. I just want to reiterate that we recently, a few weeks or half a year ago, debated the situation in this country, and that situation has worsened again. What other than a constitutional coup is, as the Supreme Court ruled, when it assumed, quite absurdly, legislative power. It is a clear further attack by President Maduro and his subordinate powers in an effort to dismantle and completely destroy the rule of law and democracy in this country. So I think, like my colleagues, Commissioner, that the European executive must be much more active in putting pressure on Venezuela, but also in trying to help Venezuela as such. Today and every day, we read articles about the lack of medicines in Venezuela, the threat of a humanitarian catastrophe, and the lack of food. So, on the one hand, we must exert more international pressure, but we must also help ordinary Venezuelans who are suffering under the current dictatorial rule.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - We are talking again about the unfortunate Venezuela, a country ruled for decades by the regime of Hugo Chavez, a left-wing regime that at one point was even lucky that energy prices were very high, and also gave the impression of creating a modern state..The truth soon came to light and now that the regime of the authoritarian leader, Mr Maduro, is in power, we see what is really going on in Venezuela: political instability, poverty, the humanitarian crisis, the social and humanitarian crisis, the power of drug lords, corruption.it says everything that cannot be called democracy.We in the European Parliament have no choice but to take the side of those we promote to democracy and, together with the Vatican and the United Nations, fight, if you will, for the people who are unhappy in Venezuela.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Stop the bullshit that what goes on in Venezuela has anything to do with socialism.It is totalitarianism, stupidity and narco-corruption of President Maduro's regime, which looks very green but is, in fact, rotten.It is the people of Venezuela who pay the costs in their hard daily lives.In view of the strong connections of the people of Venezuela to European peoples - Spain and Portugal, in particular - it is unbelievable that the European Union and this Parliament are no longer involved in the release of political prisoners and in the search for a peaceful negotiated and democratic solutionthe dangerous stalemate that sectarianism and blindness led that country full of resources, but now living in misery and, perhaps, on the verge of civil war.Venezuela does not need a coup d'état like the one tried days ago.Yes, it urgently needs free and fair elections under international supervision.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Mr President, I believe that we should pay full attention to three people who are on the spot and have been trying to help dialogue for a year: ex—Premier Zapatero and Presidents Fernandez and Torrijos. As they point out, what is in question is a deep political and social antagonism dating back over 20 years. They point out five concrete steps to overcome this situation: first, an election schedule; second, a consensual commission for the truth; third, institutional respect on the basis of the Constitution; fourth, cooperation on social and economic issues, and respect for national sovereignty on the basis of international support. And they point out that this is possible only with caution, discretion, persistence, trust and the will for dialogue. We should listen to these people who are on the spot and who, with all their wisdom, are showing us the right way to solve this tragic situation.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, this would be for Mr João Ferreira, but he is not here. I have now received the following message from Venezuela that I will now read: “Venezuela, today, I need more of the world. People, eating hamburgers, eat basura. The police rob you, the thieves kill you every day. People fight for a hari racer sole a week; sometimes you have to eat it and you have to eat it as it is cooked in water. This is another type of human situation that lives in Venezuela and that only those who live here understand the perfection ”. - The harsh reality, ladies and gentlemen, is that citizens in Venezuela - where there are about one and a half million Portuguese and Portuguese descendants - live in oppression. Judiciary and electoral power remain subject to the interests of the executive. The National Assembly remains asphyxiated by sentences that usurp its functions and the private citizens to exercise the rights that the constitution guarantees them, as is the case of the revocation referendum, or even to fulfill the mandates for which they were legitimately elected, as well illustrates the situation of my friend António Ladesma, who had been in prison for two years. In fact, what is in Venezuela is an entire people of political prisoners. Defending democracy without resorting to euphemisms is an obligation for all Democrats.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me thank all the honourable Members for their interventions. I believe that Venezuela needs to re-establish its democratic stability through peaceful and constitutional solutions to address the many challenges that its people are facing. We must keep on encouraging all political forces to follow this agenda. I know that I also can count on this Parliament; you have been an important ally in calling for a peaceful and constitutional outcome to the crisis of Venezuela, and I encourage you to continue doing so.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed.  The vote will take place on next part-session. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: written. - A few days ago the Supreme Court of Venezuela annulled the powers of the National Assembly - where the opposition is a majority - and eliminated the parliamentary immunity of its deputies. We cannot forget that Parliament represents the citizenry, it is the center of democracy par excellence. These rulings represent an attack on democracy, which we can say is non-existent in a country where it is clear that the division of powers is not respected. The Judiciary is in the hands of those who are loyal to the President, who shows that he is capable of anything to cling to power. Unfortunately, it is the Venezuelan citizens who suffer the consequences of their actions, those who have to live in a country mired in chaos, uncertainty and poverty. I am also concerned about the enormous influence that totalitarian states of the region exercise over Venezuela, such as Cuba. Maduro allows the extension of Cuban tentacles in his public notaries and civil registries, the ministries, social programs, the state oil company and the army. Cuban advisers run the Venezuelan government and any resemblance in Venezuela to the way it is repressed in Cuba is no accident.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: written.- Democracy is in danger in Venezuela.It is necessary to denounce this situation, but it is necessary to go further, because peace is in danger.In Venezuela there are two powers, the executive and the legislative, both with original legitimacy, which represent contradictory political projects, and whose radical confrontation puts the future of the country at risk.From Europe we must not fan that flame by limiting ourselves to condemning the situation without providing any solution.We must not consider dialogue for dead, because only a democratic process, which leads to a consensual political agreement between the parties, will provide a peaceful solution to Venezuelans and hope for the future.That is the reason why the Vatican, the UN and High Representative Ms. Mogherini continue to bet on dialogue, and that is why the European Parliament must also do so.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written.- Democracy is in danger in Venezuela.It is necessary to denounce this situation, but it is necessary to go further, because peace is in danger.In Venezuela there are two powers, the executive and the legislative, both with original legitimacy, which represent contradictory political projects, and whose radical confrontation puts the future of the country at risk.From Europe we must not fan that flame by limiting ourselves to condemning the situation without providing any solution.We must not consider dialogue for dead, because only a democratic process, which leads to a consensual political agreement between the parties, will provide a peaceful solution to Venezuelans and hope for the future.That is the reason why the Vatican, the UN and High Representative Ms. Mogherini continue to bet on dialogue, and that is why the European Parliament must also do so.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the adequacy of the protection afforded by the EU-US Privacy Shield (2016/3018(RSP)).

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me first of all thank you for the opportunity to speak to you today and to update you on the state of implementation of the privacy shield and our plans for the upcoming first annual review. Today’s discussion is very timely, as I have just returned from Washington and can inform you of the latest state of play. As you rightly note in the motion for today’s resolution, the privacy shield has attracted a lot of interest, with more than 1 900 companies that have been certified under this framework. This shows the importance of the instrument for our trans-Atlantic relationship. It also means that an increasing volume of the personal data that is transferred across the Atlantic benefits from the many protections that the privacy shield offers for individuals. I know that some of you had hoped for more, and I too would one day like to see a fully fledged comprehensive data protection law in the United States, but in the meantime, our assessment is that the privacy issue of framework lives up to the requirements of our data protection laws, as interpreted by our highest court. Our highest court has clarified: adequacy does not mean that the rules in the third country have to be an exact photocopy of our rules. Rather, what the Commission has to assess is if that third country offers in law and practice an essentially equivalent level of protection to that guaranteed in the EU legal order. Clearly the privacy shield is a substantial improvement when compared to the old safe harbour. This is the view of our data protection authorities, and I am glad to see that your motion contains the same clear statement. However, putting in place the privacy shield framework, the privacy principles, together with the commitments and assurances by the United States’ government, was only part of the work. It is equally important that these rules also fully apply in practice. This is why our focus since the adoption of the decision has been on the effective implementation of this new framework. This involves several actors, and I am happy to report that our data protection authorities and the United States authorities have cooperated closely in working out procedures to ensure a robust oversight and enforcement of these new rules. Representatives from the Ombudsperson’s office as well as the Federal Trade Commission and Department of Commerce have come to Brussels on several occasions to discuss with the Commission and the Article 29 Working Party the details of this cooperation, and to report on their implementation work. During my visit to Washington last week, I put a particular emphasis on some of the key foundations on which the privacy shield is built. This concerns in particular the limitations and safeguards that apply in the area of government access for national security purposes. A central element of this is Presidential Policy Directive number 28, which specifically addresses the privacy protections afforded to foreigners. Another key element is the Ombudsperson mechanism, which ensures that Europeans have a possibility to obtain an individual review if they believe that intelligence authorities have broken the law when accessing their personal data. A third one is the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board. For the sustainability of the privacy shield it is essential that these elements are part of it. We will closely monitor any relevant developments in the United States with a possible impact on the privacy shield, including the upcoming debates around a possible reform or prolongation of Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, which expires at the end of this year. This is the message we have been sending since the start of the new administration. I have repeated this message during my recent visit to Washington and my meetings with the White House, the Commerce Secretary, the Attorney General State Department as well as Congress, and I received assurances that this message is well understood by our US counterparts, both as to the value of the privacy shield and the need to keep all of its elements in place. Let me make this point very clear: If we are faced with any developments that could negatively affect the level of protection afforded under the Privacy Shield, the Commission will take its responsibilities and use all available mechanisms, be it review, suspension, revocation or repeal, to promptly react. My focus is now on the first annual joint review. This will be a crucial moment: a moment of truth where we take stock of how the privacy shield functions in practice and to see whether there are things that need to be improved. I have agreed with the US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross that the first annual joint review meeting will take place in Washington in September. All the various elements that are relevant for the functioning of the EU-US privacy shield will be covered by this review, inter alia: first, how US companies comply with their data protection obligations and the mechanisms they have put in place to ensure a speedy handling of complaints. Second, how the Department of Commerce and Federal Trade Committee certify companies, monitor compliance and cooperate with our data protection authorities in the enforcement. Third, the operation of the rules regarding access by public authorities and the rules and procedures to ensure that the Ombudsperson mechanism functions well. Fourth, in addition, in the issues identified already in the Commission’s adequacy decision, such as the dialogue on automated decision-making, as well as any developments in the United States law that might raise questions concerning the EU-US privacy shield and its operation, will have to be discussed. As partners in this review, we will of course discuss the precise parameters of the review with the Article 29 Working Party. The input from business and from civil society will also be of crucial importance. I met both sides in Washington, and they are committed to contribute. On the US side, we expect the joint review to involve the Department of Commerce and the Federal Trade Commission, but also the Ombudsperson and representatives from the intelligence community. Directly after the joint review we will report our findings to you and to the Member States in the Council. This will allow you and us to assess and discuss where we are on this and also discuss the next necessary steps. Honourable Members, thank you again for giving me the opportunity to speak to you today, and of course I stand ready to address any questions you might have.

name: Axel VOSS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner! It is important that we give our companies, SMEs and startups, etc., legal certainty, and also provide a concrete legal basis for the transatlantic data exchange while at the same time safeguarding data protection. And in my opinion, the data protection shield combines both. In all these years, recently, the Commission has achieved a great deal on the one hand in terms of data protection and on the other hand in terms of the data protection shield. We will never be able to get the 100% that other groups in this House would like to have, but there is no reason to speak so negatively about this privacy shield right now. We ourselves in Parliament already adopted a motion for a resolution on the free movement of data here in June 2016, where we also rate the data protection shield positively. But now there is really no reason to be right in the middle of it - it has been running since June or July of last year, and now we actually have to wait until the new report comes in September, and then there might have been a reason to evaluate it. So we neither have the practical experience that we can evaluate now, and theoretically this simply cannot be easily penetrated here. You have all highlighted the positive elements, and compared to the Safe Harbor Agreement, that is a huge step that we could not have expected in itself. In particular, you have achieved more than what we ourselves are willing to give in our own Member States, and that is a good thing. This interface with national security will always be difficult to overcome, but I believe that both sides benefit from these transatlantic data flows in the end, and it is also an indispensable opportunity for both sides to continue along the way.

name: Claude MORAES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, to be very clear, the purpose of this resolution is because we have a September evaluation. I really believe that the members of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs – and indeed other Members who have expertise and interest in this extremely important topic – need to give their views to the Commissioner. I do not see any problem with this. In fact, I think this is a positive and important part of our work.  I want to begin with what you said about your trip to the United States. I think it is very important, Commissioner, particularly for the Civil Liberties Committee, that we have an interaction with you before we go to the United States in September. Why are we doing this? Why are we proposing this resolution? We are not doing it because there have not been significant and key improvements on Safe Harbor thanks to Privacy Shield, but because we want to ensure in Parliament that Privacy Shield stands the test of time and that it does not have weaknesses that would be difficult for the future. We know that Privacy Shield protects the fundamental rights of anyone in the EU whose personal data is transferred to the United States, as well as bringing legal clarity for businesses relying on trans-Atlantic data transfers, and we cannot allow that to fail. So the resolution acknowledges that the final agreement on the Privacy Shield, adopted in July 2016, has taken a number of Parliament’s concerns into consideration. We know that key improvements have been made compared to the former Safe Harbor. We note also that the agreement will facilitate data transfers from the EU to the US, particularly from SMEs and business in the EU, and that the EU Data Protection Authority’s supervisory powers remain unaffected by the adequacy decision, including the power of suspending or banning data transfers to US companies that are members of the Privacy Shield. We also take note of the clarifications and interpretations of the US Administration, in particular as regards the processing of personal data by security agencies. However, several issues must be resolved. The resolution highlights issues of concern that remain unclear, particularly, for example, those made by the Article 29 Working Party, which – as we all know – is deeply involved in these matters. These include concerns regarding the principle of data retention, the bulk collection of personal data for national security purposes, the need for sufficient judicial redress, and the effect of independent oversight, as well as several law enforcement issues. If these concerns are not taken into account, the Privacy Shield risks not achieving its purpose and could face further challenge in the courts. This is one of our deepest concerns. Both citizens and businesses relying on transatlantic data flows need that certainty of a robust legal framework, and this text calls on the Commission to conduct that proper assessment. It does not doubt that that will happen, but we are doing our job in ensuring that every part of this detail is covered.  We will raise these concerns during our LIBE delegation with our US counterparts, and we are now experienced in these negotiations. The Parliament has consistently called for a stronger agreement, following the invalidation of Safe Harbor in October 2015, and we now want the protection of personal data which meets the requirements of the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the data protection legal framework. Commissioner, today we are calling on you to conduct a proper assessment to ensure this legal certainty is provided for citizens and business alike. We in the Parliament simply want to do our job. That is what the resolution is saying today.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - First of all, I regret that certain political groups did not want to wait for the first evaluation by the Commission. Having said that, I am also not at all happy with the content of the rapporteur Moraes resolution. I have therefore worked with the EPP Group to provide a more positive alternative. Let me emphasize a few things from this. First, transatlantic data transfer is essential to our economy, trade and security. No one can deny this and please let us not put it aside in this debate. Anyone who is pushing for a suspension of the Privacy Shield should consider the consequences of the legal uncertainty that this entails. Second, with the Privacy Shield, we achieved an unprecedented level of data protection. A gigantic step was taken in the right direction. The rights and legal protection of EU citizens when data transfers to the US are advancing enormously. Of course I agree that the Commission should always strive for the highest possible standard of data protection, but some political groups and Members of Parliament continue to believe that only a copy of the European rules will suffice. However, the United States is an independent nation. However, while the country is an important strategic ally of the EU, we should not forget that it is not a member of the Union. I and my delegation strongly believe that it is best for our businesses, the European economy and the privacy of EU citizens to have an operational privacy shield.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, in reply to Mrs Stevens, we are not actually calling for the suspension of the Privacy Shield, but we do expect the Commission to defend the interests of EU citizens and monitor, extremely critically, what is happening. We had already expressed very serious concerns under the Obama administration and, for some reason, the changes that have been made by the Trump administration do not alleviate my concerns. I do not know why, it is probably me. Indeed we do not expect the US law to be identical, but we do expect it to be essentially equivalent, because that is what the judges have said. So that is not a party political request but an obligation for the EU institutions, and the Commission is responsible here.  I do not need to outline all the questions that we have put in the resolution. I am actually a little bit disappointed. The resolution has been available in the public domain for some time now. I would have expected the Commission to have already responded to the questions which are in there. What about the privacy and civil liberties oversight board, which is under quota? What about the Ombudsmen, who has not been replaced? What about the impact of Section 14 of the Privacy Act? What about the legal status of the assurances? What about the definition of bulk transfers? What about the interpretation of PPD—28? The Commission could have addressed all these things in its statement.  I would really urge the Commission not just to repeat what should be done, but actually to  be on top of things. That is the way the Americans would do it, so why do we not do it on behalf of our citizens? Two final issues, because this is not about party politics, Mrs Stevens; there is a legal challenge before the ECJ. There is also the other issue, namely that national DPAs may actually decide to suspend the transfers and then we have legal uncertainty. It is not by asking critical questions that we create legal uncertainty; it is by not asking the Americans critical questions. So I would say to the Commissioner, please make privacy great again.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President! It is exactly like that. No, we cannot make peace with the privacy shield. We find that this is also not an appropriate answer to the Schrems judgment and the Safe Harbor Agreement, which has been brought down, because it does not offer equal data protection for everyone, because mass surveillance for the purpose of criminal prosecution should continue to take place elsewhere because, as we all know, huge amounts of data continue to be happily delivered to 16 US agencies, free of charge, without judicial authorization, because the State Department ombudsman is a fig leaf, as we all know, because many US organizations involved in the want to participate in privacy shield, do not even have a data protection authority and because US President Trump has at least signed a decree that wants to exempt non-US citizens from data protection. Anyone who still talks about a protective shield is a dreamer. The privacy shield we are talking about here is an open barn door for arbitrariness at the expense of fundamental rights. And it can get even worse if it is the case that the US Senate and the House of Representatives have actually overturned a ban, that the ban on the FCC telecommunications regulator has been overturned, so that Internet providers then collect and use private data with practically no consent from their customers can sell. So. If Donald Trump still agrees, then US data protection is fun - that's how I say it. We therefore fully share the critical view of the resolution on all points, because the problems have in no way been resolved.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - We do not live under a stone and the Greens understand very well that it must continue to be possible to continue to send personal data to the United States for commercial purposes. Facebook is fun, whatsapping is really indispensable, but sending our personal data should not be at the expense of everything. Our fundamental rights deserve protection and I am therefore concerned about the Privacy Shield in its current form, because the protection of our personal data is not guaranteed on the other side of the ocean. When the Americans claim national security is at stake, analysis of bulk data remains possible. Let me repeat and underline that again: under the Privacy Shield, bulk data may still be analyzed. That in itself is enough to dismiss the Privacy Shield. The European Court was clear, wasn't it? Storage and analysis of bulk data is prohibited. So we can set the clock: the privacy shield will die, just like Safe Harbor in Luxembourg. So the resolution we will be voting on tomorrow reiterates what we all know: under the Privacy Shield, our rights in the US remain substantially lower than here in the European Union. Not equivalent, no, lower. So what do we do? Are we stubborn and are we waiting for Max Schrems and his companions to travel from Ireland to Luxembourg and the Court to reprimand us? Or is the European Commission now going to renegotiate with the Americans? I also see that the interests of American commerce are well represented by the EPP and the ECR. They have an alternative resolution that opts for the companies and against the fundamental rights of our citizens. But, friends on the right, a treaty that could be annulled by the Court at any time is not good for business. It makes business unreliable. Commerce also benefits from renegotiations, so I ask you for it our amendments asking to support renegotiation.

name: Viviane REDING
text: – Madam President, my question is simply: is the Privacy Shield stillborn? Vault 7 revealed that the CIA tapped directly into our smartphones; Microsoft and Apple court cases exposed the FBI tendency to bypass existing legal frameworks to access data; the Congressional Review Act allowed Comcast, AT&T and Verizon to use people’s data without their consent and Trump’s Muslim ban ordered agencies to exclude non-American citizens, not only Muslims, from their privacy policies.  Now all this has taken place after the adoption of the new framework and all eyes are now riveted on the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) Section 702. I would like to ask the Commissioner, does she really feel assured? The Article 29 Working Group does not because yes, the Privacy Shield has improved Safe Harbour but, no, it did not assuage many of our concerns.  The problem is, and always has been, the use of national security as a blanket exemption and this is one of the numerous questions that need answers, most of all during the upcoming review. Concrete evidence must prevail over alternative facts, legal obligations over written commitments, MEPs’ demands over Congressmen’s promises.  We must build a transatlantic digital bridge on a rock-solid privacy pillar and unfortunately, I have the feeling that the shield might already have turned into a smokescreen.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: - Madam President! Only after the European Court of Justice declared the Safe Harbor regime null and void did the Commission try to create better rules for data transfer to the USA. However, despite some progress, the overall result cannot convince me. It is still difficult to legally defend against misuse of your data. The US ombudsperson is not independent enough. US companies are not required to delete personal information when it is no longer necessary. The biggest problem, however, is that the new Privacy Shield does not rule out mass surveillance either. In its ruling on the repeal of its predecessor “Safe Harbor”, however, the European Court of Justice made it clear: general access to the content of electronic communication violates the essence, the core of the fundamental right to respect for private life. The first review of the privacy shield is due soon. It is important to us Social Democrats that the points of criticism mentioned receive sufficient attention there and that legal certainty is created. Parliament cannot suspend the privacy shield, but the Commission can if the deficiencies in the protection of fundamental rights are too great. I very much regret that the Conservatives in the Home Affairs Committee did not want to support our jointly negotiated resolution. It seems that they are more important to quick solutions for companies than sustainable, fundamental rights-friendly approaches, which also offer more legal protection for the companies concerned. I therefore hope that in plenary we will find a majority in favor of this resolution. This is how we can send a signal to the Commission. The European Parliament will follow the functioning of the privacy shield in practice extremely critically. If the review reveals that the privacy shield is inconsistent with the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and the new EU data protection rules, the Commission must suspend it. Otherwise risked she is embarrassed that this protective shield fails again before the European Court of Justice.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, last year some of us stood here and warned that the Commission’s EU-US Privacy Shield agreement would not protect citizens’ privacy rights; and how right we were. The so-called ‘shield’ is an insult to citizens across Europe whose privacy has been further undermined. The agreement allows the US intelligence to carry out mass surveillance and collect huge amounts of private data and bulk information indiscriminately. It allows US companies to collect data on individual citizens every time they go online, with no effective legal protection, and it is only voluntary. It only applies to companies that have signed up. The rest can run fancy free with our information. So this shambles breaches our fundamental privacy rights and it needs to be fixed. It needs to be fixed urgently with a robust, effective and enforceable system that protects the privacy rights of citizens, not the interest of spooks and big business. I would call on the Commissioner to fix it before the European Court of Justice forces you to do so for a second time.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Madam President, as we stressed in the resolution on big data and fundamental rights that I drafted and which was passed by this Parliament last month, in this digital age it is extremely important to strengthen citizens' confidence in the use of new communication technologies and ensure security of personal data collected online and by all types of electronic devices. These principles necessarily apply to transatlantic data transfers to ensure legal certainty for companies and citizens, within a legal framework, robust in equivalent data protection regimes and less vulnerable to criminal and misuse. This European Parliament resolution recognizes that the privacy protection shield between the European Union and the United States contains significant improvements with regard to the clarity of the rules, in comparison with the old regime, called safe harbor, as a result of the efforts of the European Commission to address the shortcomings raised by the Court of Justice, the Article 29 working group and the European Parliament, among others. Even so, Parliament points out a number of reservations, both the commercial aspects and the access by the United States public authorities to data transferred from the European Union. And there are just a few, such as the absence of specific rules on automated decisions and the application of the principles of the shield to subcontractors. The absence of a general right of opposition on the part of citizens, the need for guarantees on the independence and powers of the mediation mechanism and the absence of guarantees on the failure to carry out a mass indiscriminate collection of personal data which is prohibited by the European Charter Fundamental Rights. All of these concerns can lead to a challenge of this regime to the courts. In addition, the political situation in the United States today is clearly different. We cannot ignore, Madam Commissioner, the impact of the election of Donald Trump on the fulfillment of the agreement and the guarantees given by the Obama administration. Trump has already shown complete contempt for deals signed by the previous administration. Just this week the President enacted a law that gives Internet operators in the United States the freedom to sell their customers' data, such as browsing history and other private information, to the advertising market, without the consent of the persons concerned, the which demonstrates the contempt of the new administration for the minimum guarantees to protect privacy and personal data that existed previously. That is why, on the occasion of the first annual joint review, the Commission must proceed to an in-depth analysis of all the gaps and deficiencies that are mentioned in this resolution and has to verify the compatibility of Trump's new laws and executive orders with the commitments made within the framework of the privacy protection shield, as well as its impact on data protection ... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I said at the beginning that I very much appreciate the opportunity to take part in the discussion here today, to answer your questions and to hear your views because I think the period between the moment when we started the full functioning of Privacy Shield and the first annual report, which will come out as late as September, is very important. I am grateful for hearing your views, including the critical voices, because we take all of them very seriously and share many of them. That is why – as I also said at the beginning – we are closely monitoring the situation in the United States. It is not true that we only say what should be done. I am informing you about the things we are doing. This is something I want to emphasise very strongly.  I am aware of the fact – as Mr Moraes, Mr Voss and some others clearly said – that at the moment we still do not have a full assessment of the functioning of Privacy Shield, because this is just the beginning. It is also for this reason that I am glad about the idea which we discussed today with the Chair of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, namely that I could come in the first half of this year to give full information about how we see and assess the functioning of Privacy Shield. This is my commitment which I would like to repeat here in the plenary. When I say that the first annual review will be the moment of truth, I mean it very seriously. This must not be just another report. I want to give an honest and true reflection of the situation. That is why I want to use all possible channels to have this fully-fledged review which will reflect how Privacy Shield protects the privacy of Europeans and whether it fully protects according our requirement, the requirement of European law, and the requirement of the court ruling.  That is why I want to take all the inputs from the State Administration, from the Article 29 Working Party on the European side and the Federal Trade Commission on the American side. I want to take on board all the critical comments from the NGOs. I spoke to NGOs on both the European and American sides. They are very critical and share some of the concerns which you voiced here today. I want to a create a precise and detailed questionnaire which will be sent to the certified companies – the companies which have been certified under Privacy Shield – so that we receive information from them about the number of requests from the intelligence services and security bodies on the American side, and much other detailed information. I also want to use the media reports about the atmosphere, tendencies and trends in the United States to capture something which I call a real feel for how to look at the situation in the United States. We must focus on three main things: the legal environment in the United States; the capacities which the United States partners invest in the full functioning of Privacy Shield; the way Privacy Shield is used and respected by the certified companies; and the way Privacy Shield is used by the citizens themselves, because, as you know, an important part of the Privacy Shield mechanism is offering new ways of redress for EU citizens. These are the things which we are going to fully focus and reflect on through the first annual review. Mrs in 't Veld asked for a specific answers to some questions. I will try to answer them now but, as I said, we are ready to give you more detailed responses whenever you ask. On the Ombudsperson, the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB) and the Federal Trade Commission, what I said before is relevant, namely that we are focusing on the United States institutions to be fully equipped as regards the capacities and the responsible leadership to keep Privacy Shield running. We shared our concerns in Washington about the fact that we do not see any persons nominated or appointed to these positions. We now have to face the reality that the new American Administration still has to appoint about 5 000 people to senior positions in the State Administration, out of which 1 000 must also be also endorsed and authorised by the Senate. The Ombudsperson, for instance, is one of them so we will now have to negotiate with and monitor the work of the acting Ombudsperson. My colleague has spoken to this person, so we are in contact and they understand how important this is for us. As for the Ombudsperson, I will rely for the review on the information from the Ombudsperson’s office because there should not only be information about the complaints he or she received, but also information about how many requests were sent from the intelligence services to the companies. I will push hard to get such information because we also want the Ombudsperson to act as the relevant source of trustworthy information for us.  On PCLOB the situation is similar. We urge the American side to have the full capacity of the Federal Trade Commission. I spoke to its acting Chair, and we made it very clear that we are waiting for the official new representation. On PPD-28, we have been assured that no changes are foreseen, but we will of course keep monitoring this. We also have strong allies in the Congress and among the experts who are monitoring the situation on this piece of legislation, which I made absolutely clear to our American partners is the main pillar, as it is for the American legislation, for keeping Privacy Shield running. This is what we need to see in place and fully functioning. Regarding Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA), still no information can be received on whether there will be amendments or whether it will continue in the same way as it is in force now. We have to follow all the information we receive in the months to come, but I am rather sceptical about whether before the review we will have anything more concrete about whether there will be any changes. I made it very clear that, if there are changes to the detriment of the situation for the protection of Europeans’ private data, we will have to act because this is an absolutely crucial piece of legislation for Privacy Shield. The situation on the executive order is different, according to our legal analysis, because the protections of Privacy Shield are not based on the US Privacy Act. Therefore the executive order which you mentioned has no impact on this. This is the executive order on enhancing public safety. In Section 14 this concerns protections under the US Privacy Act of 1974. The Privacy Act only applies to US citizens and permanent residents. The Obama Administration had instructed federal agencies to use their discretion also to apply these protections to others in the context of migration databases and this policy has now has been reversed. But let us be clear: as I indicated, the Privacy Act never granted any rights to Europeans. That is why we had to negotiate new arrangements, notably the umbrella agreement and the accompanying Judicial Redress Act, to ensure the necessary protection for Europeans and these remain unaffected by the executive order. This has also been confirmed in writing by the United States. Let me conclude by saying that for us the main message to take to Washington was that we can see that security is a very high priority in the United States. I made it absolutely clear that for us the protection of Europeans’ private data is a very high priority and a fundamental right which must also be protected in the transfer of data to the United States. I think that this was well understood by all our key American partners. I would say that the protection of private data must remain great, not be made great again. This was our message to our American partners.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner, for your really exhaustive and comprehensive response, and we can only hope that this protection provided by the Privacy Shield will work so well.I have received two motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure. I close the debate.The vote will take place tomorrow.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the debate on the 2016 report by Ivo Vajgl, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (2016/231 (INI)) (A8-0055 / 2017).

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: rapporteur. - The report that we will obviously be discussing late tonight refers to the European Commission's progress report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia for 2016 and has not yet been completed. We will write our closing remarks when the expected shift in the crisis takes place in Macedonia. With the active participation of all shadow rapporteurs and after comprehensive consideration and support in the European Parliament's Foreign Affairs Committee, a document has emerged that clearly supports Macedonia's integration into the European Union and Euro-Atlantic integration, provided the protracted political crisis ends a new government that will take into account the results of the elections on 11 December last year and the relations and possibilities of coalition cooperation in parliament based on them. Today we can only conclude that the crisis continues, that the work of parliament is practically impossible, that the basic rules of parliamentary democracy are not observed and that instead of committing to the long-term interests of the state, the political confrontation of parties is dominated by tones. Instead of allowing the country to move along the outlined European path, urgent and profound reforms are directing the disgruntled politicians of the masses of their supporters into street protests that encourage interethnic mistrust and intolerance. Almost four months after the snap parliamentary elections, which were held in accordance with democratic standards, we concluded that the constitution of the parliament and the formation of the government could not be due to systematic obstruction of the process by the strongest political party VMRO, which failed to form the required majority. for refusing the President to entrust, in accordance with the rules and practice of democracies, the mandate to form a government to the leader who has given him the necessary assurances that he has the majority support of Parliament. The highest representatives of the European Union, NATO and the leaders of many European countries have clearly and critically commented on the conduct of President Gjorge Ivanov. They all are called on the President to use his powers to enable the normal functioning of parliament and the formation of a government on the basis of the generous majority available to the potential ruling coalition. President Ivanov insists on a position that reveals above all his party affiliation and prolongs the crisis. It is still time to change its position and align it with the demand and principles of parliamentary democracy, to restore peace and hope for a better life in peace and mutual respect to all citizens of their country. Ladies and gentlemen, the report, the content of which I prepared as rapporteur in constructive cooperation with you, the Commission, colleagues in the mediation team on behalf of the European Parliament and in close substantive cooperation with Commissioner Johannes Hahn and his Cabinet, will need to be updated as the crisis unfolds. Macedonia before we put it to the vote. I am convinced that Macedonia deserves more encouragement than criticism. He has been waiting too long for negotiations to begin over the anachronistic name dispute. The report takes the view that bilateral issues and disputes should not be an obstacle to the country's progress towards Euro-Atlantic integration. The recommendation to start accession negotiations, conditional on resolving the political crisis and accelerating work on reforms based on the Pržino agreement and the document on urgent reform priorities, would encourage progress and the much-needed participation of all political parties on the national priority. EU. Macedonia and the region around it need stability and peace. At the moment, it also needs reconciliation and reconciliation as a condition for a different, inclusive policy. (One more sentence, please.) Macedonian politicians should resolve their relations in a democratic way. In doing so, they can count on the support of the European Parliament and the European Union and its institutions as a whole.

name: Ian Borg
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you for the opportunity to discuss with you the Commission’s annual report on the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. On 9 March 2017, the European Council discussed the situation in the Western Balkans. It stressed the EU’s commitment to the region and reaffirmed its unequivocal support for the European perspective of the Western Balkans. President Tusk visited the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia earlier this week and confirmed this commitment. On behalf of the Presidency I wish to reiterate our commitment to advancing the enlargement process in full respect of the basic principles of conditionality and on merit.  The early parliamentary elections finally took place on 11 December 2016, after having been postponed twice. We take good note that the OSCE considers that the elections were competitive, but that they took place in an environment characterised by widespread public mistrust in the institutions and the political establishment. Unfortunately, the government has not been formed to date, and we are concerned at the current political impasse. We look forward to the formation of the new government without further delay in line with democratic principles and the constitution.  In Skopje on Monday, President Tusk called for statesmanship and unity in order to find a way out of the current deadlock. We also remain worried about the continuation of the political crisis and the partial implementation of the Pržino Agreement. We share your view that political will is necessary to ensure its full, tangible and sustainable implementation. The country continues to suffer from a very divisive political environment, polarisation and the lack of a culture of compromise, with backsliding in important areas such as the functioning of the judiciary, which should be allowed to work independently.  Let me also reiterate the importance of a thorough and independent investigation, without hindrance, of the allegations of wrongdoing brought to the fore by the wiretaps and the related failures of oversight. In this respect, I would like to recall the importance of the mandate and the work of both the Special Prosecutor and the parliamentary committee of inquiry to look respectively into legal and also political responsibility. It is also important to restore trust in the national institutions. We also back your call on all parties, including those forming the future government, to take ownership and to honour the undertaking to implement the urgent reform priorities, and also to address systematic rule of law issues, including in relation to breaches of fundamental rights, judicial independence, media freedom, elections, corruption, politicisation of state institutions, state or party blurring, and failures of oversight. We also welcome the Commission’s intention to continue the close monitoring in order to assess systematic failures in the areas of justice, corruption, fundamental rights and human affairs, as reflected also in the urgent reform priorities. We expect the new government to urgently, as a  first priority, address overdue reforms, including the one I just referred to – the urgent reform priorities – for the benefit of the country and its citizens, and also in order to return the country to its European path.  The Council also acknowledges and encourages the constructive role played by civil society in supporting and improving democratic processes. I would also like to stress the importance of good inter-ethnic relations. The review of the Ohrid Framework Agreement needs to be completed by the new government as soon as possible in an inclusive and transparent manner, and its recommendations implemented. Let me finally underline that maintaining of good neighbourly relations, including a negotiated and mutually accepted solution to the name issue, under the auspices of the United Nations remains essential. We all agree that there is a need to bring the longstanding discussions on the name issue to a definitive conclusion without delay. Let me welcome the fact that the confidence-building measures have started to produce tangible results. Actions and statements which negatively impact on good neighbourly relations should also be avoided, and we note the continued high level and expert contacts with Bulgaria aimed at strengthening good neighbourly relations. We look forward to their timely translation into concrete results. We also welcome the fact that the Commission is prepared to extend these recommendations to open accession negotiations, conditional on progress with the implementation of the Pržino Agreement, and substantial progress in the implementation of the urgent reform priorities.  The Presidency is ready to revert, when appropriate, to the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, including on the basis of an update from the Commission once sufficient progress has been made on these issues and in line with the previous Council conclusions and established conditionality. The political leaders now have the responsibility to take the necessary steps and put their country back on the Euro-Atlantic path. The European Union stands ready to support them in these endeavours.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank the Parliament, and in particular the rapporteur, Ivo Vajgl, for the report which is before you today for discussion. We find it balanced and in line with the main findings of our 2016 report on the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. As you all know, the political situation in the country is of very serious concern. The Commission, therefore, greatly appreciates the work of this House, and in particular the efforts of honourable Members, Ivo Vajgl, Mr Fleckenstein and Mr Kukan, and, before that, Richard Howitt. In very close coordination with Commissioner Hahn, they send common messages to the political leaders during their recent visit to Skopje. President Tusk was also in the country on Monday. More than ever, we need to continue speaking with one voice. The early parliamentary elections last December were a key part of the political agreement which the country’s leaders signed in 2015. But they were only a start. We are all deeply concerned about the latest developments and the continued refusal of President Ivanov to give a mandate to a coalition which is clearly supported by the majority in the assembly. This risks undermining the stability of the country and its credibility. We are also gravely concerned about the emergence of inter-ethnic inflammatory rhetoric by some actors. Such rhetoric means playing with fire. It could have broader regional implications and must, therefore, stop immediately. I therefore strongly encourage all political leaders in the country, including the president, to respect the results of the elections and the clear parliamentary majority. We expect the president to let democracy proceed and a new government to be formed. I know that, especially, this House feels strongly about the central role of national parliaments, and we expect all political leaders to stop fuelling inter-ethnic tensions. The rapid formation of the new government will, however, not to be sufficient in itself to return to business as usual. We will continue to insist on the implementation of all parts of the 2015 Pržino agreement, including key reforms on the rule of law. We need to see a clear and firm political will to tackle these issues. Substantial progress is not only needed in the implementation of the so-called urgent reform priorities, which address the serious rule of law issues in the country. This also means that the special prosecutor’s office should be given time and resources to complete its work. Let me at this point also emphasise the crucial importance of empowered civil society and good neighbourly relations. We are concerned about the criticism and attacks faced by civil society organisations. An empowered civil society is a crucial component of any democratic system, and should be recognised and treated as such by state institutions and politicians. Good neighbourly relations are also essential for the country. Resolving bilateral issues with the neighbours is crucial and finding a solution to the main issue remains a priority. We should all come together to support this goal. Last but not least, the country was also at the front line of an unprecedented migration crisis in 2015 and 2016. It has received very considerable support from the EU and from individual Member States. The Commission remains committed to continue helping with this challenge, despite the situation being much calmer now. Let me, however, also say that our good cooperation on migration issues does not mean at all that we will close an eye to the aforementioned democratic and rule of law issues. That would be extremely short-sighted, and I know this is not how this House sees enlargement. In short, the European Council has just reaffirmed the accession perspective of the entire Western Balkans region. It is now up to the countries in the region to use this momentum, with our help. This is a long, complex process so there is no time to waste. This is particularly true for this country. I now look forward to the debate.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I very much appreciate the constructive approach by Mr Vajgl. We are still optimistic about this very complicated programme and on behalf of the EPP Group I can say that I fully support his stand.  I think the key word was provided by President Tusk a few days ago when he said that Macedonia can count on EU support once the domestic political crisis is solved, based on democratic principles, decency and common sense. I think we can interpret this as meaning that the EU wants Macedonia to move towards the EU and NATO membership. The internal situation remains extremely complicated but we must understand that it is our shared worry and shared responsibility.  The EU has a responsibility, especially now, to play a stronger role in the region or, as we know, there will be other powers to fill the void. The external influences have already fuelled internal divisions in Macedonia. If we are hesitant or slow to bring Western Balkan countries closer to the EU others will not hesitate to drift them away from us.  The major problem remains national reconciliation, which means serious efforts to develop inclusiveness and mutual trust. To advance this, the EU too has to offer a credible European perspective to Macedonia.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! I would also like to thank Mr Vajgl for his good report, even if we cannot vote on it today. We cannot vote, although he, Eduard Kukan and my predecessor Richard Howitt made every effort to work with the parties to find a solution to end the crisis in Macedonia. And this solution was called democratic elections, which are also recognized afterwards. And these elections took place, and they also took place in an environment that one could say: the work was worth it. But the work was not worth it if democracy only works if the respective party wins. That is why I say very clearly: the result is clear, 67 MPs have formed a coalition, and we expect those who have been voted out to leave their offices, do proper opposition work and maybe return in four years when this government is in place who now comes into office has done a bad job. But what is not possible is to take an entire country hostage just because one's own claims to power are what they are. And there is no need to fool around - you have to be very clear: If you continue like this, the road to Europe will be closed at some point. There can be no recommendation for any form of negotiation if the largest party in a country is of the opinion that democracy only works if it wins. And let me say one more thing: the people on the street who are afraid of losing their identity in their country, you have to take them seriously, you have to talk to them. Incidentally, that is also the job of the 67 to take away their fear. Because the Albanian platform is, if you read it through in peace, something that is not difficult. That it was officially adopted in Tirana is of little help, and that should be known to all actors, including the Prime Minister of Albania.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, Skopje, in violation of international law, has long illegally closed its borders to refugees. Their action was also condemned by the former UN Secretary General, Mr. Ban Ki-moon. By closing the legal Balkan corridor, Skopje has trapped thousands of refugees in Greece. And instead of the European Union recalling them, Mr. Tusk himself just the day before yesterday in Skopje rewarded their attitude. He rewarded the people of Skopje who, in violation of international law, hit thousands of refugees on the border with Greece, in Eidomeni, and illegally threw flash grenades and tear gas against the thousands of people trapped in Eidomeni. As long as Skopje illegally keeps its borders closed to the thousands of refugees trapped in Greece, the Greek government must impose a full economic embargo on Skopje's state, for which it must also be noted that it continues its provocative stance. against Greece. The redemption of Skopje is expressed by the falsification of history and the blasphemy of the name of our Macedonia, a practice that was recently accepted by the rapporteur himself, who called Skopje "Macedonia" instead of "FYROM". Skopje, therefore, must understand that the Greek people will not accept the hatred of the name of our Macedonia.
