Also, the Greek people will not accept a compound name for the name of Skopje with any geographical designation. I am opposed to any future accession of Skopje to the European Union.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group of Representatives. - Madam President, Commissioner, out of a series of very slow developments and crises in the Western Balkans, Macedonia has been at a standstill for the longest time and it can be said that progress there has been completely absent in recent years. It may even be argued that Macedonia is in a worse position today in terms of the prospect of joining the European Union than it was ten years ago. A country going from crisis to crisis. The example of Macedonia shows how young countries, young democracies can stop in their development and how these fragile democratic processes can be turned backwards. This is of course possible, it also happens in developed democracies, but we should be interested in what is the role of the European Parliament and the European Union in this process. The country is left without perspective. In a way, it has been humiliated for the last ten years and this feeling of abandonment has certainly intensified the negative tendencies that are happening in Macedonia. The country is in a very sensitive area. Social internal political conflicts are threatening to escalate into ethnic and interstate conflicts in that wider area, and we know that the area itself is unstable anyway. I know that the European Union does not have large, strong mechanisms, but in addition to appeals and calls and support, there should have been a clear, thoughtful policy, clear plans and a greater presence of the European Parliament and the European Union in Macedonia.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, you argue that you are working for the country to overcome the current political crisis and find its European pace. You argue that your policy of ignoring, beautifying and rewarding the systemic deficit that exists in key sectors of the country and of course in the Copenhagen political criteria helps in this direction. You argue that the degradation of all these negative elements that make up the current tragic situation in the country can create a positive atmosphere of consensus and cooperation. I have repeatedly stressed that this policy could only act as a deterrent to the progress of the country and its people. And, unfortunately, developments confirm this. You ignored the development of nationalism in the country. You welcomed the invention of the tradition in which its politicians invested. You ignored the rhetoric of hatred and xenophobia that was developing. You have made the country's politicians accustomed to abdicating their responsibilities. No self-criticism, no respect for the rule of law and the fundamental principles of the international legal order, no compromise and no political responsibility. Yesterday, Greece and Bulgaria were to blame for the impasse and lack of political will in the country, today Albania and today we are waiting to see who will be to blame tomorrow. These are the results of your policy. Ladies and gentlemen, any discussion on the opening of accession negotiations before the Copenhagen political criteria are met, good neighborly relations are ensured and there is substantial progress on the nomenclature will be out of place and out of time.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: - Madam President, another report on the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia - this is its official name, which many overlook in promoting redemption through a dangerous stalemate - a report that promotes the integration of this country and the Western Balkans as a whole into Europe. Union and NATO in the interests of European monopolies, to control the transport routes of energy and other products to Europe, in competition with capitalist Russia, to stop, according to the overall EU plan, the refugee flows of wars, NATO and the European Union. The peoples of Europe, after the NATO-EU war for the dissolution of Yugoslavia, are again involved in their governments and the policy of "divide and rule" of the European Union in competition and risks of general ignition. Imperialism returns to the redrawing of borders on the basis of ethnocentrism, emancipation, bigotry that he cultivates. Today's developments are related to all this. Joining the European Union means for the people in all countries unemployment, poverty, anti-popular reforms, a blow to the labor rights of the people for the profitability of business groups. A necessary complement is the vulgar anti-communism that this report exudes. The KKE opposes the accession of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to the European Union for the same reasons as for Greece. The peaceful coexistence of the peoples of the region under socialism was interrupted by the imperialist intervention. The peoples have the power, by breaking the shackles of NATO and the European Union and of bourgeois governments, to live peacefully for their own prosperity and not for the gain of monopolies.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Madam President, I would like to offer my sincere thanks to the rapporteur for his good work.  We have been dealing with the political crisis in Macedonia for the past two years. I would really like to see the light at the end of the tunnel, yet democracy in Macedonia is still politically paralysed and the victims are the citizens of the country and hence the integration process itself. Let me say this clearly: it is in our utmost interest to see a strong and democratic Macedonia coming onto the EU path.  We do appreciate the positive role that the country has played and can play in the region, yet democratic development and political stability are the key pillars on which it needs to be built. I am concerned at the deepening of the political crisis. Like many others, I would also like to call on the President of the country to fulfil his responsibility in the process of forming a new government composed of political parties with a real majority in the parliament. In addition, the parliament should itself start working according to the normal procedures.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, regardless of the circumstances, I congratulate my colleague Vajgl on a quality document because the resolution covers all facts and processes relevant to Macedonia during 2016. What is certainly not good is the sequence of events after the early elections held in December. Faced with the loss of power, the long-standing ruling party, its leader and the President of the Republic from its ranks have put the country in a difficult situation. After the president repeatedly refused to give a mandate to form a new government to a leader who managed to secure a majority of MPs elected in the election, Macedonia has returned to a period of internal strife. Encouraging protests in the streets, unsubstantiated accusations that the new government will threaten the country's unity, ignoring European Union officials who advise respect for the Constitution, are becoming instruments of maintaining tension and forcing new elections. At the same time, the former ruling party is blocking the functioning of the new parliament, so that regular local elections scheduled for May have not been called. What seems crucial to me is that the dividing lines deepened by the former prime minister and his party do not leave a mark on the European Union's common approach to the crisis in Macedonia. Such an approach by the European Union and the international community has already yielded good results on several occasions. By discussing the long-lasting and increasingly serious crisis in Macedonia, we are actually answering the growing dilemma of what kind of political arrangements we want in the countries of the Western Balkans. Because depending on the clarity of our views and the insistence on consistent adherence to democratic standards, we will send a message to all the protagonists of violating them. No one disputes the results of the early parliamentary elections recently held in Macedonia. I can say this as a direct observer of these elections. The election did not yield an absolute but a relative winner. A winner who failed in his attempt to renew the coalition with his previous partners. But that same party is after that opposed a coalition of former partners and immediate rivals.Political communities can run into crises because that is the nature of relationships in societies.However, it does not matter how a political community recognizes the crisis and how it emerges from it.Let's not forget that party conflicts in Macedonia are inseparable from ethnic tensions.Fortunately, the current disputes have not caused the crisis to spill over to a wider area of the already sensitive region.That is why our reaction must be consistent and timely.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! I cannot understand how people in the 21st century can quarrel over the name of a country that it shares with a neighboring region of another country. But if you take a closer look at the centuries, almost millennia of history of the region, it becomes clear. Nevertheless: A name dispute must not lead to a blockade. Otherwise, I welcome Macedonia's efforts towards the EU. I acknowledge the achievements in implementing the common acquis. I have great respect for what the small country has done to close the Balkan route. I regret that this does not find the grateful support of the EU more clearly. But I also see the country's current problems and combine that with a clear appeal to the EPP and S&D in this House: It is your member parties who are currently blocking stable development through stubborn behavior. It would also be up to Messrs Weber and Pittella to make a difference here. Then the efforts of the citizens of Macedonia can also be rewarded. Then it is “thumbs up” for the accession negotiations. We'll soon have a lot of space here in the house.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - Allow me to begin by thanking and congratulating my colleague Ivo Vajgl for an excellent comprehensive report, such as the problems in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. This country has been a candidate for accession to the European Union since the end of 2005. It has encountered blockades by neighboring Greece over long-running name disputes. And at this time, when Europe also helped Macedonia on this path, some economic progress was made, reforms were carried out. The state also solved the problems of the migrant crisis in times of crisis. However, it has entered a deep internal political crisis. This crisis is so deep that it has led, even after complications, first with the conduct of elections, to a blockade of the establishment of a government. That is why I think it is right for the European Parliament, the European Union, to continue to support Macedonia on its European path to help it resolve this conflict. I appeal to the leaders of these political parties to be aware of the great historical responsibility they have at the moment in the Republic of Macedonia.

name: Jens NILSSON
text: - Madam President!Thanks to the rapporteur for a very good motion for a resolution, very good.I, along with other colleagues, was an election observer in December, when the election took place.An election which, in the agreement that existed, was perhaps the most important step: to be able to carry out democratic elections and fair elections.All election monitors also said that this was done in a good way, so now everyone must respect the election result.An election that took place in exactly the same way as all other democratic elections.The parties go to the polls on their programs.After the election, they gather to see if they can find a majority.And right now there is a majority that could work, appoint the President, appoint the Government.But there are forces that oppose it.What we need now is a new government based on the election result, and we need to give that government a chance, for the sake of the people of Macedonia.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the rapporteur for this excellent report. The Union's enlargement policy represents an investment in terms of peace, security and economic opportunity, to the mutual benefit of the European Union and the countries aspiring to join it. However, it must be ensured that future Member States implement profound reforms in every sector, from transport to internal and foreign policy. Cross-border connections must be strengthened, customs procedures standardized and the results required by COP 21 shared. I am confident that the Pržino agreement will lead to a stable government with a view to joining the European Union. I also hope that a compromise will be found both with Greece, with which the dispute over the official name of the country is underway, and with Bulgaria for the improvement of mutual relations. I therefore reiterate the need to multiply efforts in every sector for a shared integration process that will bring benefits to Macedonian and European citizens.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Madam President, I would like to commend this report prepared by the rapporteur. I believe that it is necessary to take a positive approach to Macedonia and, despite all the problems, show it the way to European structures and to NATO. In my opinion, this report is very balanced, it clearly describes the political problems that are plaguing this country at the moment. After all, most of the speakers also talked about it. As a lifelong judge of judicial reforms in Eastern Europe, I am pleased that a large part of this report is devoted in great detail to the state of justice in this country, the state of the Public Prosecutor's Office and the state of the fight against organized crime and corruption. It is clear that judicial reform in Macedonia alone is not enough. The establishment of individual offices, such as the Office of the Special Prosecutor, is not sufficient if this office does not have a chance to carry out an independent investigation and its activities. I support the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Madam President, the report is inappropriate, untimely, out of date and highly utopian. No democratically legitimized government has emerged through elections and a political negotiation is currently under way. The four Albanian minority parties are meeting in Tirana, while holding underground talks with other parties in Albania and Kosovo. Much of the international community sees the break-up of the state and the permanent threat to the stability of the wider region. The report is a provocation to the detriment of reality. A fake solution is being promoted by realizing the nightmare of a greater Albania in the soft belly of the European Union. The only test solution is one and it is a one-way street: to accept the historical reality that there is no Macedonian nation and that they do not have any basis on the name "Macedonia". Only then will the name issue be resolved in order to open accession funds and at the same time the path to stability.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Madam President, the functioning of democracy is a prerequisite for the continuation of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia's path towards the European Union - because that is the official name of the country in this institution and in the European Union. Obviously, the reason why Skopje has not yet received a date for the start of negotiations is not the difference with Greece, as the report erroneously points out, the name dispute being negotiated under the auspices of the United Nations until a mutual agreement is reached. acceptable solution for everyone. The reason lies in the inability of Skopje's political system to accept the rules of independence, justice, freedom of speech, minority rights and, ultimately, to accept the election result. Because of these, ethnic tensions have risen dangerously. We must immediately deactivate, with the intervention of the entire international community, this bomb that could lead to uncontrolled ignition in the region. I understand that here in Strasbourg we are far away. But in Greece, in Macedonia, in Thessaloniki, we are adjacent to the bomb and any negative development in Skopje will endanger the stability of the region and its consequences will be directly borne by Greece, already burdened by the crisis.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, as stated in the report, conditions are currently in place in Skopje that are hindering the country's progress towards EU and NATO membership: political corruption, division, organized crime and the manipulation of justice. Nevertheless, there are some who claim that Greece is responsible for delaying the progress of the accession negotiations and even argue that bilateral disputes should not hinder this progress. First of all, the issue of Skopje with Greece, ie the issue of the name, is not bilateral. It is international. But, let's assume at some point that this name issue is being resolved today. Does anyone think this will help tackle Skopje's problems? Will there be unity in the country? Will Albania stop claiming its territories in the context of the creation of a Greater Albania? Will Bulgaria stop telling Skopje that you should not be called "Macedonia" but "Vardaska"? So let's be honest and try to put things in perspective. If Skopje does not comply with international law, it has no European perspective.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Madam President, I am concerned about the situation in Macedonia in which the political crisis has lasted too long, and all because of the interference and influence of other countries in the internal political affairs of Macedonia. Unfortunately, this crisis is not over. And while America and Albania are clearly showing their influence in that part of Europe, the EU institutions are extremely passive, although I consider them most responsible for the situation in Macedonia because they allowed the blockade of Greece and Macedonia has been unfairly in front of the European Union and NATO for 12 years. For the 38th day, Macedonian citizens have been protesting in the streets because they do not want Macedonia to be governed on the basis of a Tirana platform composed in another country. I understand the dissatisfaction of the Macedonian people because I personally would not like the establishment of the Croatian Government to be negotiated in another country. I call on all political actors in Macedonia to respect the Constitution, and above all to respect the will of their own people, who are the biggest victims of this political crisis and who did not vote for the Tirana Platform. I call on the European Union to open negotiations with Macedonia and thus send a message that it supports Macedonia's European future and that it cares about stability in the Western Balkans.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - I consider it a very important signal that the report draws attention to the fact that concrete measures are needed in Macedonia to create social cohesion between different ethnic, national and religious communities. It is a common mistake for international organizations to watch debates between national communities incomprehensibly and to expect tensions to subside on their own. In comparison, the right approach is what the report states: there would be a need to set up joint committees of experts on history and education with neighboring countries, which would contribute to an objective, fact-based interpretation of history. The only problem is that in Europe, especially in its eastern part, individual nations mean different things to objective historical facts. One can criticize this phenomenon, but it is a fact. The historic reconciliation that took place in the western half of the continent after World War II is still pending in the former socialist countries. And this has consequences for the whole of the European Union.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the political leaders of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia now have the urgent responsibility to take the necessary steps to put their country back on the EU track. This is what the vast majority of their citizens want. Too much time has been lost.  The continued crisis is already taking a heavy economic and financial toll. A government must be formed now. All parties must implement their own political agreement and tackle the urgent reform priorities as agreed.  The Commission remains highly committed to the European perspective of the country but let me be clear, the key to this EU perspective is in the hands of the President and local leaders. Only they can put the country back on the path to Europe. We cannot and will not do their job for them.  Thank you very much for your attention and for this constructive and forward-looking debate on the report.

name: Ian Borg
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me first express my sincere gratitude also for the excellent work and commitment of the rapporteur, and also his important recent efforts with Mr Fleckenstein and Mr Kukan. The Council, as I stated in my introduction, attaches great importance to moving forward with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. However, we remain seriously concerned as to the fragile domestic political situation, which was also highlighted by many of the speakers in tonight’s debate. The need for a constructive dialogue extends to all parts of the political scene, most notably to the main political parties. In this regard, we count on the continued support of the European Parliament in calling on all the leaders to cooperate in good faith and to overcome the current impasse and to put the country back on the reform track. I thank you once again for the opportunity to participate in this debate.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: Rapporteur. - We confirmed in this debate that Macedonia is a complicated country with difficult problems that it can hardly solve without the sympathy and cooperation of neighboring countries. It is important that neighboring countries understand the problems of this complicated multinational country and that they do not aggravate the situation by interfering in its internal affairs, which we have witnessed often lately. Macedonia faces difficult tasks on its path to the European Union. Today, we reaffirmed that Macedonia's progress towards membership of the European Union is not only in the interests of the country, but of the European Union as a whole and stability in the region. I expect that the crisis will come to an end, that the government will be constituted and that normal parliamentary life will be revived in Macedonia. It is also important that all parties are aware of the importance of national reconciliation, reconciliation and the inclusion of inclusive policies. No one should feel lost. A big national project is in front of everyone and everyone should be aware that they are acting in the interest of the state and the people of Macedonia.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place at the May I part-session.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - I thank my colleagues for the constructive work on the report. I am adamant that both I and the EQF group support Macedonia's aspirations for membership in the European Union. Unfortunately, the elections did not solve the problem and the country fell into an even more severe political crisis - on the brink of ethnic conflict. The lack of a government is holding back the accession process and pulling the country back. All political parties must recognize the outcome of the election, but the formation of a government cannot be done at any cost. The so-called Albanian Platform is clearly foreign interference in the internal affairs of a sovereign state. The political crisis that has gripped our neighbor can only be overcome with the support of Bulgaria and the EU. I believe that the Republic of Macedonia must first guarantee the rights of Bulgarians in Macedonia through legislative changes and only then look at the "Albanian Platform", because at the moment the Albanian community is recognized by the authorities and even represented by the two ethnic parties DUI and DPA, and the Bulgarians have no representation and are not recognized by any state body. The path of the Republic of Macedonia to the EU passes through good relations with Sofia, and I think the same for overcoming the political crisis.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the debate on the recommendation to the Council by Vilija Blinkevičiūtė, on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, on the oral question to the Council on the Committee on the Status of Women (CSW) (O-000027/2017 - B8-0214 / 2017) (2017 /2544 (RSP)).

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Author. - Equality between women and men is a fundamental principle of the European Union, enshrined in the Treaty on European Union. And our European Union is also guided by this principle in its external action, because women's rights and gender equality are not only fundamental human rights, but also necessary measures to promote development and reduce poverty, and the basis for a peaceful, prosperous and sustainable world. The European Parliament in February adopted its recommendations to the Council on the EU's priorities for March this year. The 61st session of the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women, held in New York, was dedicated to strengthening the economic power of women. The European Parliament's priorities covered five main areas. Firstly, it is a framework for strengthening the empowerment of women and girls, which means giving women the tools they need to become economically independent, equally represented and equal in all areas of life, gain more power in public life and control all decisions that affect their lives. Secondly, it is strengthening women's economic power and removing barriers in the labor market. And measures such as reconciling work and family life, closing the pay and pension gap, are very important here. Third, equal participation of women in decision-making at all levels. Fourth, the needs and problem-solving of the most vulnerable women, and these are women with disabilities, women refugees, women living in rural areas or in poverty. Finally, fifth and very important: all these issues and all these problems must have a sufficient budget, sufficient resources. So I now turn directly to the Council. Can the Council answer the following questions: how has the Council taken account of the priorities set out in Parliament's recommendation in formulating the European Union's position, and which points have not been accepted by the Member States? If not, why not? What were the main features of the European Union the progress made in negotiating the conclusions of the Commission on the Status of Women and to what extent was it possible to translate the European Union's priorities into a harmonized text of the conclusions? Finally, is the European Union achieving any results on global commitments in the field of women's health, and in particular on action to combat the negative effects of the so-called universal silence rule on women? As you probably know, the new US administration has announced the cessation of funding for the United Nations Population Fund, i. y. it is an agency that supports family planning policies around the world. Knowing that the US financial contribution to this program is particularly significant, such knowledge is really worrying in this case, as the United Nations Population Fund has saved the lives of tens of thousands of women around the world by providing access to family planning services, preventing unsafe abortions, supporting mothers and baby health. So how does the Council view such a message and how do you see the potential for strengthening the European Union's role in this area? It is clear that with the withdrawal of the United States from funding such important programs, the European Union must become a leader in this area. Another question that needs to be answered. Parliament supported the proposal to draw up an International Labor Organization convention with a view to establishing an international standard for tackling gender-based violence in the workplace, which is, in fact, very relevant. So, are there any plans to take any action in the future in relation to this convention to make such a convention come into being? And finally. Mr Borg, I thank you in advance for your answers and, of course, thank you for your cooperation with the Council. I also just want to emphasize and ask that, in future, we really need to strengthen institutional cooperation and coordination, because we have one common goal: ensuring women's rights and gender equality.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! Year by year, the UN session on women's rights is gaining importance, involving more and more and more and more important institutions and people. This is linked to the fact that there is a growing understanding of the socially and economically important issue of women's rights and equality. This year's session was devoted to the economic empowerment of women, and we all hoped that the voice of the European Parliament, which adopted joint recommendations especially for the session, would be properly heard. It is hard to find an institution in the world that can boast a longer experience in successfully promoting women's rights than the European Union, especially in terms of access to education and the labor market. Despite such strong legitimacy, we are not sure what our contribution was to the final conclusions of the 61st session in which we attended as Parliament's official delegation. The question of the results of negotiations is important in the context of the backlash phenomenon, which we observe worldwide in relation to women's rights. Backlash poses a huge threat to further progress, but also to the implementation of decisions already agreed. Ladies and gentlemen! Regarding the negotiations, I am particularly interested in the results of these talks on access to high-quality education. We know from European experience that education alone is not enough. Women graduate more often than men, but work in lower paid jobs and in lower positions. The more attractive the sector, the higher the position - the less women. These gaps are particularly visible in the ICT sector, which is the backbone of the economy of the future. Only 3% of tech start-ups are run by women. Women less frequently use the Internet and Internet services, bank, buy and sell online less frequently, and work and learn online less frequently. Internet and high technologies, which are a potential tool of change in the field of equality, which could facilitate the equalization of opportunities, become another cause of women's exclusion.This problem can only be solved by the appropriate quality of education, by appropriate programs and policies in this area, which is mentioned in the recommendations.That is why information on the effects of the negotiations is so important: what of the presidency's postulates were included in the conclusions in this area?

name: Anna HEDH
text: for the S&D group. - Madam President! Often, several times per session, we discuss the situation and gender equality of women in this House, tonight on the theme of women's economic self-determination. I am the rapporteur for the forthcoming report of the Gender Equality Committee on the same subject, and I attended the European Parliament delegation to New York and the 61st summit of the UN Commission on Women earlier in March. The European Parliament has recently stepped up its efforts for gender equality despite massive opposition, not least in response to, among other things, the United States' recent attempt to restrict women's right to their own bodies. Women's economic self-determination is fundamentally a matter of freedom for women. It is about the right to individual financial freedom. For me, economic self-determination is a central issue in gender equality work, but there are also other factors that today prevent women from enjoying the same rights as men. The fact that the right to one's own body, and the right to decide over it, does not always apply to women is incomprehensible to me. Since Donald Trump reintroduced "global gag rules", it is estimated to mean a financial deficit of about ten billion dollars, and most recently the United States withdrew its money to the UN Population Fund, about 32 million dollars. This development we are seeing, not just on the other side of the Atlantic, means that women will actually die. Women who do not receive the medical help they need are now falling victim to the policies pursued. Borg mentioned that some member states have chosen to compensate for the US restrictions on the right to SRHR, but the question is whether the Council will work to get more member states to do so and that the EU will do so.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I will focus on one question, and that is global abortion funding. The de-funding of the UN Population Fund is a very positive outcome from the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women. I am happy that the US is no longer funding forced abortion and involuntary sterilisation in China. The blood of Chinese women and babies will no longer be on their hands. This does not deny anyone maternal health care, as abortion-choice stakeholders in this House claim. Rather, it protects women from suffering the horrific ordeal of having their young baby torn limb from limb from the womb. These barbaric acts should cause an outcry, but not against me as the messenger, but against anyone cruel enough to support this gendercide. Feminists should be particularly outraged, as it is baby girls who are more often killed in the womb than boys. This is cruel, illegal discrimination. Let me be clear, abortion is not health care. There are no medical benefits. The EU should stay out of women’s uteruses.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on 14 February this year the FEMM committee, of which I am a member, approved a recommendation addressed to the Council, indicating some priorities that are being discussed in the 61st CSW. I would like to underline that there is a global movement, which on March 8th filled the streets of over 50 countries around the world to denounce, as does the recommendation of the FEMM commission, that male violence against women is the most widespread violation of rights. worldwide, which is independent of all factors of age, social class or economic condition and which harms entire communities, has significant economic and social costs and limits and undermines social growth. This global movement is called "Not one less". In Italy its main variation is currently the elaboration of a feminist anti-violence plan that will be presented before the summer. I say this because I think that an advance like this in Italy represents a European and global advance, because it can help restore violated human rights. The 2017 Commission on the Status of Women had as its central theme "Women's economic empowerment in the changing world of work". Violence against women, as underlined by the Istanbul Convention, which has not yet been ratified by 14 EU Member States, is not only physical violence, but also psychological violence, unpaid domestic work, wage gap. Here, I believe that we need to give more strength to the recommendations made by this Parliament. I believe that, for example, the work of the gender mainstreaming network should be made effective in the passage from the European Parliament to the Council and, in turn, to all the governments of the Member States.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, among the main priorities of this edition of the Commission on the status of women, in which I participated together with the delegation of the FEMM commission, were the economic empowerment of women, the challenges and objectives in achieving the sustainable development for women and girls and the emancipation of indigenous women. During the four days of the mission, the need for the European Union to accede to the Istanbul Convention and to consolidate cooperation with the United Nations for the fight against violence against women and for the achievement of equal treatment between men and women was stressed. women. However, one of the problems that could arise is linked to the lack of transparency and correct information towards all the actors of the international community, starting with the citizens. I believe that once the appropriate solutions have been found, it is only right to promote them in an institutional and above all in the media, to involve everyone proactively and to allow everyone to offer their contribution. Furthermore, as I personally expressed to the Secretary General of the United Nations, there is an urgent need to add concrete tools to current policies that can push Member States to implement existing rules and monitor changes over time, especially with regard to the rules. relating to the fight against violence against women. Only with the adoption of a holistic and transversal approach, which also includes education, education and culture, will it be possible to witness the emancipation of women and the achievement of gender equality.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Madam President, I am very pleased that we are trying here, after the Commission meeting, to evaluate the outcome of the negotiations of this important body and to ask what the conclusions of this institution's negotiations should be for European Union policy. I must say that I am disappointed with the way in which the Council representative approached today's meeting, because I was really waiting for the conclusions of the meeting that had already been evaluated, and the Council representative's response was that more or less the conclusions had not yet been evaluated. It is therefore difficult to debate the conclusions at a time when the conclusions are simply not evaluated, and therefore we remain with the general theses. I am sorry, because I consider the issue of the status of women and equality between women and men to be extremely important, not only in the European Union, but in the Third World as well. And we need to say what we can do to improve the position of women in the Third World. The issue of women and their economic position is very important, and it is clear what we will do in the future to compare the remuneration of men and women for the same work, in order to make it easier for mothers to enter the European Union after graduation. maternity leave, back to their jobs. What can be done to ensure that these women do not lose their professional qualifications and can continue their careers after maternity leave? And there are a number of specific things that I hope we will talk about in the future.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the coming years will be increasingly crucial in reaffirming the role of the European Union in defending women, and last March's meeting of the UN Commission on the Status of Women was a first fundamental step . The European Union is increasingly becoming a fundamental global actor to defend the role of women, to defend, of course, her independence, her emancipation, but not only economic independence and emancipation, as has already been said. I believe that we should increasingly oppose those systematic attacks that are made, for example, on sexual and reproductive rights that constitute, colleagues and colleagues, the basis of respect for women as an independent subject in her choices. And the results achieved to date cannot and must not be questioned. This is what we should be doing on the world stage. We hope that the Council and the Commission will continue these battles.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, I would like to begin by regretting the fact that we are left with the issue of women, as usual, until the very end of our negotiations. I think it would sometimes be appropriate for the status of women to get to an earlier meeting, for example. With regard to the current issues addressed, I must agree with my colleague Pospíšil that we do not have evaluated conclusions, so we will again present only general theses. The priority of the UN Commission on the Status of Women was the economic status of women and overcoming barriers in the labor market, as well as opening a debate on the empowerment of so-called indigenous women. The European Parliament has just adopted recommendations aimed at women's economic status and overcoming barriers in the labor market in February this year, ensuring an equal share of women at all levels of decision-making and addressing the needs of the most marginalized women. This was a recommendation. As I have heard, it was also reflected in the conclusions of this sixty-first session of the UN Commission on the Status of Women. I think that we should focus, especially in the future, on gaining global political support for the concept of equality, especially in the third world, and on analyzing the impact of current changes in the labor market on equality between women and men. Because, indeed, the labor market is literally overwhelmed by new changes and I think they should also be reflected in the position of women and their protection.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, women’s rights and gender equality are under attack around the world, so now more than ever we must push to strengthen international cooperation on women’s rights and empowerment, including our reproductive rights. The EU has always been a crucial promoter of gender equality in Europe, and on the world stage, and we must redouble our efforts for the sake of those who come after us at home and abroad.  The UN Commission on the Status of Women has been a key international forum for the promotion of gender equality and for mainstreaming a gender perspective across policy fields. At this moment in history, with misogynists like President Trump normalising sexual harassment and limiting women’s reproductive rights, the movement for gender equality must become unashamedly intersectional, in order to tackle the gravest forms of discrimination, exploitation and abuse that women face. We must be specific in tailoring policies that tackle the problems faced by different groups, be they refugees, migrants, young girls looking for an education, women with disabilities, or older women facing poverty.  We must be able to give a voice to those who have been denied one and we must make our voices heard in the corridors of power. We must ask men to step aside and give women a seat at the decision-making tables, particularly in policy areas such as defence and security, where we can offer an alternative to patriarchal warmongering and remind the world that it is always women and their children who pay the highest price when conflict ensues. The role of women in peace-building and conflict prevention is therefore crucial and both the UN and the EU have a key role to play in this respect.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Madam President, women all over the world face various forms of discrimination, the glass ceiling, the violation of their human and civil rights, which we often put in the background. The contribution to humanitarian aid is important and the European Union has an obligation to participate, but the gap that is claimed to have arisen as a result of the global blocking rule does not exist. America is allocating 10.3 billion US dollars for humanitarian aid. Most of this money, as much as 70% goes to HIV prevention and treatment. It is not true that the money earmarked for this purpose has been reduced. It is also not true that funds for medicines, maternity and postpartum care, contraception have been abolished. It is incorrect that funds for abortion are limited in cases where the mother's life is in danger and in cases of rape or incest. It is true that money is redirected to organizations that do not promote abortion as a method of family planning, which is in line with international conventions. When we talk about the United Nations Population Fund, he does point out in his program that he does not promote abortion as a method of family planning, but supplies a drug called “misoprostol” that is also used to induce abortion. I wonder why so-called family planning organizations put abortion promotion at the center of their work, instead of helping millions of women who want to have children, which they can’t.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, I would like to say that the empowerment of women has been the subject of this year's 67th session, but it has also been the subject of many parliamentary reports over the last two years, such as the report on women's poverty, reconciling family and working life. on the promotion of women in business and rural conditions. That is why I was interested in what position the Council defended and how satisfied it was with its results. I would like to say to the representatives of the Council that there are more of us here, and you have heard the speeches of speakers who do not agree with the European Union financing the abortion as a form of planned parenthood. This is not a measure that can help women. As a member of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, one student asked me this week about the balanced representation of women and men on this committee. I must have been ashamed to say that there were only 5 men out of 36 members. This is therefore not a balanced representation of full membership. I think that if we want to advise others, such as the United States, then we should first deal with a balanced representation of women and men ourselves.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, it is a given that the European Parliament has important positions both in promoting equality between men and women and in the emancipation of women and in equal pay. These views have also been expressed by the European Parliament. However, it is not certain that these views are shared by all Member States. And I think that's the point. Because, as the Presidency has said, yes, efforts have been made, but, in practice, we have 14 Member States that have not ratified the Treaty of Istanbul and we are going as the European Union to the UN to teach lessons to others. So there are serious contradictions within the European Union that need to be overcome. And I think the European Parliament is setting the tone. I would like to congratulate the colleagues who asked the question, because they highlight issues and contradictions. We, as the European Parliament, are fighting. The issue is what the Member States are doing.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: – Madam President, regarding the 61st session of the UN, I would just concentrate on a few points. The Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality criticised the US Government for how it spends its money on foreign aid and the new conditions it puts on its aid. The US is a sovereign country and only accountable to its own citizens. We, as the EU, also do not want to be criticised by others when we put conditions on the aid we give. I think the EU should rather attend to the aid it gives itself.  The 79 ACP countries that welcome EU aid sometimes find the conditions we ask on our aid to be socially oppressive. We are in no position to criticise the foreign-aid practices of other countries.  According to the UN regulations and regarding the wording, I think the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality should always remember one thing – abortion is no form of reproductive health or family planning.  Under this emphasis I would kindly ask Mr Borg to analyse the negative effects on women, especially mothers, of the global gag rule. We should by no means develop an own method of discrimination against mothers.

name: Ian Borg
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I thank you all for your input into this discussion, and for organising it as well. The Council, notably the Working Party on Human Rights, has not yet the opportunity to carry out its assessment. We will continue, as holders of the Presidency, to follow it closely and also keep Parliament abreast of the developments there. We have had a very useful debate that also clearly demonstrates the high degree of convergence between the European Parliament’s and the Council’s views on this matter. It is also clear that we cannot reach sustainable development goals without the active participation of women, and investing in women is the way forward. Therefore, the Council will work intensely in this direction. Once again, I would like to thank you for your debate and the invitation to participate.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: In written form. - I join the call for better results from the EU in terms of commitments to women's health, as a priority for the EU during the 61st session of the UN Commission on the Status of Women. I believe that ensuring health at global level must indeed be one of the main focuses for world leaders, including towards targeted support for reproductive health, health education and the upbringing of young women. These topics are essentially related to the demographic problems and the demographic policy of the countries and should be developed and applied differently, through reciprocal actions the specific circumstances of the demographic processes in the world. I hope that the Council will continue to urge our international partners to cooperate more and to focus on this area.
